DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1988-89APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 April, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Dr Hewson had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:

(1) budget estimates put Commonwealth Government outlays at over a quarter of Australia's GDP, and that this is funded by revenue collection that has made this the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;
(2) the Government's budget strategy is in tatters with its key forecasts on inflation and the balance of payments wildly off-track;

(3) the Government is locked into a strategy of sole reliance on monetary policy and high interest rates to bring the economy back on track with the result that home loan interest rates are now at their highest level in Australia's history; and

(4) the process of micro-economic reform has stalled with the Government either stopping or delaying much needed structural policies which are crucial if Australia is to increase productivity and to reduce its unsustainably high level of foreign debt'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89 is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the history books about the period of the Hawke Government are written, there will be quite a deal written about its commitment to social justice. It is my firm view that this Government's commitment to the concept of social justice and its implementation will ensure that it is firmly recorded that this has been and will continue to be a government of vision. A cornerstone of the Government's philosophy is the achievement of a fair and just society. I remind the House that that is based on concepts of equity in the distribution of economic resources, equality of civil, legal and industrial rights, fair and equal access to essential services such as housing, health and education and the opportunity for participation by all in personal development, community life and decision-making.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Budget passed last year the Government set about building on its already substantial social justice achievements by continuing to ensure a sustained fast pace of job creation, now at record levels-over 1.3 million jobs have been created by the Hawke Government-and by improving, through further increases in the family allowance supplement or rent assistance, the position of working families to meet the Government's commitment that no child need live in poverty.

It is the Government's concern about child poverty that I wish to emphasise today. At the last Federal election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was clear and explicit in his policy speech. He pledged that our Government would give top priority to ending the financial poverty of Australian families with children. He said:

By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty. And to this end, my Government will establish a new program of family help-a program designed to lift more than one million Australian children into security and to help the more than half a million Australian families in greatest need, the hardest pushed, the most disadvantaged.
Labor's new family allowance supplement will be paid to mothers on the basis of family income and family size.

That was the commitment this Government made. This Government set itself benchmarks, measures of adequacy against which it could be judged. We said that families with children under the age of 13 would get 15 per cent of the married rate pension per child. We said that families with children aged 13, 14 and 15 would get 20 per cent of married rate pension per child. That commitment was historic. For the first time ever a Federal government set a standard of financial support for all our children below which we will not go. We will reach that standard and we will maintain it.

We have made great progress towards achieving that pledge. In the seven years of the Howard-Fraser regime payments for children in low income families were increased once, I repeat once. In 1980 the payment was increased from $7.50 per week to $10-the only increase for low income families in seven years; an abysmal performance. On the other hand, the economic policy of the Opposition when it was on the treasury bench deliberately threw families out of work. The result was devastating. By 1983 one in five Australian children lived in poverty-a scandalous situation. In 1976, 370,000 children were in low income families; by 1983 this figure had grown to 830,000-a period when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer. The response of the Hawke Government in six years is clear and stands in stark contrast to the abysmal position of the Opposition when in Government.

We have increased pension and benefit rates in every year of our term: in 1983 from $10 to $12; in 1984 from $12 to $14; in 1985 from $14 to $16; in 1986 from $16 to $17; in 1987 from $17 to $22 for younger children and $28 for older children; and in 1988 from $22 to $24 for younger children and from $28 to $31 for older children. The progress is there to see. Under the Fraser-Howard Government in seven years there was one increase from $7.50 to $10. In real terms payments to families fell by an abysmal 35 per cent, which represents a dramatic reduction in living standards for Australian families. Under Labor, payments for younger children have increased in real terms by 61 per cent. What a comparison! A real increase so far by this Government of 61 per cent; a real decrease in the Fraser-Howard years of 35 per cent. This Government has increased payments for teenagers by 108 per cent to $31.

The story does not end there. The Prime Minister set benchmarks for child payments. We have set those benchmarks and we will reach them this year. We will lock in the real value of payments. The Prime Minister went on to say in his policy speech that the Government was not just on about getting all families out of poverty by getting their incomes up. He also said:

It is just impossible, with any credibility, to proclaim concern for families and then proceed to smash every part of the social infrastructure that determines the welfare of Australian families. Yet that is the measure of our opponents' hypocrisy.
Indeed, it is. He said:
For us, the family means jobs.
He went on to say:
It means child care. It means education. It means health care that every Australian family can afford.

How true his words were. This Government has maintained its extraordinary rate of employment growth. As I have said, it has created 1.3 million jobs. We have maintained our commitment to public housing and home purchase assistance. We have expanded rent assistance to low income working families. We have expanded child-care places at an unprecedented rate.

Retention rates in schools have exploded, from 36 per cent when we came to power in 1983 to the current 59 per cent, and tertiary places are increasing. These are the opportunities that this Government has set about giving Australian people-educational opportunities to ensure that they can find fulfilment in the work force. This Government has provided the fairest and most comprehensive health care system in the nation's history. Medicare grows stronger and stronger and the people who benefit most from this are Australia's working families.

The Government has gone further. Half of all children in poverty in 1983 were in sole parent families. We have introduced the child support scheme to deliver regular secure child support for them each month. We have introduced the jobs, education and training scheme to help sole parents to overcome the disabilities they face in the labour market, to give their families the opportunity to live like the bulk of other families in Australia. We have increased the mothers' or guardians' allowance in real terms. We have introduced the Newstart program to overcome the scarring of long term unemployment, to deliver to ordinary Australian working families shut out of the mainstream a new chance to share the full benefits of economic recovery-something foreign to the Opposition.

The debate about child poverty is a debate about standards, again a subject which is foreign to the Opposition. Because the concept of poverty is so ridden with value judgments, this Government set some objective standards. Each younger child should attract a minimum of 15 per cent of married rate pension. Each teenager should attract a minimum of 20 per cent of that rate. The Government did that following detailed work on the issue by Bettina Cass. The approach that Howard adopted in government was the exact opposite. To pass the hat around at the end of the Budget was his Cabinet approach. That approach resulted in one nominal increase in seven years and a massive reduction in real terms of 35 per cent. On the other hand, the nation has seen a dramatic increase in real terms under the Hawke Labor Government. The Leader of the Opposition now says that he does not even want to do that. He will reverse policies designed to protect low income families from the drop in national income. His personal document Future Directions says so at page 53. That is the measure of the Opposition.

If we contrast that with the performance of this Government we will see that the measures taken to assist families and children in poverty truly have as their basis the concept of meeting standards of social justice. When the history books are written, this Government will be seen as one of vision for what it has done in the area of social justice and for what it has done for Australian families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about the state of the health industry in Australia. In doing so I also want to talk about the Government's often repeated claim that two million Australians were disenfranchised under the previous Government and to speak briefly about the situation of people travelling overseas with Medicare benefit coverage. I have sat in this House for almost two years now and at least a dozen times I have heard from the Government that over two million Australians were disenfranchised from health care insurance prior to the Labor Government being elected. The last time I heard it was when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) mentioned it in Question Time last week.

SPEECH.PARA: When I tried to verify those facts I found a March 1983 document from the Australian Bureau of Statistics entitled `Health Insurance Survey', which was the last health insurance survey undertaken by the Bureau. Table 14 in the document looks at the number of Australians without health insurance. Rather than the two million figure that I have heard talked about so often, the figure in the table is actually 1,031,500. But if one looks closer one sees that 391,000 of those lived in Queensland and had access to free hospital treatment; a further 140,000 had pensioner health benefit cards or access to medicine under repatriation benefits; and another 123,000 said that they did not need health insurance because they were healthy enough and they chose not to have it. That leaves 376,500 people, which is a far cry from the two million people that I have heard about so often. Irrespective of whether Medicare was introduced to help two million or 376,000 people, one must ask what the effect will be in my home State and your home State, Madam Speaker.

Two days ago the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health released its December quarter figures on health insurance coverage around Australia and these figures have set a new low mark. They showed that 46.2 per cent of Australians now have private health insurance-for nine successive quarters there has been a drop and that is yet another record low since health insurance statistics were first taken over 15 years ago. What is happening because of this? The financial viability of the health funds is threatened; there is an increased burden on our public hospital system; and there is an adverse effect on the elderly.

Rather than the Prime Minister waxing lyrical, as he did last Tuesday, about what has happened in the health industry, he should look at the industry. He will find that it is having a very difficult time, for a number of reasons. The first reason is reinsurance. This is a measure first proposed by the then Government in 1979 to pay the costs of nursing home-type patients who were in private hospitals. It was a commitment by the then Government to the elderly of Australia. Initially the amount was set at $50m but it was increased to $115m in 1982-83. It is now sitting at $1m and the funds have had to pick up the difference. The second reason for the difficulty is the introduction of Medibank Private. That health insurance fund has had the ability to transfer profits from Victoria around Australia, thereby underpining its national operations. Other funds have not been able to do that. Other funds have not been able to share joint costs and appropriate them to the health fund in a beneficial way.

The Government has specifically prevented funds from accumulating special reserves for long term hospital patients; then it complains when the funds have difficulty in meeting those obligations. The Government has added a burden of $500m to Australia's private health insurance in the last five years. Specifically, it has abolished the bed day subsidy, at a cost of $140m a year; it has reduced benefits for medical services in hospitals from 85 to 75 per cent; and it has lifted the $20 cap. That has added a $105m burden to the health funds. The Government has required health funds to pay for prostheses and it has determined that patients going to public hospitals are deemed to be private.

In Victoria there is a chronic nursing home shortage. Per head of elderly population, Victoria has the lowest number of nursing home beds of any State in Australia. What that means is that in country hospitals where there is not the access to nursing homes, privately insured patients go into a hospital even though they should be in a nursing home and the health insurance funds have to pay their costs. The average cost is $52,800 a year. With the current premium rates it would take 142 years for the health funds to recover those costs; yet they are having to pay them right now. That leads us to the present situation where health funds in Victoria are making a combined $30m loss in the financial year, on top of a $20m financial loss last year. That cannot continue if the funds are to keep operating.

Looking through the history of health insurance in Australia I came across the summarised findings of the Nimmo commission in 1969. It found in looking at private health insurance that the operation of the scheme was unnecessarily complex-beyond the comprehension of many; that benefits received by contributors are frequently much less than the cost of hospital and medical treatment; that contributions had increased to such an extent that they were beyond the capacity of some members of the community and involved considerable hardships for others; that an unduly high proportion of contributions received by some organisations were absorbed in operating expenses; that the cost of illness may include, in addition to hospital accommodation, treatment and medical service, a wide range of other services which had never been covered by the health insurance scheme; and that there was a high level of reserves held by some organisations.

That was 20 years ago. For all the great rhetoric that we hear about how much things have changed, they have not changed at all in 20 years. All that has changed is that from a high level of reserves we now have health funds which in some cases in my State are below the statutory two calendar months requirement. While that is an artificial figure-I concede two months may not mean anything if health funds are making a profit-if health funds in my State are making a $30m loss, the two calendar months requirement becomes very significant.

What will this mean? It all impinges very severely on the elderly in the population. The Government has recognised the need for reinsurance. Indeed, we are expecting legislation on that in this place in the next couple of weeks. A particular problem with older people is that if they are nursing home-type patients, the health fund has to pay. If they are older persons-over 65 years-they will take $3 out of the funds for every $1 they put in. I understand that the response of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) will be to share the costs between all the funds. I also understand that the Government will remove its obligation to the reinsurance pool. That reinsurance pool, which was set up in 1979, recognised the Commonwealth's direct responsibility for care of older people.

Since the 1950s the Commonwealth had actually paid directly the bills of nursing home-type patients and chronic patients. The reinsurance fund was set up as a more efficient way of dealing with these payments. From being $100m in 1981, this contribution to the care of elderly Australians has now dwindled to $1m a year. While the Government concedes the need for reinsurance, it will remove its own obligation to look after elderly Australians-an obligation government has conceded since the late 1950s. It says, `We have to have reinsurance but we don't want to have anything to do with it'. It is a very short term fix. It will cause the level of health insurance to decrease significantly below what is already a record low level. It is very hard to see how the funds in my State and yours, Madam Speaker, can survive, given that situation.

The final thing I mention is a situation raised with me by a constituent; that is, Medicare benefits for people travelling overseas. The situation was changed on 1 January by the Government. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) in the other place-I quote from the Senate Hansard of 20 December 1988-said:
. . . not all of those who travel overseas get sick-so why should those Australians who do not have the privilege of travelling overseas subsidise those who do?

He went on to ask why people in those special circumstances should not protect themselves merely by taking out comprehensive travel insurance and not be a burden on the others. There is a particular problem with this argument and that is the situation if one has a chronic illness. I do not know whether it has happened to you, Madam Speaker, but if one has a chronic illness and one attempts to get comprehensive travel insurance one will not be covered. We have a situation where any Australians with, perhaps, diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis who attempt to get travel insurance overseas find they do not have Medicare benefits covering them and they cannot get covered by health insurance. This is of particular concern to such people. It appears that it has not been recognised in that legislation and it is of great concern to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to speak about a matter of great concern not only to the people of my electorate of Bowman but also to many others on Brisbane's southside who are experiencing severe noise pollution problems as a result of the opening of the new Brisbane Airport last year. I raise this matter in this debate because it is an example of the huge capital investment being made by the Federal Government in a project which, because of bad planning, particularly in the late 1970s prior to this Government attaining office, is now causing misery to many thousands of people who happen to be unfortunate enough to live under the flight paths of the new Brisbane Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The source of their anger lies not so much in the fact that they have the noise-although obviously that concerns them, as I will tell honourable members later-but in the fact that they have never suffered this noise before. With the opening of the new Brisbane Airport the noise shifted from one area of Brisbane-in other words, an area where it had always been-to a completely new area. What is angering people the most is the fact that they purchased properties in areas where there was no noise pollution and, all of a sudden, they find themselves underneath flight paths, with the resultant loss of their peaceful use and enjoyment of their properties and the loss of property values.

Those who had the foresight to investigate the potential difficulties at the time the new airport was proposed were assured that all planes landing at and departing from Brisbane's new airport would do so over Moreton Bay. The people of Hemmant and Tingalpa and other areas that are not in my electorate, such as Morningside, Camp Hill, Belmont-parts of which are in my electorate-Cannon Hill and a number of other southern suburbs now have a discomfort which at times becomes absolutely unbearable. I remind honourable members that no curfew exists at the new Brisbane Airport. The noise is something that residents have to contend with 24 hours a day. In fact, yesterday the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) asked the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) why 11 aircraft were allowed to break the curfew hours at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport because of the air traffic controllers' disruptions. I remember that the answer to the question was that special dispensation had been given because of exceptional circumstances. I accept that to be the case.

What is the difference between the thousands of people who live around Brisbane Airport, particularly those who have never been subjected to this sort of noise before, and the residents of Sydney? I am all for the curfew at Sydney Airport but I just wonder what differentiation is made between residents around Sydney Airport and those around Brisbane Airport. They are no different. It seems fairly obvious to me-and I will discuss this later-that whatever the reasons were for the curfew being lifted at the Brisbane Airport those reasons no longer exist and the curfew should be reimposed. I hasten to add at this point that neither this Government nor any previous Labor government instigated the planning for and the construction of the new Brisbane Airport. Decisions on the location of the new airport and the construction of its runways were made long before the present Government came to office in 1983.

I want to say one thing which I am sure those who suffer the noise problems would want me to say on their behalf. Frankly, I am sick and tired of the doubting Thomases, those who continually berate and ridicule the noise affected residents and those who berate and ridicule even people like me because I always make it an issue and because I always stand up for what I believe in. I believe that these people should enjoy what everybody else in areas that do not have airport flight paths enjoy-that is, the peaceful use and enjoyment of their properties.

Some of the comments that I often hear are: `It is not that bad', `Surely you can get used to it', `Obviously, you are exaggerating', `The aircraft have to go somewhere'. It is easy to say, but I wonder how those people would feel if aircraft were going over their houses. I challenge any of these doubting Thomases in the media, in surrounding areas and even amongst colleagues on both sides of this House to come and live in areas that are affected by noise pollution, or at least spend a day and a night there and see what it is all about. Unfortunately, the attitude of a lot of people is the attitude that sometimes permeates throughout the community-that is, `I am all right Jack. It does not matter because it does not affect me'.

I can tell the House that two people, Warren and Jean Bowden, are very actively involved in the noise protest action groups in the Brisbane southern suburbs. I have had cause to call them on a number of occasions. Only the other day I spoke to the Bowdens on the phone and twice during that three minute conversation Warren had to say, `Stop, I cannot hear you because there are planes going over our house'. I was on the other end of the phone and I could not hear him speak. I could actually hear in Canberra the extremely bad noise they were suffering in Morningside which is not in my electorate; nevertheless, they are people who are affected. In addition to that I have received a letter from one of my constituents. This is only an example of some 600 letters that I have received. Some of them are in more serious terms than this. This letter is from a Mrs Major, a lady who is in her advanced years and who resides at Morningside. Amongst other things she states:
I got my house washed down on the 18th December '88 as it was a disgrace with black fallout, no doubt due to the planes overhead. It cost me $80 . . .

I was away ten days over Easter and when I came back and saw my house I could have cried very easily after paying to get it washed down three months ago as well as to preserve the paint which was done 2 years ago this coming May. With the rain we have had the house is almost as bad as it was before I got it washed down.
It is senseless on the Aviation Department's view denying fallout. At times you can smell it no lie and that is why myself and many others are suffering with sinus and other respiratory complaints.

I not only can't hear T.V. but sometimes they seem as though they are coming in my back window. Why should we have to suffer this after living in a suburb for 60 years paying rates, insurance, etc and have to put up with this in our late years.
I am willing to let anyone come and look at the outside of my house to see the fallout which comes down worse in wet weather.

She goes on to talk about those sorts of problems. I have at least 600 of these letters that contain examples much worse than Mrs Major has given. I sympathise with what she has to say because I can relate to exactly what she is talking about.

At the time of the planning for the new airport it was widely stated in official publications and documents that Brisbane's new airport would mean relief from noise problems for many neighbouring suburbs. In fact, a document which I have in my possession states:

New runway alignments will mean take-offs and landings will generally be over Moreton Bay, reducing the number of homes adversely affected by noise from 3500 with current airport operations to fewer than 20. By the time aircraft leaving the new airport pass over residential areas, they will be high enough not to create a noise nuisance, giving Brisbane an airport capable of operating 24 hours a day.

As the residents of Brisbane southern suburbs know all too well, this statement is clearly false and the thing which angers local residents is that many professional people and other individuals made public submissions at the time the planning was being carried out to the effect that the new airport would do nothing to improve noise conditions over Brisbane and would, if anything, exacerbate these problems. The Federal Joint Committee on Public Works and the Brisbane Airport Advisory Committee were two groups which were looking at submissions from professional and public bodies around the time of the planning of the new airport. Indeed, the honourable member for Griffith, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), and the State member for Lytton, Mr Burns, both warned of the consequences should the airport be built in the area as planned. In a submission to those committees, the air traffic controllers said:

It will not reduce noise pollution, but merely move the noise sensitive area to a new group of suburbs. Imagine the shock and bitter disappointment which will pervade the citizens of Brisbane when operations commence from the new runway.
The air pilots' submission stated:

We were told what the Department was doing but we had hoped all along that people would sensibly see the error of their ways . . . unless we can point out to you the total disaster this area is going to be without a cross runway, I think we have failed.

We may well ask why these committees did not heed the warnings given to them by professional and community groups. It is now recognised that the reason for the siting of the new Brisbane Airport at its current location and the alignment of the runway was purely political. The Federal seat of Lilley at that time was held by Mr Kevin Cairns who was under extreme pressure from his constituents to do something about Brisbane noise problems. I know how he felt. It is widely acknowledged now that the decision on Brisbane Airport was largely influenced by a desire to hold the seat of Lilley for the Liberals.

None of the bitterness or finger-pointing which we politicians sometimes indulge in will solve this problem. The reality is that we now have this airport and it is operational. It will achieve nothing to blame previous governments, and I do not intend to do that. But I do want to make it quite clear that whilst it is a problem that we have inherited as a government, it is a problem that was foisted upon us by a previous Liberal government. Therefore, the issue is not political. I hope that those who live in the vicinity of Sydney Airport, who will suffer further noise pollution as a result of the third runway, will not blame the Labor Party and its members. If they were to do the silly thing and elect Liberal candidates, the Liberals would be quite happy to put five or six parallel runways there. There would be a fourth runway, a fifth runway and a sixth runway.

The configuration of Brisbane Airport is as follows: The main runway, known as O19, is the one causing all the problems. In addition to that runway, there is a smaller runway, known as 14/32, which is perpendicular. We call it the cross-runway. This smaller runway is not suitable for larger aircraft but is aligned in such a way that the overwhelming majority of take-offs and landings would be over Brisbane's Moreton Bay. The cost of expanding this cross-runway is something which this Government will seriously have to consider in the near future. The alternative to extending this cross-runway is to build a runway parallel to the existing runway. This is the worst fear of local residents, as it would mean a doubling of the noise problems which they are already expected to endure. The Joint Standing Committee on Public Works concluded in 1981 that the 14/32 cross-runway is best to meet the demands of forecast traffic in terms of safety and noise pollution and that it should be extended for these reasons.

People in my area are extremely wary of the recent decision to build a third runway at Sydney Airport. They quite correctly liken it to building a parallel runway at Brisbane Airport, which would compound the aircraft noise pollution, health and safety problems currently being experienced. It is expected that Brisbane will become Australia's second largest airport in the next decade or so. We have the opportunity now to avoid the situation which is faced in Sydney. We now have the opportunity to stop all plans for a parallel runway and start investing in the extension of the cross-runway, 14/32.

The other matter which has made my electors quite angry is the fact that the curfew on Brisbane's old airport was lifted on quite false pretences. At the time of the planning for the new airport, it was stated that it would be curfew-free but it was stated that this was possible only because the new airport would supposedly not provide any aircraft noise problems. In fact, the glossy brochure put out by the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation said, `There will be fewer than 20 houses affected'. That was an absolute lie.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a fraud.

—It was a fraud. The reality is that some thousands of houses have been affected. So much for the credibility of the civil aviation authorities from the 1970s until the present. Frankly, I think the Civil Aviation Authority has a lot to answer for when it comes to the question of the use and enjoyment of people's properties, whether it be in relation to the Sydney Airport or Brisbane Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: A survey of 78 homes at the end of last year by one of the noise protest groups which exist to lobby on this issue revealed that 84 per cent of householders living in the vicinity of airports live in fear of low flying aeroplanes and the dangers of a crash. The survey also pointed out that a number of very serious health problems are associated with people living near airports. In my electorate and in the southern suburbs of Brisbane two voluntary social workers have had to be employed virtually on a full time basis to counsel these people who are being driven mad and who, as I say, are having respiratory problems and other associated problems. There are so many of these people.

My electors and the electors of the south side are getting tired of this problem. They expect someone to try to help them. I pay special tribute to the previous Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), who took some notice of my problem, of the problem of the southside residents. He visited the electorate. He spoke with the protesters. He was all but ready to announce a package of measures which I believe would have helped the situation. Unfortunately, he resigned from the Ministry. He must be commended for what he did because it shows the sincerity of his wishes regarding the use and enjoyment of properties by his residents. He made the ultimate sacrifice; he sacrificed a ministry, which we all aspire to in this place.

The airline companies, as well as the Civil Aviation Authority, have a responsibility to the public they supposedly serve to ensure that noise pollution is not continued in residential areas. I have written to both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines Ltd asking them to do something about the problem. Ansett at least wrote back. That arrogant company, Australian Airlines Ltd, did not even bother to acknowledge receipt of my letter. It stands condemned for that. I call on the new Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) to revitalise the package, to come to my electorate-which I am sure she will do, as I have already made an appointment to see her-and do what the residents want. They want an extension of the cross-runway so that all planes will go over the bay; they want the introduction of a curfew or at least restrictions before any international terminal is built; and they want airline companies to reschedule their noisier aircraft out of Brisbane Airport so that residents do not have to cop all that noise. They do not want a parallel runway to be built at any time in the future.
I support the legitimate concerns of the people on the south side of Brisbane. I assure them that I will continue my fight to help them as much as I possibly can. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) may be concerned about aircraft noise, but Australians are concerned at present about whether aeroplanes will fly at all. It would be good to see the Government taking some strong action in regard to the current difficulties being experienced by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) with air traffic controllers. If this country is to continue to have small unions holding vital transport services to ransom, it will suffer a great loss to its economy and to its developing tourist trade. Perhaps the honourable member could turn his mind to those issues.

SPEECH.PARA: During debate on the Appropriation Bills one may talk about a whole range of financial matters. I wish to talk about some of those issues today. Tonight we will hear an economic statement which will impact upon all of us, regardless of where we live in this country. Some areas in Australia have particular concerns. I refer to regional Australia-farmers, people who live in provincial cities and those who live in the smaller States. Not all Australians live in large cities although, admittedly, the vast majority do.

The Government, in determining the range of activity of its financial programs, needs on all occasions to take into account the needs of regional areas in this country. Families in regional Australia have been suffering for a considerable time and continue to suffer. All of us know that inflation levels, as high as they are, and interest rates-the blunt instrument of economic control being employed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-impact on all of us. But when one takes those issues which impact on family incomes and puts them together with some other policy directions taken by government which affect people in regional Australia, one sees that they are suffering a double whammy. I think this Government is ignoring some of those people.

I represent a seat in Tasmania. We have taken consistently disproportionately larger cuts from this Government during its period in office. The editorial in the Examiner in Launceston on Tuesday, 11 April, stated that further cuts in government spending are indeed necessary, as all of us would recognise, to address the economic imperatives we, as a nation, must face. Quite simply Australia cannot afford to have tonight a statement which is an election-based, economic package. If there is an avoidance by the Government of making tough decisions, we will all be the sufferers.

The important point is this: When the Government determines spending programs and future policy options, each area of Australia deserves to be treated fairly. It is quite clear that Tasmania-and I am sure people from South Australia and perhaps from other States will have similar views-has been treated particularly unfairly in recent years. Indeed, only last week on 7 April the Hobart Mercury ran a headline titled `Fairness essential in federal spending'. The editorial went on at some length to castigate the Federal Government for its system which militates against Tasmania getting its fair proportion of Federal Government spending, especially in the capital works area.

The figures that were released by the Federal Government confirm that Tasmania has been missing out badly on money for capital works. They show that total government spending on capital works in Tasmania in this and the next few years will amount to only $38.62 per head. This compares with $198.96 per head in New South Wales and $157.44 per head in Victoria. The figures are contained in the document `The Commonwealth Construction Programme 1988-89' published last month. Those details show that Tasmania is at the bottom of the scale in terms of expenditure per capita. Tasmanians of both political persuasions are upset and outraged at the treatment they have received.

Tasmania gets next to nothing in the way of defence projects. It has been the practice in this place by those on the other side to criticise the former Prime Minister, but from Tasmania's point of view Malcolm Fraser was concerned about Tasmania. He recognised the importance of regional Australia and was prepared to govern for all Australians. With the Hawke-Keating duo, we are starting to see a selective approach in terms of expenditure of Commonwealth finance to buttress areas where they think they will maximise votes. That is an abrogation of the responsibility that is reposed in them as the leaders of this country to treat every Australian as far as possible in a fair and equitable way. As I said, the people in my State of both political persuasions have not been treated fairly.

I ask the Government to reconsider all that it is doing with regard to Tasmania. The Government knows that the loss of the Wesley Vale pulp mill was an economic blow not just to Tasmania, but to Australia. Admittedly, there needs to be a balancing between environmental and economic concerns and all of us in this place search for that, but we need to put in place proper mechanisms, proper consultative arrangements, and guidelines that are published well in advance so that everyone knows where he or she is going. If we do not do that, we will end up with the difficulty that we have just experienced and the debacle that occurred during that Wesley Vale program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we do not want that again.

—I acknowledge the presence in the chamber of the honourable member for Lyons, who, I am sure, would share my views that we do not want to see Tasmania suffer continually at the hands of a government that is concerned only about buttressing capital city votes.

SPEECH.PARA: Another major event that has taken place on the Opposition side of the chamber has been the establishment of the Waste Watch Committee. This Committee has been very successful in identifying waste in government. It was formerly chaired by the shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). The Committee is now chaired by me and has on it the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) from Western Australia and the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) from New South Wales respectively. It is quite clear that our economy is under seige and it is more important than ever to improve productivity and efficiency and to ensure that taxpayers' dollars are spent wisely. The Waste Watch Committee's early successes in identifying and stopping extravagances such as the $200m Commonwealth employment program excesses and identifying the silly grants such as the $11,000 for the Wild Women Surfboard are well known to many of us. Others that received less publicity were far in excess of those examples.

Waste Watch will be looking at those types of areas and at new areas. We want to look at defence procurement and at ministerial consultants. The use of ministerial consultants is an industry that has been growing quietly in the background. We want to identify whether those consultants are actually doing work or whether it is a case of money being paid to mates by Ministers. That would be totally unacceptable.

We want to look at the statistics gathering arrangements in this country. The Australian Bureau of Statistics needs to gather statistics, but the time it takes small business people to fill out returns that are required from the Bureau needs to be questioned in a little more detail than ever before because in business time is money. We need to have a good database, but we do not want to overdo it. I suspect that we may well be overdoing it.

We need to look at a myriad of other Federal Government spending areas, but we aim to identify constructively waste and low productivity areas in the Federal administration. At a time like this in Australia's history when we are suffering extreme economic pressures that are not being managed with the proper response, we can criticise the Treasurer for charting an economic path that is taking him down a road to nowhere. He is using that blunt instrument of interest rates; he will send the economy into a recession; and his response tonight will be nothing more than a political posturing exercise to try to offend as few as possible, but to create that window of opportunity so that he can go for an early election as soon as possible, perhaps even before the next Federal Budget.

It is that management of the economy that will be the test in this chamber of who will form the next government. I have every confidence that it will be the people on this side of the House who are now charting a new course in the face of the reality of what is happening to the economy and where it is going. The future government, composed of members from this side of the House, will treat regional Australia fairly. It will take account of the fact that it should not just buy votes in capital cities, that it has a responsibility to look after all Australians. Tonight will be a very interesting test.

I come back to some more recent examples of government waste, as identified by the Waste Watch Committee. Yesterday in this chamber there was great debate about the future role and administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. We have had detailed debate on that issue. It was interesting to see that the Auditor-General's report on the Department of Aboriginal Affairs confirmed what our spokesman had been saying for a long period; that is, that there had been maladministration of that Department. The previous Minister bears a great responsibility in this area, but seems to be escaping scrutiny. The current Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) stonewalls every question, but he knows that the administration of the Department is in a complete mess.

An example that was revealed in the Auditor-General's report showed that $5,000 was expended in only four months on replenishing the nine bar fridges belonging to the Secretary, deputy secretaries and regional directors. Another example was the $3,500 spent outside the Secretary's guidelines and Finance direction on hospitality for meals. It was a common occurrence, apparently, for officers of the Department, while in receipt of travel allowance, to claim for meals when meals were already provided as part of hospitality.

That sort of activity is not acceptable. It has been identified by the Auditor-General and ought not to be happening in other departments. Those in other departments ought to be aware that people on this side of the House take a particularly dim view of that sort of activity. It is the responsibility of Ministers administering departments to ensure that that sort of activity does not take place. They ought to be personally involved in much closer scrutiny of the administration of their departments.

Abuses have been revealed by the Auditor-General at the highest levels of the Aboriginal Affairs Department. Admittedly, the sums are small but, as all of us know, problems begin when we start to think that sums are small. Each dollar is important to every Australian. Every Australian wants to know that each dollar he spends in tax is spent wisely. He wants to know that it is not wasted and that he is getting value for money. He knows that if we in this place make the dollars go further he will have to contribute less in the way of taxation and he will be left with more in his pocket to pursue his personal priorities, whether holidays, education for his children, or whatever. It is far better for each Australian to determine his spending patterns than for us in government to take more and more and spend it and, more importantly, spend it unwisely.

Another interesting area the Waste Watch Committee has identified has been that of the prices network. The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) runs around the country talking about how we need to look at prices and pursue the issue of prices. He says that it is terrible that the prices are going up and in the same breath says it has nothing to do with the Government, that it is all the fault of big business. Government does have a responsibility. I suspect-and have made the allegation-that the Government, with its prices network system, is creating a political front, a political blind. It is appealing to people's base prejudices. None of us likes high prices, but the Government is trying to divert attention from its failure to address the fundamentals that need to be addressed to ensure that businesses can put products on shelves at prices that people can afford.

How is it doing this? Perhaps you, Mr Deputy Speaker, should know, as you are a member of this Government. I understand that the Government has a Caucus secretariat from which it employs additional staff. These additional staff are allocated to Labor Party members, one of whom is the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), to assist in creating and developing prices network information which is put together in press releases right around the country. These press releases claim the Government is doing all it can and the problems are all the fault of business or supermarkets; they are nothing to do with the Government.

We have discovered that since 1 July, 12 staff have been employed part time in various offices. They are paid at the rate of $13.64 an hour. All the senators and members connected with the prices network have been provided with fax machines. For example, $46,000 is provided annually by the Federal Government to employ part time staff in the office of the coordinator of the Caucus committee secretariat for this specific purpose. Why is that particular grant made directly to the Caucus committee secretariat? Another $87,000 has been provided to five Federal Labor members of parliament for additional hardware and software in their offices to gather information on this prices network. Grants in aid totalling $66,000 have been paid to the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations and the Australian Pensioners Federation to try to encourage them to be supportive, not critical, of anything that the Labor Party does. That type of direction of funding is not in the best interests of Australians. If those funds were directed towards developing more realistic policy options, allied to what the Treasurer could be saying tonight, the question of supermarket prices and other issues would be more readily addressed.

Admittedly-and we have said this consistently-price watching is not in itself inherently bad. It does have some advantages. But we maintain that in its price watching the Government is trying to captivate genuine price watching, convert it to political ends to support its own needs and divert the attention of people away from the fundamental issues that are causing problems. These fundamental issues include an inflation rate which is three times that of our major trading partners, trade deficits and the level of imports and the lack of policies that support import substitution. Those are the things on which this Government should be concentrating; it should not be spending money on getting Labor backbenchers to run around the country making good fellows of themselves.

Another example that I should quote, given that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) is in the House, is the recent example of the advertising campaign on the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme with the generic drug initiative. There was some frivolity in the marketing strategy used and that is indicative of the gimmickry that has been part of the approach of this Government in trying to get its message across. We have had the Priority One: Young Australia situation and we have had other instances where a lot of funds have been spent in just trying to get the message across in a gimmicky sort of way. But this giant pill exercise in recent times takes the prize. Pharmacists received a plastic capsule, 10 inches in length, containing information on the changes that had already been sent out to them three times before. The information contained nothing new. The capsule is a great big container that cost three times as much as a standard letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do they do with the containers?

—I will come to what happens to the containers. The total cost has yet to be revealed by the Government but I think it ought to be. There may well have been consultants involved in this strategy and they charge a great deal of money. Between $40,000 and $50,000 may well have been spent to send out information that pharmacists and doctors already had. That information was sent out to some 30,000 doctors and 5,000 pharmacists around the country. Members of the Government might say it was a good idea. But what do the pharmacists and doctors think about it? They pay tax. They know they have a responsibility to deal professionally with changes in drug arrangements and they will do that. But let the Government ask them what they think about it. We have had these little red and white containers dropped off at our offices around the country and I would not be surprised if there were members on that side of the House who have returned these containers suggesting that this marketing strategy is over the top; that it is a waste of money. That is an example of the types of excesses of government that Australia cannot afford any more. We want efficient government. We want government that takes account of every dollar that it spends, taking the view that a dollar saved is a dollar less that we have to take out of the pockets of ordinary average Australians who are suffering greatly.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be my role as Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, together with my colleagues both in the Senate and in this place, to identify and bring to the attention of Ministers, some of whom do not seem to take a close enough interest in the administration of their portfolios, ways in which money can be constructively saved. That is the important thing. All of us in this place want to be constructive. We want to save money and taxes. In that way families get a better go and we get a better Australia. That is something which we should all be pursuing with real diligence in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin let me say that honourable members probably will not like this speech because it is about a new tax, not removing tax. I would like to begin by quoting C. S. Lewis, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Future is something which everyone reaches at the rate of 60 minutes an hour, whatever he does, whoever he is.

The majority of the Australian people are aware of the nuclear winter, the greenhouse effect, ozone holes, et cetera, and the general destruction of our precious environment. I would like to approach the environment question from another perspective.

For some time scientists have been trying to contact other civilisations in distant worlds and there has been no sign as yet that there is anyone else out there. It appears that we on Earth are alone. When we think about this it is obvious that we are custodians of life for this whole universe. We have an awesome responsibility. We have to survive and we have to make certain that future generations survive so that they may explore and expand into other worlds. This may appear a very fanciful dream to some, but I can assure honourable members that before the year 2100 humans will be living on a number of planets within our own solar system.

Our environment on this planet is deteriorating extremely quickly as our ever-increasing population rushes to use the resources with which the earth is blessed. Every person has the right to a decent standard of living. If the world's millions had the same standard of living as that enjoyed by the majority of the Australian population, the planet's resources would be consumed and devastated in a very short time and pollution would wreak havoc on our environment. Some time ago I proposed in this House that a levy be placed on polluters and pollutants to fund research into the greenhouse effect. As yet nothing has happened in respect of that proposal. However, I am very pleased to note that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) have announced that approximately $8m has been allocated by this Labor Government for research into the greenhouse effect.

I would like to go further than that and propose that a pollution tax be introduced immediately. This proposition has been looked at by a certain Wallace Oates, a professor of economics at the University of Maryland in the United States of America. Some of his arguments for a pollution tax are very compelling. Taxes on pollution not only offer an effective policy approach to the protection of the environment but also provide a very appealing addition to the revenue system-I am sure Senator Walsh would be very pleased with this proposal. Whilst most taxes have a harmful side effect on the economy by distorting economic choices, taxes on pollution have a socially beneficial side effect in that they cost society less than the revenue they produce. I am certain also that this sort of tax would be electorally acceptable.

The economic case for pollution taxes is really just a straightforward corollary of the logic underlying a market system. The proper functioning of a system of free markets depends on the emergence of a set of prices that accurately reflect the cost to society of the resources used in the production of goods and services. Prices are the basic signals in a market system that direct the flow of resources to their most productive use. For most goods and services, the market forces of supply and demand generate the proper price.

Under certain circumstances, however, such prices may not reflect true social cost-and pollution is a classic case of such a circumstance. The basic point is straightforward: the absence of an appropriate price for certain of our scarce environmental resources, such as clean air and water, has led to their overuse, resulting in what the textbooks call a case of market failure. A producer, for example, whose factory spews smoke on a neighbouring residential area is using up a scarce resource-clean air. Put slightly differently, the producer is imposing real costs on those who must live with the dirty air. But the firm need not bear this cost in the same way that it pays for other resources-labour and raw materials-that it employs.

While the price of labour and materials encourages the firm to economise on their use, there is no such incentive for the firm to control its smoke emissions. Whenever a scarce resource is made available free of charge, as is the case where individuals have free access to our limited stocks of clean air and water, it is bound to be used to excess. Producers and consumers alike must be made to bear the costs that their activities impose on others if they are to be expected to adjust these activities in light of costs.

From this perspective, the basic cause of excessive environmental degradation is the absence of an appropriate price for scarce environmental resources. Once accepted, this proposition has a direct policy implication: the need for government to intervene and, in the absence of the interplay of supply and demand, to impose an artificial price, a tax or effluent fee, on damaging waste emissions. It is easy to show in terms of micro-economic analysis that if this tax is set equal to the value of the damages from an additional unit of emissions, sources will have the proper incentive for controlling their discharges of pollutants.

Pollution taxes provide a powerful set of incentives that encourage both the selection of the proper control technology among existing options and the search for new and more effective abatement procedures. Such activities would be directly profitable to polluters since they would reduce costs. For example, a firm that discovers a less expensive way to control its waste discharges could employ this new technique to reduce its discharges yet further. It would realise savings both on its control activities and on its tax bill as a result of lowering the level of waste emissions. Society benefits from the cleaner environment that results in turn. A system of pollution taxes would effectively harness the powerful market force of competition on behalf of environmental protection.

Some concern has naturally been expressed over the potential inflationary impact of taxes on pollution. However, these concerns have, I think, been greatly exaggerated. Pollution taxes would constitute only a tiny fraction of the costs of most polluting industries so that their effect on the prices of final outputs is likely to be small. Moreover, a system of pollution taxes will set in motion a process of innovation in abatement technology that over time should lead to significant cost savings that would largely offset or, perhaps, more than offset any inflationary effects.

I feel that today-the day that the April statement is about to be brought down-is a very appropriate day for me to raise the question of a new tax, a tax that I have said before would be acceptable to the majority of the Australian community. This very day we read that once again the oil companies are pressuring the Government to lower their taxes and Senator Cook has announced a review of the oil excise regime and the total tax structure for the industry. The oil industry is one of the world's greatest polluters, if not the greatest. I feel that it should be the first to pay a pollution tax. It is responsible for car emissions and oil spills. The latter have been graphically demonstrated by what happened in Alaska. The oil industry is responsible for all of those things. That industry has made billions of dollars from the resources of this planet. Now is the time for it to give a little back, to repair some of the damage it has done.

A pollution tax that is spent on returning our environment to a healthy and safe place to live in I am certain would be worthwhile. We are running out of time and I believe that we should act immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve months ago on a Supply Bill in the old Parliament House I had the opportunity to present a maiden speech, joining three other contemporaries who had recently joined Parliament-the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) and the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott). As the member for Adelaide I am pleased to have taken my place in this Parliament and to speak on behalf of my constituents scores of times on a lot of issues affecting retirees, pensioners and veterans and on issues such as the Government's mishandling of the availability of X-rated and pornographic videos and drugs in schools. Today is the very significant day that the April economic statement is to be brought down. There are two teams promoting the cause of their champions and there is a lot of heady debate. When the people of Australia dissect what is going on, I guess they still see the democratic principle of parliament working in a true cause. I guess they will see further examples as the jokes go around Australia from the comedy cafe. The latest one doing the rounds is, `If the answer is Paul Keating it must have been a very silly question'!

SPEECH.PARA: Today the people of Australia will be treated to another bout of pre-election conning by the Hawke-Keating Government. In exchange for the much touted tax cuts they will be asked to forget or put aside the six years of mismanagement and hardship experienced under this Government. The people are somehow expected to forget the serious decline in living standards since 1983, the chaos which characterises the nation's health system, the ballooning trade deficit and, in particular, the spiralling home interest rates which are quickly crushing the Australian dream of home ownership. The people of Australia will be asked to forget all these things in exchange for a fistful of dollars. What contempt this Government shows for the people of this country that it should expect them to forget so readily this record of disaster for the sake of a few extra dollars in the pay packet-dollars which, on the evidence of the last six years, will disappear quickly enough as living standards continue to drop further and further.

Living standards have dropped in any of a dozen areas. One can point to any number of Government decisions which have prejudiced the position of ordinary Australians. The examples I would like to mention in this debate are recent ones, but every year of the Hawke Government is replete with similar examples. Last year the Government announced changes to health reinsurance arrangements which will have far reaching and potentially disastrous effects on the health insurance industry and on its capacity to provide affordable health insurance to all Australians. This announcement was the culmination of a series of changes this Government has effected to the private health insurance industry since coming to office, none of which have helped the affordability of adequate health insurance for Australian families.

The reinsurance pool established by the Fraser Liberal Government in 1976 was designed to subsidise the high claim rates of the sick and elderly and spread the burden of such claims between health funds. All funds had access to the pool to which the government of the day also contributed. Underpinning the establishment of the pool was the principle of community rating, which demands that every contributor to a health fund pay the same amount, regardless of age or state of health. However, since 1983 the Federal Government has progressively retreated from support of the concept the reinsurance pool embodies. In 1981 the Federal Government contributed $125m to the pool. Today that figure is just $1m. That drop amounts to a massive withdrawal of government support for the aged and chronically ill in our community, since the inevitable effect of this decline in funding has been greater upward pressure on the contribution rates of private health funds, particularly as they affect pensions.

One has only to find a few examples of where the Government has lopped $124m from a single program to realise that tax cuts of the order we will no doubt see tonight are close to meaningless. What the Treasurer (Mr Keating) gives with one hand, he will quite surely take back with the other. Moreover, the Government is supremely out of touch if it believes Australians do not notice what is going on. I have received many letters from constituents in my seat of Adelaide expressing concern at the proposed changes announced by the Government to the reinsurance scheme, in particular from the contributors to the South Australian Police Employees Health Fund. The Secretary of that health fund, Mr G. Mackinnon, has provided me with a copy of his submission to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) urging the abandonment of the Government's reinsurance proposals. I also wrote to the Minister in March supporting the points raised by Mr Mackinnon. As yet, several weeks later and despite the urgency of the matter, I have not had the courtesy of an acknowledgment from the Minister.

The South Australian Police Employees Health Fund was established more than 50 years ago. Like many employee-based funds, its operating costs have been kept to a minimum-3 per cent compared with 17 per cent in the case of some other funds-and maximum benefits have been made available to members. The letters from members of the fund support the Secretary's claim that the fund is managed efficiently, is viable and provides an effective personal service in health insurance to employees of the South Australian police department. The Government's reinsurance proposals will undoubtedly increase the premiums payable to funds such as the South Australian Police Employees Health Fund. Significantly, many of these are from retirees who have maintained their private health insurance in their senior years. The suggestion that the Government's changes are designed to benefit the older members of the community is clearly not supported by those retired members of that force.

The Government's reinsurance proposal should not be seen as an isolated step. It is very clearly part of a structured, progressive campaign against the very concept of private health services. The Government has not flinched, from its first day in office, from the path of centralising and socialising medicine and health care in this country. Medicare the institution has outgrown what it was designed to achieve. The patterns whereby the Government has pursued this goal are unmistakable. Medicare has been only part of the process. The burden which the Government has sought to place on private health funds has mounted from year to year. The burden has included abolishing the Commonwealth bed day subsidy to private hospitals; increasing the benefits funds have to pay to psychiatric and rehabilitation patients; preventing funds from accumulating special reserves to cover long term patients; and shifting the cost of prosthetic implants from the States to the funds. Of course, with each additional burden imposed on the funds, their attractiveness and competitiveness diminishes. That is the Government's intention and it is succeeding.

Membership of health funds has declined for the last nine quarters in succession. Today the proportion of people with private insurance has slumped to just 50 per cent of the population. Today the House was given the latest figure, which is 46 per cent, by a conservative member. The saddest figure of the Government's whole strategy is that the health funds could, if the Government permitted them to do so, play an important part in reducing the blow-out in Medicare expenditure which we have experienced. That would be good news indeed for the 100,000 Australians awaiting elective surgery. Yet the inescapable fact is that the hikes in health insurance costs which Hawke, Keating, Blewett and co. have made inevitable will force more and more people, especially senior citizens, out of private funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to other honourable members by their constituencies.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As if that was not enough, the Government is mounting a vicious assault on the ageing in other ways. They are penalised for thrift and made increasingly dependent on government handouts. Those who manage to retain some financial independence are confused by continuous and complex changes to the tax law. What a disgraceful way to treat our elderly!

SPEECH.PARA: In mentioning another area where the Government's decisions have had a disastrous impact on the ordinary Australian, I refer to the recent changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). The Government has delisted from 1 April some 21 brand drugs from this scheme. But that is by no means the only change it has initiated. Concern in local pharmacies up and down the country is at an unprecedented level. The fact is that many are set to go to the wall, and the Government is almost entirely to blame. I have had some correspondence on this issue but none so articulate as one letter from a pharmacist in Adelaide, whom, I suppose, I cannot name for ethical reasons. He shows convincingly in his letter that the costs he will have to bear as a result of changes to government policy will push his business to the limits of profitability. He says that as a consequence of the Government reducing wholesaler margins from 15 to 10 per cent, he will lose about $275 a week. The decision to increase the maximum quantities of over 100 PBS drugs will cost him $470 a month in additional outlays, reduced dispensing fees and extra labour and container-purchase costs. The fee he can charge to dispense drugs is reduced by another government decision by 10c per script.

Once again, the elderly are major losers in this little package of horrors. As pharmacies are forced to close-and that is inevitable-the older members of the community will have further to travel to obtain medication. In addition, the Government has failed to take into account the valuable role the local pharmacist plays in diagnosing and treating minor ailments. Reduced frequency of visits, and indeed fewer pharmacies, will put a heavier burden back on the already overburdened Medicare system. It can ill afford that.

I turn to another area where the Government's record is none too proud. In recent years we have seen unprecedented attacks on the standard of living of veterans and war widows. Just what do those people have to show for six years of Labor Government? I will examine briefly the last four years. In 1985 the travel allowance payable to veterans was reduced by half to a flat 11.6c per kilometre. Since then there has been only a small increase to offset that cut. The big losers are country veterans who have to travel long distances. At the same time, subsistence allowances to veterans, including meal and accommodation allowances, have been substantially reduced, saving the Government $500,000 but costing veterans and war widows dearly. Under the dental scheme four categories of treatment have been limited to a maximum $300 annual limit with no consumer price index (CPI) adjustment. Totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension criteria have been tightened up. In fact, veterans in the retirement phase of their lives are no longer eligible for TPI.

The Government made provision for termination of the dependant allowance by commutation, albeit on a voluntary basis, and there was to be no further increase in the dependant allowance. War widows and their dependants, as well as service pensioners with their fringe benefits-what is left of them-no longer have access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. War widows who also received an age pension have had their social security component frozen at a maximum level of $60, once again with no CPI adjustment. In 1986 a 2 per cent cut in Defence Force retirement benefits pensions was imposed, along with a six-week deferment from early November 1986 of the CPI related increases for veterans' pensions. From 1 January 1988 a $5,000 statutory patient contribution was imposed on veterans in nursing homes for war related conditions. On top of all this there has been a series of cutbacks in the list of drugs available under the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, along with an increase in the number of drugs requiring prior authority and adding greatly to the administrative burden. What a shameful litany of betrayals to the people who fought for our country, people to whom we should give thanks for the democratic freedoms we enjoy today.

And so with this kind of record in all these areas, who could really trust the Government, expect this Government, somehow to restore with a few paltry tax cuts the devastation it has wreaked on this land during its term? It would require cuts on a truly massive scale to make up for this sorry record. In any case, are tax cuts really the issue? Are they really what the Australian people most want the Government to deliver? I suspect not. I believe that the issue most close to Australians today is interest rates. I would like to address several matters of concern in this area. In today's Australian, the headline says it all-`Rates, not tax, voters' real fear'. There is no doubt that Australia deserves a pay increase and a tax cut. It is not the housing starts people are concerned about but rather how they will fund them, how they will handle the interest rates, the overdraft, the mortgage repayments, the consumer debt. My bank manager tells me that he is worried about my overdraft. I tell him, `It is no good both of us worrying about it-that is what he is employed for'. But we still have to service the consumer debt.

It is obvious that this Government has lost touch with the majority of Australians, the workers it purports to represent. Honourable members opposite have conveniently forgotten what it is like to be a wage earner, a person on a fixed income who gets a gut-wrenching feeling when the bills strip him bare. It is about time they remembered. They have forgotten the economic woes that the Government brings to Australians. Certainly, the rhetoric that is applied to competition, productivity, manufacturing and imports and what we will hear both today and tonight smacks of some sort of hypocrisy. Even in this excellent Parliament House, which is in our national capital of Canberra and which is the centre of learning and government, we find that the stainless steel containers we use for tea, milk, sugar and condiments come from China; the clocks, with their intricate bell-warning mechanisms, are imported from England; the radios are made by Mitsubishi under contract from China; and the desk blotting pads come from Denmark. I would have thought that our manufacturing industries could have supported some of that.

In conclusion, tied in with the contributions by some honourable members to the debate on the economic woes, the litany of broken promises, the high interest rates and their spiralling upwards that concerns a lot of constituents, is the very sensitive foreign investment policy. We are faced with two conditions: either we have to borrow or we have to sell. Australians are genuinely concerned about selling off the farm. I echo those sentiments. I also support companies in South Australia which have offices around Australia such as Kumagai Gumi Co. Ltd, with its joint ventures, and Mitsubishi Motors Aust. Ltd, the giant car component manufacturing company which probably saved several thousand jobs in the failing Chrysler car plant in Adelaide. It is a most important area. It is something that must be addressed in the future. The government that holds the key to that will have to address the problem most seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one needs reminding these days of the problems Australia-and Sydney, in particular-is facing from the pollution of its harbours, rivers and beaches. For almost the whole of this last summer, courtesy of some excellent investigative reporting by journalists of the Sydney Morning Herald, the full horror of the disgraceful state of the waterways in and around Sydney has been brought home to the residents of Australia and one of the world's most beautiful cities.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the obvious damage to the health of those people who choose to swim in the areas worst affected, the pollution caused largely by sewage outfall is having a devastating impact on the New South Wales fishing industry and is starting to impact on the No. 1 growth industry in Australia-tourism. I might add that most of people's fear of the fish is unnecessary, as only a minute proportion of the fish available for consumption is caught in the polluted areas. Nevertheless, the fear is real enough and the impact on the fishing industry has been quite devastating.

It is not my intention to spend the time of the House going over the reasons why this present shambles has occurred. However, it is worthwhile quoting the article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 4 March, which said:
The conspiracy of silence between these two bureaucracies-
the Water Board and the State Pollution Control Commission (SPCC)-

has been under way almost from the day the SPCC began operations in 1971. Long before this, the seeds were sown for the scandal which is only now starting to surface. Two key elements were the abrogation by politicians of a direct interest in the board's work and the emergence within the board of an engineering elite.

A cosy relationship between the Sydney Water Board and the State Pollution Control Commission has been instrumental in making the city's beaches unfit for swimming and contaminating the marine food chain.
The relationship means that one government body monitors another, with political realities dictating that it is in no-one's interests to blow the whistle.
Herald investigations into the environmental scandal of the beaches leave the two bureaucracies, either singly or in concert, accused of having:
