fixed pollution standards at levels which the SPCC knew to be unjustifiable but which suited the board.
consistently understated the health risks of swimming at our beaches and used measurement criteria which both knew to be hopelessly inadequate.
secretly dumped thousands of tonnes of highly-toxic sewage sludge into Sydney's waters despite warnings of abnormalities in marine life.
tried to shift the blame for what has happened on to the public.

Vital decisions have been made regularly behind the closed doors of the board and the commission. They were made despite a steady stream of evidence that the decisions were wrong or, at best, questionable.

Throughout the shambles, the two organisations have condemned all opposition. They have kept from the public not only internal reports which seriously questioned their policies but also alarming scientific research.

The roots of what is happening on the beaches today stretch back more than 100 years to the formation of the Water Board as a power unto itself. One of the oldest statutory bodies in New South Wales, it officially came into being in 1888 to cope with the demands of a growing metropolitan area.

Most of the domestic sewage and much of the industrial waste from that vast area-as much as 1,000 million litres daily-is dumped into the ocean through three main outfalls at Malabar, North Head and Bondi. This waste has undergone only basic treatment to clean it up.

This is not the time to start apportioning blame. All the governments in New South Wales, both Labor and non-Labor, must share the blame. About the only one so far that cannot be held responsible is the present Greiner Government, although its immediate predecessor in the non-Labor chain-if honourable members will excuse the pun-the Askin Government, is part of the history of neglect and ignorance.

Federal governments, with one rare exception-the Whitlam Government-have taken little interest in the problem, taking the traditional view that sewage was Sydney's own business-again, if honourable members will excuse the pun. When the Whitlam Government came to office in 1972 more than three-quarters of Sydney's residents were without sewerage. As the Sydney Morning Herald team went on to say:

The politicians remained happy for the board to run itself and solve the city's problems as it saw fit. Pipes and drains were rarely `sexy' election topics, although former Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, took some mileage from the subject. Mr Whitlam likened himself to the Emperor Augustus, who had found Rome a city of brick and left it a city of marble. Mr Whitlam said he had found Sydney unsewered and left it fully flushed.

Our present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is known as `the Great Communicator', whilst his predecessor, Gough, will go down in history as `the Great Flusher'. `It's a shitty job', he once said, `but someone's got to do it'. It was Gough, of course, who referred to Australia as `the effluent society'.

The important point now is not to look back in anger at what we should have done but to concentrate on what can be done in the future. In all the discussion that has taken place in recent months, the most depressing feature has been the pessimistic outlook about cleaning up the mess. Mr Tim Moore, the present New South Wales Minister for the Environment, who seems to have taken to his new position with enthusiasm and relish and who does not appear to be frightened of talking to the big industrial polluters, has forecast that it will take up to 10 years to clean up the mess. That seems to me to be not a very attractive prediction.

What I wish to raise today is the fact that one major Australian company of high standing in the community claims not only that it could, if it started tomorrow, clean the sewage outfall problem within two to three years but also that it could do it at reasonable cost. When I first heard this claim, my first reaction was one of total disbelief. Who were these people who claimed they could solve one of Australia's worst pollution problems and do it quickly and reasonably? As soon as I could, I arranged to meet them to find out whether they were for real. A lot of questions came to mind. Were they a bunch of shysters who were jumping on the bandwagon? Were they a group of dreamers who had an unrealistic faith in their ability to solve these mammoth problems? I arranged to meet with the executives on a couple of occasions to satisfy myself about their bona fides. The more that I have talked to them, the more that I have read of what they have done and can do, the more I am convinced that governments, both State and Federal, should be talking to them and examining what they have to offer. If their claims are exaggerated they can be quickly tested. If their claims are right we have a very exciting solution to what seems an intractable problem.

First, let me give a few facts about the company, Memtec Ltd, which is located at Windsor in New South Wales. This company was first listed on the stock exchange in March 1984. It has assets of over $200m and in the half year to December posted a profit of $5.585m. It employs 700 people world wide and has offices in the United States of America, Japan, Europe and, of course, Australia. Its chairman is Mr Dennis Hanley. I think that establishes that we are not talking about some backyard operation with a bunch of nutters running the show. What is exciting about the company is neither its personnel nor its profit or asset backing but the fact that it is now one of the largest filtration groups in the world. It has developed a filtration membrane that is the most advanced in the world. It claims that it is at least six years ahead of the rest of the world. Put simply, its filtration membrane can filter all extraneous matter out of waste water. Let me repeat that it claims that it can filter all extraneous matter out of waste water-not 90 per cent, not 99 per cent, not 99.999 per cent, but the whole lot.

It is important to be aware that this claim is not some wild fantasy. Already Memtec's technology is being utilised in a variety of areas. The wine and food industry is utilising it; our Federal Government, through the Department of Defence, is utilising it-the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), as an ex-hero, would be familiar with what I am talking about-and the Royal Australian Navy is using the technology in its submarines.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean, an `ex-hero'?

—Honourable members opposite should pay attention. This frivolity does not become any of them. Memtec filtration units are used to desalinate water, thus enabling submarines to stay submerged for much longer periods. The Australian Army is using the technology in mobile field units so that scarce water resources can by recycled for washing and drinking. Gone are the days of the old bush shower. Memtec is winning contracts with some of the top companies and government instrumentalities in the world. Current customers include Revlon (Australia) Pty Ltd, Atomic Energy Canada Ltd, L'Oreal, the United States Army and Navy, Schweppes Pty Ltd, Nestles Australia Ltd, Coca-Cola Australia, and Baxter Japan. So we are not talking about a little backyard operation. More to the point, Memtec is now working with major water authorities in the United Kingdom, Japan and the Middle East.

SPEECH.PARA: Memtec's work is not entirely unknown to Australian authorities in the sewage treatment area. At a plant in Dural over the last 12 months Memtec, in conjunction with the Sydney Water Board, has been testing a highly advanced self-cleaning membrane filter system which can change secondary sewage into pure water. The new process requires no chemicals and produces water free of both bacteria and viruses. Memtec has proven conclusively that this process is effective for the finer treatment of sewage and it is now focusing its technical attention on the scaling up of its manufacturing process and the reduction of cost in its equipment for large scale installations. It has also been involved in water treatment programs where its technology was used to produce 100 per cent pure water.

I could go on recounting the successes of this very innovative and exciting technology. What staggers me is that in all the brouhaha in recent months about Australia's polluted rivers, harbours and beaches I have not heard any mention of the company or its technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of Memtec?
—Yes, Memtec.
—That is in my electorate. I often mention it.
—I have not heard the honourable member mention it. I certainly have not heard him say anything about it in the Parliament or in the press. He is not doing his job. Shame.

SPEECH.PARA: In my discussions with the executives of the company I have been surprised at only one thing: governments in Australia, both State and Federal, do not seem to be fully aware of what this company can offer the nation. As I understand it, by the use of its tertiary treatment system adapted to existing outfall systems into rivers, harbours and beaches, it can gradually ensure that what is going into the system is 100 per cent pure. Much that is filtered out can then be utilised as nutrients for use in agriculture. So even the muck that is cleaned out is not wasted; it is put to good use. What continues on its way is pure water.

Obviously, the question of cost is very important. But when I talk to these executives it is very difficult for them to say, `We can do it at so much', because the problem is enormous. But they are saying that they can do it at a reasonable cost; certainly at a lesser cost than anyone else can do it, but they can do it properly. In all our discussions so far other people have said, `It will take us 10 years and, at the end of 10 years, we are not really sure whether it will work and we will spend hundreds of millions of dollars to do it'. The executives of Memtec say that if they can get the cooperation of governments, they can do it soon, they can do it in two to three years, they can do it 100 per cent and they can do it at a reasonable cost.

I am not here as a publicist for this company. I am saying that it seems to be the only company that claims that it can do it. We have this problem that has been headline news in our papers month after month. Once upon a time people surfing off Sydney's beaches used to be worried about the Noahs. Now they are worried about the Henrys. I understand that it is not a very pleasant experience swimming off Sydney's beaches these days. I hope that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and the State Ministers listen to what these people have to say, give them a chance to put their case and, hopefully, if they are right, we can solve the problem quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89, which are money Bills. Usually money dictates capacities and I wish to talk about the capacity of Australia and our defence forces to protect Australian interests. I note in the Bills that some $47m has been budgeted for and allocated for Australian defence industries soon to come into operation. That is something that the Opposition supports. I note also that some $7.3m has been allocated to the United Nations Transition Assistance Group serving in Namibia. Of course, we have always supported and will continue to support our involvement in that peacekeeping operation. We wish those troops, the main body of whom will be deployed this week, the very best in their deployment. It will be a difficult operation however much we might like to think otherwise. Some people have already been deployed and they are experiencing the difficulties of a peacekeeping operation in a country such as Namibia which has been at war in one form or another for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of overseas deployment, it would appear that the Government will also be faced with some commitment to a peacekeeping operation in Cambodia. Again, in principle, that is something the Opposition supports. As we have said before, we would also support reasonable requests that may come from Papua New Guinea, which is experiencing considerable internal problems. The Australian Government has said that it will be responsive to any requests and we would certainly support an approach. It is not good enough for Australia not to assist a country with which we have had a long historical and very close relationship which is now experiencing increasing domestic difficulties.

The main criticism that the Opposition has of the present Government's defence policies are these: firstly, defence has never been funded to the level on which the policies were based-that is, the 1987 White Paper; secondly, over the last six years there has been a continual decline of our defence capabilities; thirdly, there has been a lack of any meaningful or extensive regional involvement; and fourthly, over a number of years there has been quite a shameful and deliberate neglect of our Defence Force personnel.
Let me turn to the question of funding. The 1987 White Paper stated:

This Government recognises that considerable waste and inefficiency in defence planning is inevitable when unrealistic guidance is given as a planning basis for defence spending. The Government is committed to more realistic financial guidance for defence spending . . .
The Government then went on to say that this White Paper was based on a real annual increase of 3 per cent. The White Paper continued:

If we are to achieve the levels of defence capability and the priorities reflected in this Paper, there is a need, over the life of the program, for an allocation of resources generally within the order of 2.6 per cent to 3.0 per cent of GDP.

Since that White Paper has been produced-it was three years ago now-funding has never approached that level. This year the percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) allocated to the defence budget has fallen to 2.4 per cent, which is the lowest proportion of GDP since 1950. The White Paper claims that the Government:
. . . believes that this level of resources will enable the strategy outlined in the Defence Policy Information Paper to be maintained.

Every time there has been a cut in defence funding-and that has been three times so far-the Government says that the White Paper is still on track. There is a limit to the credibility of such statements. The Government says that it is going to cut back the money but that everything is all right. After a while the integrity of the White Paper is destroyed, as it has been. What has happened? As the funding has been cut back the big equipment programs have been left in place and the operating budget and the personnel programs have suffered.

I want to take a brief look at what has happened in the last few years on the question of capabilities. Firstly, there have been severe cuts in regular Defence Force personnel-some 3,000 in the last three years. All units are feeling the pinch, and all units are expected to do more with less. In the long term this means that when these units are deployed to the field they simply do not have the manpower to sustain themselves in field conditions over a long period. In some units we have the problem of low morale and the will to serve. For many personnel the feeling that one is doing a useful, important job has been destroyed. With dedicated personnel it is possible to achieve anything, but if the people in the Services do not believe they are doing a worthwhile job and that the Government is looking after them and needs them, then their pride and their profession of arms will be destroyed. Unfortunately in too many cases that is exactly what has happened.

A few day ago I was talking to three young Army majors all of whom are leaving the Army. I said, `Why are you leaving at such a time when you have your whole life and professional career ahead of you?' Three of them independently said, `We are leaving because we believe the Government no longer cares about Defence Force personnel'. These men who have served for 10 years and are about to start putting their experience back into the Defence Force are leaving. Unfortunately that story of the three young majors is typical of the reasons that so many people give when they leave the forces. Because so many have left we have this dramatic decline in experience levels in all out units.

A week or so ago I was at Tindal for the opening of the important new air base outside Katherine. No. 75 FA18 squadron has been posted to Tindal, comprising 600-odd people, I think 12 planes, and eight pilots. Of the eight pilots, the commanding officer of the squadron and the second in command could be described as having a reasonable level of experience. The remainder were almost totally without any experience whatsoever. They are good men and good pilots, but we cannot run an operational squadron if we do not have people with the experience not only to look after their colleagues but also to pass it on to those who follow. This dramatic drop in experience levels has been caused by wastage rates which have reached unprecedented record levels and the shameful neglect of personnel: 50,000 have left the Australian Defence Force in the last six years out of a total of some 72,000.

Let us look at some of the other capabilities. Continual cuts in the operating budget have meant that exercises and flying hours have been reduced. Army training last year was cut by 10 per cent, and there is more to come. Kangaroo 89 is the biggest exercise we have seen in this country for years. It will take most of this year's and next year's operating budget resources and facilities. In the White Paper, the Government stated:

The Government's defence planning will continue to provide for modest annual real increases in operating costs, recognising that it generally costs more to operate modern and more capable equipment than it did to operate older designs of equipment.

Again, this is a hollow promise because operating costs since that date have continually reduced. Let us look at some of the other capabilities that have also been reduced in the last few years. We have lost the aircraft-carrier and the fixed wing component of the Fleet Air Arm has gone. We are now leasing back from New Zealand, under some arrangement which is not yet clear, the Skyhawks which a few years ago we sold to it for a song. It is totally unacceptable to the Opposition to have that arrangement in place because it is dependent on the whim of the Lange Government. The Lange Government's record in matters of defence and regional security is so abysmal that we cannot trust that arrangement for any length of time. The amphibious squadron has been disbanded and the landing craft have been scattered. We still have no ship that can carry the Black Hawk helicopters. Elements in the Army artillery have been mothballed. The pilots for fighter squadrons have been reduced from 18 to 12. The Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) staff college has been closed because there are not enough officers in the RAAF to attend as they are required for other duties.

Right now on the desk of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) we have options which he is considering for further cuts. Cuts in RAAF flying hours, further cuts in Army exercises, further reductions in manpower, the First Brigade of the First Division is being looked at to see whether it should be retained or whether some of the units in that Brigade should be disbanded, including the First Armoured Regiment. One option is to get rid of the F111 squadrons at Amberley, our most effective and visible deterrent. Another option is to get rid of, disband or mothball an FA18 squadron and it certainly looks as though the Chinook heavy lift squadron at Amberley will go. The decision has already been made to disband that squadron. That decision is being looked at again. I hope that people will realise that it is not only an effective military asset, but also a national asset in view of the work that it has done in the recent floods.

If we get rid of the Chinook heavy lift squadron, what are we going to do for the tactical movements of fuel and equipment around the battlefield? Are we going to use the Black Hawks? If we use the Black Hawks, they certainly cannot do the same job and this means that they are being used for tasks for which they were never designed. For the Government to say that it is not considering that option is nonsense. The personnel in that squadron have been asked to fill out posting preferences already. Now they have been put on hold and they do not know what they are going to do.

Exercise planners for Kangaroo 89 are not sure whether the Chinooks will be there, so they have taken the only sensible option and decided to plan the exercise without them. It is an absolute shambles. The White Paper contains policies basically for the defence of mainland Australia. Paragraph 217 of the White Paper states:
In general Australia's environment, our strategic environment around us, is favourable.

The authors of that paper may have thought that at the end of 1986 and the beginning of 1987, but I invite people to look at what has happened in our region in the last two years. We had the problems of the coups in Fiji. There have been ongoing problems in Vanuatu and New Caledonia, and closer to home and much more important are the ongoing problems in Papua New Guinea. It is clearly time to abandon a policy which relies on a defensive and relatively isolationist approach to our defence. It is time for a positive policy of regional involvement. If we are going to live in this area in peace we have to be able to contribute to the peace of the region in which we live. That will take some effort.

Our present defence cooperation program for the region, for example, comes to $60m, roughly the same amount that we give to the Australia Council. Important as that august body might be, I doubt whether we could put the Australia Council in the same league as a program which is designed to secure Australia's security and defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the referendum-$45m?

—The referendum cost $45m and of course there is the hoary old amount, which I have forgotten, which the Government gives to the gay mardi gras to fund its publications year by year. We give to Papua New Guinea, for example, some $24m under the defence cooperation program. It is simply not enough, considering the problems that are being experienced in that country. Australia's security is tied to the stability of the region. The present defence policy of sitting at home, relatively isolated, saying to anyone who may be tempted, `Come and get us if you can', is plainly stupid. We have to develop a sensible program of training, exchanges, exercises and military assistance for those countries which seek that assistance in the region in which we live.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned the problems of personnel many times in this House. Unfortunately, the problems do not seem to be going away. One would have thought that after six years in office the Government would recognise the enormous damage it has caused in the Defence Force which, by any conservative reckoning, will take 15 years to put back together in terms of getting experienced people back into some of the units. This year the Army will be some 350 officers short. The following signal went out to all units last week:

Anticipated officer vacancies for 1989 are expected to be in the order of 350, mainly in the lieutenant to major category. Apart from posting action already under way, the Military Secretary can do little to redress this shortfall.

We have a report in today's newspapers that the position in the Royal Australian Air Force is so desperate that one of the options the Government is looking at again is to recruit RAAF pilots from allied countries around the world. That we have to do that after all these years of relative peace is a tragedy and an indictment of any current defence policy.

This is what the Government should do: Firstly, it should acknowledge that the White Paper has become largely irrelevant. It should acknowledge that the deficiencies which have characterised this policy over recent years have damaged it, stop pretending that all the policies and programs are still in place and be realistic in the assessment of the damage that has been done. The Government should re-emphasise the importance of deterrence in seeking peace, give some aerial refuelling to the F111s, which are probably our single most visible deterrent asset; and acquire some airborne warning and control aircraft. We must look, as a matter of priority, at developing an offshore capability as a deterrent against adventures to Australia's territories or mainland and as a deterrent against anyone who may be tempted to undertake military adventures against our regional friends and allies. We must emphasise as a matter of urgency the regional involvement of our defence policies and put them back in place so that we are once again regarded as a country with some influence and some clout able to help our friends and allies in this area if they get into trouble. At home we must re-order the priorities within the Budget and put back a proper balance into equipment, operations and the personnel programs which are now completely out of kilter and which are doing so much damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like others on this side of the House, I support the Appropriation Bills which are being debated today and have been debated over the last few days, the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89. The Government has continued to allocate its resources wisely. It has carefully selected its priorities in line with the changing needs of Australian society and in the interests of social justice and economic equity. Economic growth continues and employment prospects are still strong. Unemployment is now 6.2 per cent--
—Unemployment.
—Yes, unemployment is now 6.2 per cent, down almost 4 per cent from its 10 per cent level when Labor came to office in 1983.
—What was it when we came to office?
—It was more than 10 per cent. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) would be interested to know that figure, I am sure.
—He was partly responsible.

—He was partly responsible. A total of 1.3 million jobs have been created in the time that we have been in government. But what do these figures mean in real terms to real people and their lives? They mean that literally thousands of Australian families are materially much better off than they were before because they now have a working breadwinner. Alternatively, they mean that a family which was seeking a second income has been able to obtain one, thus improving markedly its standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: Most Australians are fully aware that the strong growth in our economy is nothing to weep and moan about. They know only too well the difference between the conditions of relative boom presently being experienced and the recession conditions of yesteryear. They understand that the main feature of recession is high unemployment, no expansion and no jobs, no money and no opportunities for change or growth-no opportunities for anything.

Most Australians realise that because the economy is growing the demand for money and resources is unusually high. They understand also that high demand for scarce commodities usually results in higher prices. They know that they are paying through the nose in some areas of industry, such as construction, because the strong demand has brought about a shortage of materials, land and labour. They know that they are paying higher interest rates than is comfortable, because there is such a call on money for building, buying and investing. However, they also know that there are jobs to be had, for them, their sons and their daughters. It is against this backdrop that they view their relative economic well-being.

The Opposition in its policy document, Future Directions, seems to want to hark back to earlier times. It seems to want to wallow in sentimentality and nostalgia, in the hope that people will think the past can be revisited. However, older Australians cannot be so easily fooled, and younger Australians are even less easily fooled. Older Australians are astute enough to understand the difference between fantasy and reality. Indeed, few of them had the benefit of the idyllic 1950s lifestyle which the Opposition would have them hark back to. On the contrary, theirs is the generation which remembers the dark days of the Depression and which understands that some of the so-called economic problems of today are, by comparison, not problems at all. Even though members of the younger generation were not actually part of the Depression, they certainly have had very strong stories conveyed to them by their parents about the Depression and what those days mean to their parents' families.

Older Australians do notice, however, that thrift and savings are words which have been virtually missing from the national vocabulary for some years, although, at the present time, that is probably changing. They also seldom have been comfortable with the use of credit, with the possible exception of a home loan. Even then considerable personal equity was a prerequisite for taking out a bank loan and modest housing was all that was sought.

How then do older Australians feel about the never-ending drive for material possessions which has characterised recent generations in Australia? How do they feel about the reliance on credit, be it hire purchase, Bankcard, or personal loan? They firmly believe that the expectations of today's young people are unrealistic and that they have no concept of the end cost of it all. They believe that young people should be learning to settle for slightly less than the best at the beginning of their married lives. In short, they would be happier to see expectations moderated and savings accumulated for less immediate and more long term family and personal needs.

Whether these perceptions are right or wrong is not important. However, a moderation in new housing demand would certainly remove some pressures on the home construction market, which would result in an immediate cost reduction of materials and land, if not labour. An increase in savings likewise would remove some pressure on the demand for money in the form of credit, permitting a reduction in interest rates in the longer term

I believe that young Australians recognise these realities and are beginning to moderate their demands accordingly. However, all Australians, whatever their age, have a role to play in maintaining the economic health and wealth of our country. In particular, we can all make a positive contribution to the reduction of import demands. That issue has been taken up at least twice in the debate to date. If we all bought Australian products, and took that ethos far more seriously in our personal and commercial purchases, we would help to reduce the impact on the current account deficit while, at the same time, supporting the employment of other Australians. That is a matter which is taken very seriously by older Australians, because they are very aware that to buy Australian is to protect the job of another Australian and possibly one's own job.

This Government's record on wages has been consistent, although restrained. We understand that most workers have tightened their belts in the interests of the economy. Generally, they have not complained. But the time has come for an improvement in their position. That fact is undoubted. Previously, workers were asked to minimise wage increases in order not to fuel inflation. More recently, legitimate productivity increases have begun to be rewarded, but there are still many ordinary working people who require an increase in their incomes to accommodate increases in the cost of living. Award restructuring will provide the vehicle over the next few years for this type of increase and will expand opportunities for people within their own employment fields. The Government's commitment to tax cuts for low and middle income earners will also improve the situation of those people and reduce the inflationary impact of that benefit. The extent of the tax cuts will be detailed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) this evening. Once again the Hawke Government will have honoured its commitment to reduce taxes, which is no easy task.

Let us contrast this achievement with the impotence-I do not mean personal or sexual impotence; I mean economic and political impotence-of the Opposition. The Opposition criticises the Government's policies without putting forward alternative policies of its own. The Opposition has no credibility on wages policy or tax cuts. Its members weep crocodile tears across the table about the difficulties confronting Australian families; yet they oppose the very measures by which those difficulties could be ameliorated. The Opposition's stand on wage increases is boringly predictable. It mirrors the opinion of the Confederation of Australian Industry in that it does not want wage increases. It does not want to see Australian workers rewarded for their restraint in recent years or for the productivity gains which they have made through altered work practices and progressive restructuring.
What would the Opposition do if given the chance? It will not tell us; so we will probably have to make an educated guess. Would it lower wages?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it would.
—`Of course it would', says the honourable member for Throsby, a very concerned honourable member who really works for the people in his electorate.
—It has said it will do it.

—The Opposition has said it will do it. I thank the Minister. It certainly would not support any wage rises for ordinary workers. In that area, at least, it has been consistent for years and will continue to be so. Would the Opposition cut spending? Yes, it would. The only trouble is that it is too afraid to tell the people of Australia where it would make the cuts-in education, perhaps; employment creation; pensions; family assistance. These are the big ticket items in the Budget. These are the costly areas on which the greedy eyes of the Opposition hatchet men would settle if ever they got the opportunity to put their cost cutting ideas into practice. Heaven then help the poor, the halt and the lame. There would be no mercy for students, the unemployed, the elderly and the families of working Australians. If the Opposition ever got back into government, we would surely see a return to the bad old days of hesitation, procrastination and confrontation. Do honourable members remember those days? I certainly do, as do many other people who were unable to get a job, get into university, afford health care, or find child care.

SPEECH.PARA: By contrast, the initiatives of this Government have assisted thousands of Australians across the social spectrum to find work, to enter education, to take up training; in short, to improve their lives. Women have been major beneficiaries of the changes the Government has made to employment practices, the workplace environment and employer expectations. Not only have we tackled the hard question of affirmative action in a sensible and sensitive way, but we have freed up more positions to which women can aspire and we have provided child care as an essential support structure for those with pre-school aged children.

The new start program provides long term unemployed people with the chance to obtain training or reskilling in their field of endeavour. The jobs, education and training program assists sole parents to access jobs, education, or training as required. The skill share program has greatly expanded the opportunities for such disadvantaged unemployed people to acquire training in the local community environment. Most importantly, the family allowance supplement has provided low income working families with much needed additional cash to bring their earnings to a reasonable level.

In the areas of education, we have sought to restructure and redefine the requirements of the system to permit the most efficient and effective use of educational resources. Our emphasis on increasing school retention rates is indicative of the concern with which the Government views the maxim of equality of opportunity. It should be pointed out, at this juncture, that retention rates in middle class and higher income areas are very good. Retention rates are crucially needed to be raised, however, in the working class and the poorer areas of our nation. In rural areas also, retention rates are lower because students do not have the same opportunities to attend a high school. While concerns about the higher education contribution scheme are still being expressed, more students now realise that the scheme has enabled a significant increase in the number of places available in higher education. The Government has proved its commitment to the working people of Australia and evidenced its determination to improve the economic well-being of poorer people in our community, including those who are in low paid jobs.

We have also taken steps to improve substantively occupational health and safety practices and compensation arrangements for workers on the job. As a government, we have consistently sought to provide the means for improvement of the position of working people in our society, although that has not always been recognised. In the current debate many members on the Government side have alluded to these improvements, as I have. No doubt the economic statement tonight will further that ambition and prove that commitment once again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) made what I considered to be a very practical and suitable speech on the Appropriation Bills. In excellent bipartisan terms, he referred to the pollution problem confronting the eastern Australian coast in particular. He commented at some length on Memtec Ltd, which is doing some excellent work in developing new technologies in filtration through membranes. That organisation is in my electorate, I am very proud to say, and is becoming quite worldwide famous for the advances it is making in water purification and repurification.

SPEECH.PARA: It was my very great pleasure some little time ago to present it with a cheque for over $600,000 that was granted by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, to enable it to continue its experimentation along the very worthwhile lines it has already achieved. My very best wishes are extended to that company. I hope that in the days ahead we will be able to get even greater funding from the Government, perhaps even from the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), for the excellent work the company is doing. I thank the honourable member for Robertson for his kind comments with regard to Memtec.

It is appropriate that this debate has been allowed to continue today. The Government brings down its tax-wage-productivity package tonight, but it has not allocated any time for the House to discuss the package, as honourable members will note. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) without doubt will provide a comprehensive critique of the package and he will be the only person given the privilege to comment on the Government's economic statement, which is a pity.

The package tonight will focus on tax, productivity and wages. I will provide some facts and figures on the tax burdens facing Australian families, as they are very relevant to the debate, especially in view of the statement to be made tonight. The source of the information I will give is not Opposition research, although our research confirms the data; it is the Institute of Family Studies, an independent statutory body which was set up when the Family Law Act came into being and which is totally funded from Treasury funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Substantial research.

—Yes. The Institute made some salient points in its most recent report, entitled Families and Tax in 1989. The report indicates that average tax rates increased substantially for taxpayers on or around average weekly earnings between 1983-84 and 1987-88. Family allowances, which were introduced by the Fraser Government, have been allowed to fall in value by 43 per cent. It needs to be repeated that family allowances, which were introduced by a conservative government under the Fraser leadership, have been allowed to fall by 43 per cent. This information was given in an independent report. The Government cannot say it has been trumped up by the Opposition; that is just not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The report gives the further information that the dependent spouse rebate for couples with children has fallen in value by 22 per cent since it was upgraded in 1982 by the Fraser Government. That is another point worth repeating. Tax rates, by percentage points and dollars per week, for families rose between 1976-77 and 1988-89 as follows: a one-income couple with two children on average weekly earnings, up 6.2 per cent or $30.80 a week; a one-income couple with two children on 1.5 times average weekly earnings, up 4.7 per cent or $35.02 per week. In contrast-this needs to be listened to very carefully-and to the shame of the Government, which pretends to favour the average Australian, a one-income couple with two children on four times the average weekly earnings have had a drop of 3.7 per cent or $73.53 per week in tax. It does not matter how we look at that; it cannot be argued that in any way, shape or form it can be considered a fair deal. Finally, families have done worse than single persons and the extent of their losses rises with the number of children. Can you believe that, Mr Deputy Speaker? I am sure you can. Those are the factors which should be put, dealt with and determined tonight, but unfortunately they will not be. The tax cuts tonight will be only partial repayments for the tax take since 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty-eight dollars.

—I think it is even more than that. The tax cuts will fail to come to grips with the current bias against families with children, especially when one parent wants to stay home in the formative years of their children's lives. This is one area of Government policy that never ceases to amaze me. The bulk of research around the world clearly shows how important it is that in the formative years of a child's life the mother, if at all possible, be present in the home and available for children five years old and under. Government policies should be varied to make that possible. Yet, we find today that, as policy after policy affecting the family comes out, this very commonsense piece of understanding and knowledge is ignored, to the great detriment of the country and its future.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will also try to come to grips with micro-economic reforms, that is, reforms to eliminate Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) enforced work practices and awards which make Australia uncompetitive in a dog eat dog international economy, which we have heard a lot about in recent months. To get an idea of the nature of the problem and to understand the unfairness as much as the inefficiency of current work practices and awards in some sectors, I draw on a recent National Farmers Federation document. The example involves a shipment of cottonseed from Queensland. The cost of loading and transporting the cottonseed some hundreds of kilometres from central Queensland to a position on the wharf beside the ship was $56 per tonne.

A lot of people might say that seems to be an exorbitant rate, but it pales into insignificance when it is compared with the remainder of the Federation's comments. Using a crane which lifted eight tonnes each lift-that is, eight one-tonne bags-the waterside workers succeeded in lifting an average of six bags per person per eight-hour shift. The total cost of lifting the cottonseed over the side of the ship was $62 per tonne-absolutely shameful! The purchasers said that the cottonseed was very good but that in future they would go elsewhere because of the exorbitant waterfront costs. It is not arguable that that kind of situation should be allowed to continue in this country. There is absolutely no case for the Government, or anybody else, arguing that such a situation should be allowed to continue, yet unfortunately it is.

As the National Farmers Federation points out, while farmers, who generate nearly 50 per cent of the country's export wealth, struggle to earn, on average, $20,000 a year pre-tax, unskilled waterside workers receive an average of $31,000 per year. It is extraordinary! Yet the dreadful situation which currently exists on our waterfront and which has been revealed very patently in a recent report is seemingly being totally ignored by the Government. For this, referring to the waterside workers who average $31,000 per year--

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot less than you get.

—That is right. But they commonly work a mere 25 hours a week. There can hardly be a farmer who does not work almost three times as long, often seven days a week, and the National Farmers Federation quite rightly points this out. I can assure honourable members that the farmers in the Hawkesbury and Oberon areas of my electorate are among those who work long hours, particularly in these latter months. With three major floods in the past 12 months, the total income of the Hawkesbury farmers for the 1987-88 and 1988-89 years will be far less than $20,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The main factor in the micro-economic reform equation is the very one the Government will ignore tonight. That is the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the power of the unions. As with tax relief for families, we can expect only disappointment tonight on productivity initiatives from a government which is led by a former ACTU President and which expects to have as its next leader the current ACTU President.

I turn to wages policy-the greatest confidence trick in tonight's package and in this Government's policy approach. Again because of the power of the ACTU, real gains in terms of the largest possible tax cut will be forfeited tonight because of the decision to provide wage rises. The Government knows that wage rises are illusory measures when it comes to increasing living standards and that can be illustrated very simply by looking at the $10 per week wage rise to the average person. That person will lose about $4 in tax and the providers of the salary or wage-the producers, the manufacturers-will increase their prices by $10 to $12 to recover that proposed rise in the cost of living. That will leave the average worker only $6 to cope with the $10 increase in the cost of living. It is quite ludicrous to talk about giving wage increases unless we have produced a bigger cake. If we produce a bigger cake then it is very much in order to talk about giving legitimate wage increases. Wage rises will be taxed and they will push up inflation and interest rates which will further neutralise the wage gains. In other words, the wage earner gets poorer and the Government gets richer.

I have referred to interest rates. Evidence from the most recent quarterly home affordability figures from the Real Estate Institute of Australia reveals that housing costs have reduced the income of the average household by $82 a week since 1983. That is in addition to tax increases and inflation-related family budget problems with food, clothing, transport, health care, education and so on. What should be happening tonight is that a determined approach to expenditure cuts should be used to lower interest rates. Tonight, the ACTU should be removed from power. Tonight the tax burden on families should be lifted. These things will not occur. The Government and the ACTU are as one. Their economic policies are in shambles. These things will only occur under a different government, a government committed to new directions for the future of families and the nation, committed to commonsense more than anything else. These things will not be announced tonight. We will have to wait until after the election of a Howard coalition government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we have to wait for the election of a Howard government, we will have to wait a long, long time. I am very pleased to speak in this debate on the Appropriation Bills. I am the last of a long line of speakers-and my time has been cut rather short-in a very wide-ranging debate. I listened to the speech of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), who gave the waterside workers yet another serve. Why does he not come with me to Port Kembla and talk to the waterside workers, just as farmers from the far west have done? They have discussed the problems that the rural producers have and they have seen the conditions under which the waterside workers work. The honourable member talked about low income earners. He does not want those people to get a rise. Oh no! Do we ever hear honourable members from the Opposition benches talking about executive salaries? We can rest assured that they will not complain about the massive executive salaries or company profits that are being made in this country today. All they are prepared to say is `No, no, no' to low paid workers. The lowly paid must stay that way and not get any increases. But these people will receive increases under this Hawke Government-something they have never got and will never get under governments from the conservative side of politics.

SPEECH.PARA: All Australians will welcome last week's announcement by the Government of the expenditure of almost $8m on a national program to respond to the global threat posed by the greenhouse effect. The bulk of the funding will be directed to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and the Bureau of Meteorology. I appeal to the National Greenhouse Advisory Committee to ensure that part of this research money is spent on rebuilding the meteorological stations at Mawson and Davis in the Antarctic. Much of the important work regarding any changed climatic conditions must be carried out in Antarctica, yet conditions in the meteorological buildings on both stations are totally inadequate. They are worse than that; they are a disgrace and would not be tolerated anywhere in Australia. It is only the dedication of the staff at these meteorological stations over many years that has permitted important work in relation to weather to be carried out. The same applies to the upper atmospheric laboratories. Vital work is being carried out in totally unsuitable and inadequate buildings. We now have a chance to rectify some of the failings of the past and, as a start, I urge that new meteorological stations be built at both bases.

While looking at the meteorological stations and the upper atmospheric laboratories, perhaps we should take the opportunity to look at our rebuilding program in Antarctica. Have we got our priorities right? Are we, as some suggest, aggressively imposing our presence in Antarctica? Is the sophistication of some of our centres such that a high degree of expertise is required? For example, why do we have three heated fire stations, but no fire tenders to go into them? The cost of the doors to these buildings alone would have gone a long way to building new meteorological stations. I believe that the accommodation and facilities should be the best available for the people who have to spend winter there but I do want them to be appropriate.

I might add while I am talking on Antarctica that I am totally opposed to the signing of the Antarctic mining convention. I know that there are arguments on both sides, but let us keep mining out of Antarctica. Surely the mining companies, the multinationals, have enough areas of the world to spoil. Is it too much to ask that one area remain undisturbed and unspoilt? If prospecting were permitted there it would generate many impacts, including airports, ports, tracks, accidents, oil leaks, disposal of waste and surplus equipment, housing, noise, atmospheric pollution and degradation of wilderness and aesthetic values. I understand from discussions I have had that there are not many minerals there, especially in our area. I believe that in the Prince Charles Mountain area there is some coal, but the last thing we really want is more coal than is being mined in Australia at present.

The real test would come if oil were discovered either onshore or offshore. We have seen the tragedy of the oil spill off Alaska. Such an occurrence would be worse in Antarctica. I believe the Alaskan oil spill serves as a graphic example of the inevitable consequence of exploiting fragile environments such as Antarctica. Such major disasters will occur, regardless of all assurances and untried technology. If the Americans were unable to contain the oil spill in Alaska, what chance would we have in Antarctica, which is so remote from industrial and population centres? I very much support Australia's presence in the Antarctic, and especially our research work, but I wonder how serious we are about our claim to the territory. We claim the largest part of the Antarctic-some 42 or 43 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many Russian bases are on it?

—Yet currently we have to hire a German and a Canadian ship to get us there. Even the new ship being built at Newcastle will be leased. There is no naval vessel in Australia capable of going south of Macquarie Island. If, as has happened in the past, Australia's ships become stuck in the ice, we have to rely on the Soviets or the Japanese to come with their ice breakers and get us out. Although I am not critical of the research being carried out in Antarctica, I wonder whether there has been an over- emphasis on geology in recent years. When I was there recently it seemed that every second person I spoke to was a PhD student in geology. There are other important aspects of this country's work there, such as the research into weather, the glaciology and the krill. Australia is leading the world in krill research and the important part that it plays in the world food chain.

SPEECH.PARA: The cooperation that exists between the Antarctic Treaty nations is interesting. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) mentioned the Soviets. There are some Soviet bases there, including one on territory claimed by Australia, and there is a Chinese base. Interestingly, the Chinese have achieved in five weeks what it has taken Australia something like five years to achieve. In recent weeks much has been said about the environment, and particularly the Antarctic environment. I believe that Australia's record in this respect is excellent. A recent Four Corners program on this topic was very misleading. It concentrated on the Argentinean and Chilean bases. The rubbish that is generated in Antarctica is returned to Australia and great care is taken with it.

Tourism is an aspect that comes up for discussion. I suppose people might say I am selfish because I have been there and I do not want other people to go there. I would like more people to share the pristine beauty of Antarctica, but I believe that any tourism must be ship based and not land based. Recently I read a rather silly article in the Australian Financial Review of 21 March, written by David Clark, which illustrated to me that he did not understand anything about Antarctica and the threats that would be posed there, especially by land-based tourism.

Finally, I pay tribute to the staff of the Antarctic Division. I believe they have been unfairly criticised in recent times. I found among them great dedication and a commitment to Australia's role in Antarctica. I pay a tribute also to the expeditioners whose initiative and enthusiasm have contributed so much to our understanding and scientific knowledge of a rare and vitally important environment. In conclusion, I appeal to those responsible for the allocation of the funding that work be commenced on rebuilding our meteorological buildings and I emphasise my total opposition to any mining in Antarctica.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank all honourable members who participated in the debate. I wish only to respond to two points that were raised by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) on Monday evening. The honourable member continues in his attempt to disrupt the smooth operation of the household expenditure survey. He claimed that the survey did not have the backing of law because it was not tabled in the Parliament prior to being conducted.
—That is correct.

—The honourable member interjecting knows that is wrong. The honourable member for Moreton knows it is wrong. The 1988-89 survey was not new. It did not need to be tabled. It was sent off to the Attorney-General for his advice on that matter, and the ruling on the validity of the survey from the Attorney-General's Department showed that the course followed was the right course to follow, but those who raised the matter did not like the verdict.
—That is not what the Ombudsman said.

—The honourable member should read all of the Ombudsman's letter, not the selected bits that he has been reading while traipsing around the country. He should read the whole seven pages of the letter, not the paragraph that he plucked out in isolation. He should read the lot of it. It is a great cop-out, belting public servants around the ears. That is all it is-a nice coward's castle job by a few members of this place, purporting to have an interest in the public. The household expenditure survey is absolutely fundamental to government planning, to industry planning, to the construction of the consumer price index, to the establishment of the levels of pension, to the CPI adjustment for veterans-to all these things. It is essential that the Government has an accurate CPI so that the adjustments are accurate. While members of the Opposition go round belting public servants, it is a cheap cop-out. They cannot come in here and respond to criticism from the Opposition as I am doing now. Those opposite should be a bit more constructive about it. They should go to the people who use the information required from the household expenditure survey. They are the people honourable members opposite are attacking. All of that is known. I will not go further in the time that is available.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that was raised was the tax file number. The facts of that matter are as follows: the Australian Taxation Office undertook a mail-out of tax file advices earlier this year to assist taxpayers to prepare for the upgraded tax file number system. In the course of the advice mail-out a number of advices were sent to incorrect addresses. This has been acknowledged and addressed by the Tax Office. This occurred when through computer program error advices were produced that included taxpayers who had lodged returns in past years and not, as was intended, only those who had lodged last year. It was readily admitted that an error was made. Even the Opposition makes errors. It would be better if it had not happened, but it did, and it was acknowledged. It meant, as I said, that some advices were sent out to people who have since changed their addresses without informing the Tax Office. In other situations advices were addressed to people who, unbeknown to the Tax Office, were deceased.

The Tax Office did not commit any breach of the privacy provisions built into the tax law. The tax file numbers were mailed in sealed envelopes, personally addressed to the taxpayer. The fact that personally addressed envelopes were opened by third parties does not constitute a breach on the part of the Tax Office. As I said, it would be better if it had not happened. An error was made. It is acknowledged and it has been attended to. I thank all honourable members who participated in the debate. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —But how many-55,000 to 77,000 errors in the first post-out?
—The honourable member is very good at belting public servants here in cowards' castle, is he not? Let him get out there and do it publicly.
—If they do not do their job properly and they belt the public, why not? That is our responsibility.
—The honourable member has lived off that for years.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members will cease their exchanges across the chamber.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the words proposed to be omitted (Dr Hewson's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Peter Morris) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), who so kindly moved the third reading, without advice to me indulged in an attack on my integrity in drawing to the attention of the Parliament the misdoings of the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Commissioner of Taxation and the Australian Statistician. Briefly, I will set the record right. In relation to the household expenditure survey, the legislation states clearly that this Parliament is to be advised of the intentions of the survey. That requirement was not met. The Minister, who is at the table, talks about attacking people, but he made the deliberate decision to approve suddenly the exit from Australia of the Australian Statistician prior to his attendance at a Senate Estimates committee hearing. Mr Castles came back to Australia--
—Ha, ha!

—The Minister should not laugh because I know the history of all this. Mr Castles came back to Australia one week later to learn that the committee had, in his absence, adjourned its hearings on the basis that Mr Castles would appear at the next hearing. The Minister at the table made a deliberate decision that Mr Castles would not appear before the committee. If the Minister intends to throw questions over the matter--

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.54 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of courtesy, I inform the House that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, will be absent from Question Time today on Government business. I cannot disclose what it is.
—He should be here; it is no laughing matter.

—We are devastated by the observation of the honourable member for Mayo, which is about as relevant as anything he says in this place. Questions which would normally be addressed to the Treasurer should be addressed to my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins.
—Does the Prime Minister agree with the Treasurer's statement yesterday ruling out any fall in interest rates?
—It just depends on what the period of time is.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Gear having addressed a question to the Minister for Employment and Education Services--
Mr Spender-Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. We know that these Ministers are the most brilliant collection we have ever seen, but--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will raise his point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Spender-The Minister has been asked to refer to comments and then to say what effects these comments are likely to have upon the labour market. There is no way in the world that that is not a hypothetical question. There is no way that it should be put to the Minister.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Minister. It is in order to answer the question.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Tuckey-Madam Speaker, I rise on a further point of order. The Standing Orders are specific in this regard. Questions should not be put to Ministers that are hypothetical. That is purely a hypothetical question. The Minister has no opportunity whatsoever to predict the effect on the labour market and if he were asked that question in a press conference he would reject it on the grounds that it was hypothetical. Madam Speaker, it is your responsibility to reject it accordingly. It is purely hypothetical.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair will reject the question. The question is hypothetical.
—Will the Prime Minister confirm that even since December 1988 interest rate rises alone have resulted in a more than $20 a week increase in average mortgage repayments?
—It is not a question of conceding. I do not have the exact tabulation at my fingertips, any more than I would imagine the cackling hyena opposite, the Leader of the Opposition, would.
—Devastating!

—It is not a question of devastation; it is just an observation of fact. We hear nothing but the giggleometer going opposite. Obviously I do not have those facts at my fingertips and I do not intend to pretend that I do.

—Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I would have thought that `cackling hyena' hardly fitted within our Standing Orders. I suggest to you, Madam Speaker, that it would be appropriate if the Prime Minister withdrew those words.
—I find it an unfortunate remark. The Prime Minister will withdraw.
—Happily, Madam Speaker.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy been drawn to an article in the Sydney Daily Telegraph of today's date under the heading `Coal Board men involved in mine sale'? Has this matter been referred to the Government by the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, as reported in this article? Are any improprieties involved with respect to the proposed Hunter Valley coal mine sale? Does the Government support repeated calls from the New South Wales Coal Association and the New South Wales coalition Government to abolish the Joint Coal Board?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of press reports with respect to conflicts of interest within the Joint Coal Board. The Chairman of that organisation, Mr Wilcox, informed me personally as soon as the Board was aware of the situation. I am a bit concerned that Mr Greiner and his Minister, Mr Pickard, have been inaccurate in a number of matters surrounding this issue. Only one person was forced to resign from the Board, with the other avoiding a conflict of interest by having resigned from a position where a conflict could have arisen. I am impressed with the speed with which the Board acted. It advised the New South Wales and Commonwealth Ministers and also took the necessary and appropriate action and then provided a complete and final report to both Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: The role of the New South Wales Government in trying to take credit for the Board's action and, at the same time, distance itself from the Board is very hard to fathom. One understands that it is the policy of the New South Wales and Federal sections of the Liberal Party to wipe out the Joint Coal Board. Mr Greiner, of course, is very sensitive to conflict of interest, given his experiences with his own Liberal-National Party coalition Ministers. Mr Pickard is set on destroying the Joint Coal Board. I guess I have to say quite plainly that the Commonwealth sees that the Joint Coal Board has a role to play in the New South Wales coal industry and it would like the Board to continue. I also have to recognise the Pickard fervour in pursuing the Joint Coal Board. I would not be doing my job if I did not project what role the Joint Coal Board might play if New South Wales takes unilateral action and revokes its legislation. I simply say to the honourable member that I will be supporting the Joint Coal Board and will ensure that its legitimate roles continue to be carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. As the Treasurer has ruled out any fall in interest rates, is the Prime Minister's prediction and promise before the Western Australian election that interest rates would fall now inoperative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say something on this question of interest rates, seeing that in the three questions that have been asked today the Opposition seems to be showing some interest in this issue. It seems to be implying in its questions-certainly in the question before this one-that there was some alternative to the policy that the Government is pursuing. Let us make it quite clear that, as far as the conduct of economic policy in this country is concerned, there are basically three instruments which are available to the Government to regulate the level of economic activity. They are, of course, fiscal budgetary policy, wages policy, and monetary policy.

ANSWER.PARA: It seems to be implied, at least in what the Opposition has been saying not only in Question Time today but also around the place in the last few weeks, that it would not have monetary policy as tight as it is, although one can find in statements from various spokesmen earlier this year positions which would contradict that position. However, on the assumption that that is the Opposition's current position, that it says that interest rates are too high, it necessarily means that the Opposition would have a tighter fiscal policy or a tighter wages policy. We know that it is not prepared to spell out the implications of these positions. If it is the case that the Opposition would have a tighter fiscal policy, what is it that the Opposition is saying? Is it saying that the performance of the Government in this area is inadequate? I remind the House, in particular members of the Opposition, of what the performance has been in this area. We have transformed an inherited $9 1/2 billion deficit-
Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Again the giggleometer goes, but the fact is that we have reduced the inherited deficit of $9 1/2 billion to a surplus of $5 1/2 billion. Last year we produced a surplus for the first time in 35 years. This year we will produce a surplus of $5 1/2 billion. In most of the previous 35 years when that had not been done, the responsibility for macro-economic policy was in the Opposition's hands. It was consistently incapable of producing a surplus in this country. In the course of producing that surplus we have had three successive years of negative growth in Commonwealth outlays and reduced the public sector borrowing requirement to zero. None of those things have been achieved or were capable of being achieved by the Opposition. So it is a nonsense for members of the Opposition to assert or imply that they would be able to have a tighter fiscal policy than this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: That brings us to the area of wages. I would have thought that members of the Opposition would not want any more on the area of wages after the bath they were given earlier this week by my friend the Treasurer. But, just in case the lessons that were relayed by the Treasurer have not sunk into their inadequate intellects, let me confirm what the Treasurer had to say, because what he said was right. He said, `I ask you to remember your own performance in the area of wages policy. It was the most disastrous performance that has ever been seen in this country'. At the time the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) sought to cooperate with the previous Government. It rejected that cooperation. The former Prime Minister flounced off to the royal wedding in London and left a 17 per cent explosion in wages. The previous Government's lax wages policy and its total inability to have any effective and constructive cooperation with the trade unions caused that massive wages blow-out.

As the Treasurer rightly said yesterday, its performance exceeded any expectations. Anyone could make a slight mess of an economy but, as he said, it took a very special talent to do what the previous Government did-that is, to have for the first time in this country simultaneous double digit unemployment and inflation. No-one has ever been able to do that before. But the previous Government, out of the depths of its ignorance and incapacity, produced what no-one else had ever done. So this Opposition is obviously incapable in the area of wages policy to produce anything that is relevant.

The Opposition's whole approach on the question of interest rates is revealed as a hopeless stupidity and charade because it would not be able, in the area of the other two instruments of policy-that is, fiscal budgetary policy and wages policy-to have a tighter, more effective situation. The Opposition would have to resort to a monetary policy which would be even tougher than that which is applied by this Government. As I have said before, no politician is a masochist and wants to have monetary policy tighter for one day longer than is necessary.

Do honourable members opposite think that we on this side of the House have interest rates where they are because we get some joy out of it? No. Interest rates are high for the simple reason that the economic interests of this country require it. If honourable members opposite think that we have high interest rate policies because we on this side of the House get some perverse pleasure out of it, they are wrong. Interest rates are at that level because it is not sensible to have tighter fiscal policy than we have now.

It is not possible to have a tighter wages policy. Honourable members opposite would know that at the moment the ACTU is stopping wage increases. Employers around this country are going to the ACTU and pleading with it to agree to higher wage increases. The ACTU is saying no because that would be deleterious to the economic interests of this country. That is what the ACTU is doing and credit should be given to it by people on the other side of the House.

So we cannot get tighter wages policy and we cannot get tighter fiscal policy and, within that context, interest rates are necessarily where they are. We make no apology for it. But, as a result of the policies which we are pursuing and which will be further announced by the Treasurer tonight, the prospect is that interest rates will come down. If people opposite ever had the responsibility for macro-economic policy in this country again it is as certain as night follows day that we would have a return to the economic chaos of 1981. That would be no accident; it would happen because the Opposition has no wages policy, it has an inadequate stomach for the hard task of fiscal policy; and, therefore, it would be thrust into even higher interest rate levels than this Government has at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, concerns higher education funding in Queensland. Has the Minister seen recent reports concerning Commonwealth funding of higher education in Queensland and difficulties caused by recent unilateral decisions by the Queensland Government in relation to the designation of three colleges of advanced education (CAEs) as universities? Can he comment on these reports and on the approach taken by State governments elsewhere in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of higher education is something which obviously involves the Commonwealth as the major funding government. It also involves the States as they are responsible for the statutes which establish them. We have sought to adopt a cooperative approach to the future of higher education in this country. As an example, I instance the establishment of joint planning committees with each of the States so that State and Commonwealth Ministers are getting advice from the same source in relation to the planning of higher education in each of the States.

ANSWER.PARA: Regrettably, the process of cooperation has not proceeded very far in Queensland. The Queensland Government has made what is essentially a unilateral decision to redesignate three colleges-Darling Downs, Capricornia and Brisbane CAEs-as universities by some time in the 1990s. This has been done without any consultation with us. In doing that the Queensland Government is saying that these institutions are not universities now. It wants them to become universities; therefore, they must change. The change will be expensive. The Queensland Government wants us to pay for that cost, yet it will not talk to us about the process by which those colleges might become universities or the timetable according to which they might make those changes.

These are important issues because, with the end of the binary system, we always said that there were legitimate expectations on the part of colleges to become universities or to amalgamate with other universities. Therefore, we have anticipated this kind of development. Let me just quote briefly from the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Queensland. He says that there will be a `bid for university status by a significant number of colleges, some of which do not have the staff qualifications, academic quality or research strength normally associated with Australian universities'. In other words, some colleges would need to expand their profile, increase their graduate programs, improve their research infrastructure and so on. These are issues which we are happy to discuss with the institutions and with the Queensland Government. The Queensland Government had assessors go to these three institutions and reports were produced. The Queensland Government will not provide those reports to us. They remain secret despite our repeated requests to see them. I have asked the Queensland Minister to come to Canberra and meet me and talk about it. He has not done so-at least not yet.

I suspect that these institutions have legitimate expectations to become universities and we are prepared to support them in their ambitions. But it will not happen by magic. Indeed, if it were to, it would be a deception of the students, the staff and the communities involved. If we want them to be more than universities just in name, these changes have to be dealt with and funded. Let me quote from the Rockhampton Bulletin because the Capricornia Institute of Advanced Education is one of the institutions in case. The Rockhampton Bulletin of 14 March states:
The announcement may have been yet another of the National Party's notorious phantom projects.
It goes on:
It would be presumptuous to say the least for a State Government to promote a CAE to university status without detailed consultation with the appropriate Federal Minister.
The editorial concludes:
Mr Littleproud-
the Queensland Minister-
and his Government would be far more prudent to seek urgent talks in Canberra to resolve the problem.

I endorse the sentiments of the Rockhampton Bulletin, as I always do. I am an avid reader of the Rockhampton Bulletin. It always has very laudatory things to say about the honourable member for Capricornia and at least in that context I always endorse it.
