But these are complex issues which will not be dealt with by unilateral declarations by the Queensland Government. I repeat that we are prepared to support the idea of these institutions becoming universities but we wish to see an orderly process and a plan which we and the rest of the higher education community can support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to withhold the money from them?
—The interjection brings me to the second part of the honourable member's question. She asked: What is happening in other States? I want to refer briefly--
—No; are you going to withhold the money from them?
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin did not ask the question.

—The honourable member should just relax for one minute. I want to refer briefly to what is happening in Victoria. The Victorian Government has taken an absolutely different approach, a consultative approach, not only with us but also with the institutions involved. The honourable member for Ballarat has drawn to my attention a press release from the shadow Minister involving the future of the Ballarat CAE. First of all, in relation to the Ballarat CAE, it is the Victorian Government's proposal that there should be an amalgamation between the Ballarat, Deakin and Warrnambool colleges. That is not a proposal which has come from me; it is not one that I originated; it is not one which I have proposed. Nevertheless, it is one which I am prepared to support if the parties involved agree. But the honourable member for Deakin makes the outrageous suggestion that we have been involved in withholding funds, with threatening funding cuts and, indeed, delaying the announcement of capital funds for these institutions. We have made no threats-indeed, quite the contrary. What we have said is that we are prepared to provide additional support to these institutions involved in amalgamations. We hear a lot of interjections from the honourable member for Deakin. Let me just tell the House what he knows about the structure of higher education in this country. He went to the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee (AVCC) to have a briefing on the higher education system in Australia. We would have thought that he knew something about universities--
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. I understood that the question was about funding for higher education institutions in Queensland. The Minister is not talking about that at all.
—The Minister will draw the answer to a conclusion.
—I am about to do so. He asked the AVCC for a briefing on the structure of higher education in the country and--
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. I understood you to uphold the point of order which was taken by the honourable member for Mackellar--
—Order! The honourable member is quite correct. The Chair invited the Minister to bring--
—and I take a further point of order--
—Order! Do not speak while I am speaking. The Minister has been told to bring his answer to a conclusion.

—Madam Speaker, I have a further point of order. The further point of order is this: it is an outrageous abuse of Question Time for the Minister, in answer to the question, to start talking about the conversation of the honourable member for Deakin--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Madam Speaker, you know as well as I do that it is out of order.
—Order! The honourable member will not speak to the Chair in that manner. The Minister will draw this answer to a conclusion.

—I have about two sentences to go, Madam Speaker. In asking for this briefing, we would have thought that the honourable member for Deakin would have known a little bit about the subject. But the AVCC was explaining to the honourable member, `Well, there are these universities and there are the CAEs'. The explanation went on and on and the honourable member said, `Hang on a minute; what is this CAE business?'.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the serious inconvenience being caused to domestic and international travellers by the continual disruption of air services by air traffic controllers, particularly at Sydney, Australia's largest airport. Is it not a fact that the direct cause of the inability to deal with this dispute is the lack of effective dispute settlement procedures, backed by enforcement measures, which he, as Minister for Industrial Relations, identified in 1987 as a major shortcoming in the Government's industrial relations policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question is no. The fact is that procedures are in place to ensure that there is a swift resolution of this dispute. Yesterday, as I mentioned in the House, action was being taken to achieve stand-down orders. Those stand-down orders were achieved yesterday afternoon. Action was then taken by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) last night against one air traffic controller who refused extended duty when another air traffic controller reported in sick. There seems to have been quite a lot of sickness in that area lately. As a result of that he was stood down.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that this morning another three air traffic controllers have been stood down. I understand that further stand-downs are likely to occur this afternoon. The Government and the CAA agree that the process of continuing the stand-downs is not appropriately the only step that should be taken to bring this matter to a resolution. Accordingly, if industrial action continues, this afternoon the CAA will be approaching the Industrial Relations Commission to seek a bans clause in the air traffic controllers award. The result of an imposition of a bans clause will be that if there is continuance of bans and limitations upon the work by air traffic controllers both the union and the individual air traffic controllers can be subject to fines of up to $500 a day. The Government believes that the seriousness of this dispute warrants that kind of action and the air traffic controllers should be aware that the Government and the CAA are quite serious about taking that step.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) has been chosen by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to play a leading role in the earth observatory project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Sit down now.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there is more to be said. It is a very important project and it will provide very crucial information about a fact that is of increasing importance to this Government and I would hope to the Opposition as well-that is, the composition of the atmosphere, the problems associated with the greenhouse effect and the problems associated with the thinning of the ozone layer. I make the point that out of 455 international applications to participate in this earth observing system (EOS) project CSIRO was one of only eight overseas organisations invited to take part. We regard that as a very considerable achievement. It is also an achievement for the division of fisheries down in the electorate of the honourable member for Denison because Graham Harris's team will be using data from EOS to study the relationship between climate, ocean circulation, biological processes and renewable marine resources in the Australasian region. Scientists from both the division of fisheries and the division of oceanography will be part of the investigating team. We are very much aware of the need to monitor what is happening in our biosphere. It is increasingly becoming one of the major international issues and I believe that CSIRO deserves our very hearty congratulations for what is a major achievement.

—I refer the Prime Minister to his assertion in Question Time last week that Medicare had enfranchised two million Australians who were without health cover under the previous Government. I also refer the Prime Minister to the Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin, catalogue No. 4335.0, entitled `Health Insurance Survey, March 1983', and table 14 of that survey which shows that 1,031,000 Australians were uninsured but that half of those lived in Queensland where they had free hospital treatment or were covered by repatriation or pensioner benefits.
—Is the honourable member getting to the question?
—In view of that, I ask the Prime Minister: Where did he get his figure of two million people? Is he able to substantiate it?
—That figure of two million is not a figure that was plucked out of the air. I will take steps to see that I provide the honourable member with the background on which that figure was used.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy inform the House as to what impact the reported increase in sales of Victorian milk into New South Wales provided by the Bendigo firm Sandhurst Foods will have on the national dairy marketing arrangements, otherwise known as the Kerin plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. During the past 12 months a relatively small quantity of Victorian packaged milk has been sold in New South Wales through a particular retail chain. The Sandhurst dairies which are owned by Coles have recently begun supplying its own stores with around 300,000 litres of milk per week. The Victorian processors, by selling milk in the Sydney market, are obviously seeking to take advantage of the higher price structure that is established by the New South Wales milk marketing arrangements. The New South Wales industry is understandably concerned by this development but it is hoped that commonsense will prevail and that this incident or this action will not jeopardise the whole dairy marketing arrangements. I think dairy farmers on both sides of the border are well aware of the situation with respect to the market milk premiums.

ANSWER.PARA: I am heartened because, unlike the situation some two years ago, there seems to be a lot more commonsense prevailing this time round. The New South Wales industry has begun to accept the reality of Victorian competition and the need to meet that competition in the marketplace and not by government regulation. On the other hand, New South Wales industry leaders are aware of their higher cost structures and, following Victoria's lead, are working to rationalise the industry's manufacturing and distribution infrastructure. It is only such rationalisation that will keep New South Wales competitive with Victoria and contain Victorian sales. It is my hope, and all the evidence points that way, that this more mature approach will result in an early and rational resolution of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the content of the financial statement to be given later today by the Treasurer will be the result of directions given to the Government by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple answer to the honourable member's question is no, the economic statement will not be the result of such direction. What it will reflect to a considerable extent is the detailed discussions and negotiations that have been openly conducted by this Government with the ACTU. I point out that those discussions have not been the only discussions we have had. My colleagues have had discussions with representatives of the business community, which community is totally cognisant of the fact that we have held discussions with the ACTU. There is nothing sinister or covert about this. We have been totally open, as well we should be.

ANSWER.PARA: Why should we be open? It is because in our six years of government, through the process of discussion with the ACTU, we have been able to implement an effective wages policy, which wages policy, as the honourable gentleman may know, has been commented upon favourably by many international commentators. I remind the honourable member that last year the Director of the International Monetary Fund, Monsieur Jean-Michel Camdessus, was in this country and said openly that what had been done in Australia by the Government in having consultations with the trade union movement and producing an effective wages policy was a model for the rest of the world. Madam Speaker, you may want to discount what I say; you may want to discount what the Treasurer said, but I think you will find it fairly difficult to repudiate the considered judgment of the Director of the International Monetary Fund.

The function of the International Monetary Fund is to monitor, to watch, the economic performance of the 130-odd members of the International Monetary Fund. It analyses the conduct of economic policy in all the economies of the world. The considered judgment of the Director of the International Monetary Fund was that the conduct of policy by this Government in the area of consultation with the trade union movement provided a model for the rest of the world. That is a sensible judgment, because it reflects the fact that in this country employment growth has been more than twice as fast as in the rest of the world. I do not know whether that upsets honourable members on the other side of the House. No doubt it does. The only time there is glee on the face of the Leader of the Opposition is when there is bad economic news. Honourable members will remember his never to be forgotten statement a couple of years ago when we were in the depths of the reverse in the terms of trade position. He said, `The times will suit me'. When times were tough for Australia he thought that it was good for him politically.

Fortunately, the people of Australia take pride in the fact that, as a result of the policies pursued by this Government, we have a rate of employment growth twice as fast as in the rest of the world. There is one simple reason why we create jobs twice as fast as the rest of the world, and that is the cooperation between this Government and the trade union movement. Every employer in this country knows-if honourable members doubt it they can go and ask them-that if it were not for these policies of cooperation between the Government and the trade union movement they would be paying significantly higher wage rates. Employers know that; they are seeking to do it.

The trade union movement is accepting lower nominal wage outcomes because of the way in which this Government is operating in the area of the social wage. That is something about which the honourable member should not complain. He should take great pride in the fact that he is a member of a country which is creating jobs more than twice as fast as the rest of the world. If he has the beginning of any understanding of economic policy he will know that the reason why we are creating jobs twice as fast as the rest of the world is that we are in a position where, sensibly, this Government has the capacity to sit down and negotiate constructively with the ACTU. I assure the honourable member that tonight he will see the further fruits of that sensible, constructive approach.

What is the alternative? The alternative is what the Opposition followed when it was in government in the period between 1975 and 1983, when confrontation, not cooperation and constructive dialogue, was the order of the day. Under the previous Government we had a work force which was non-cooperative with government, which went out into the workplace to try to get as much by way of nominal wage increases as it possibly could. In that situation, brought about by the attitude of the previous Government, as I said earlier today, we had something that never existed before in this country-simultaneous double-digit inflation and double-digit employment, the worst recession for 50 years, and an addition of some 350,000 unemployed in a period of less than two years. That is what honourable members opposite got from the policy of confrontation.

What we have got from the policy of constructive dialogue and cooperation is a rate of employment growth, as I say, more than twice as fast as in the rest of the world. If honourable members opposite think that the people want to return to the sort of nonsense the previous Government inflicted upon them as against our policies, they will have their chance to test that within about a year or so and they will get the answer that they got on the last three occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer and relates to his representation of the Treasurer at the World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) meetings in Washington at the beginning of April. I ask the Minister: What were the major conclusions of the IMF and World Bank meetings of governors about the state of the global economy and means for maintaining the present phase of steady economic growth? In particular, were any agreements reached about a new strategy for addressing the Third World debt crisis more effectively than during the last seven years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and I recognise his strong and continuing interest in this area and the issues involved. The interim committee of the IMF noted that over the last year output and investment in the industrial countries have expanded strongly, that employment gains have been significant and more widespread than in earlier periods and that the large external imbalances have narrowed, especially in real terms. The rapid expansion of world trade has helped to ease the debt position of a number of developing countries. The interim committee also noted that there have been developments, however, that require close attention and action.

ANSWER.PARA: In the industrial world the pace of external adjustment recently has slowed. There are signs of intensifying inflationary pressures in some countries. Interest rates have risen sharply in some countries and in many heavily indebted countries growth has slackened, debt-servicing burdens have worsened and inflation has accelerated.

The interim committee agreed that it was essential to deal promptly and effectively with emerging price pressures to ensure the sustainability of the current expansion. It noted that action in this direction had been taken in many industrial countries. The committee also agreed that, in the deficit countries, measures to increase national saving are urgently needed. In particular, early action to reduce the United States Federal Budget deficit is essential as well as steps to improve the external position of the United States without pushing up interest rates.

Germany and Japan should pursue macro-economic and structural policies that will sustain non-inflationary growth of domestic demand and facilitate external adjustment. Other surplus countries, including some of the newly industrialising economies of Asia, could enhance their standard of living and contribute further to the process of international adjustment through stepped-up domestic deregulation, external liberalisation and exchange rates which reflect fundamentals.

With regard to debt, both the interim and the development committees focused on possible ways of strengthening the debt strategy. New proposals made by several countries, including the United States of America, France and Japan, were welcomed by the committee. These proposals build on the basic principles of the collaborate debt strategy as it has evolved over the past few years, on the validity of the case by case approach and the central importance of the sustained implementation of growth oriented policy reforms and improvement of investor climate in debtor countries. Those views were reaffirmed by the committee.

The committee agreed that, as part of critical assistance the World Bank and IMF can offer for adjustment programs, the two institutions should provide support for voluntary market based debt reduction transactions. It was agreed that the bank and the fund should set aside a portion of members' policy based financing to support debt reduction operations. In addition, the bank and the fund will examine the possibility of limited interest support for transactions involving significant debt or debt service reductions. I am very much aware of the honourable member's deep and continuing interest in this area of activities of the IMF and of the World Bank. I will ensure that copies of the communiques are made available to him as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the departmental publication, Australia's Population Trends and Prospects 1988, correct in stating that Australia's annual population growth rate, including that of immigration, of 1.5 per cent, is twice that of the United States and Canada, three times that of the United Kingdom and France and four or five times that of Japan and West Germany? Is it not true that Australia's relatively high employment growth rate is a result of that relatively high population growth rate?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister would be aware of the horrific situation in Lebanon at the present time, where Syrian aggression is resulting in the daily maiming and killing of innocent men, women and children. Will the Prime Minister, on behalf of the many thousands of Lebanese settlers in Australia, take action to denounce the aggression by Syria in the forum of the United Nations? Will he also request the Syrian Government to withdraw its troops from Lebanon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He will recall that, on many occasions since we have been in government, we have clearly expressed our attitude towards the tragedy which is Lebanon. I must say I am sure, despite the fact that during periods like this we have very profound differences on both sides of the House, that on this occasion I would speak for everyone in the House in again expressing our sense of tragedy about what is happening in Lebanon.

ANSWER.PARA: As has always been the case, the innocents are the sufferers. The Government is gravely concerned about the current round of fighting in Lebanon, which has resulted in some of the heaviest shelling in recent years in and around Beirut. It has been especially regrettable, I believe, that this violence began at a time when it appeared that there might have been some prospects of a political settlement through the efforts of the Arab League Committee in Lebanon.

The Australian Government urges all those involved to abide by the Arab League call for a cease-fire and to cooperate with it in its efforts to achieve a solution. In regard to the honourable member's question, in the current situation there is a particular need for Syrian forces to exercise restraint and for Syria to act constructively.

TALK.START.PARA: —And get out.

—If there is one area of the conduct of the Government's affairs in which I need no assistance from the honourable member for North Sydney, it is in the area of foreign affairs. He lives in a time warp; he is irrelevant. Australia supports a solution in Lebanon based on the territorial integrity and sovereignty of the Lebanese republic. It supports a position where there should be a withdrawal of all foreign forces, except those which are there expressly at the request of a Lebanese government representing all communities in the Lebanon. No position could be clearer than that. That applies to Syria. Those forces should be withdrawn to the extent that they remain there other than at the express wish of a government in Lebanon representing all communities in Lebanon. They should be withdrawn and that proposition applies to all troops in the Lebanon.

ANSWER.PARA: For far too long now we have seen the tragedy in that country where there has been a combination of conflict resulting from internal divisions and, loaded on top of that, the imposition of tragedy coming from the presence of foreign forces and interests which seek to play out, in the Lebanon, their own external conflicts. That has imposed an unsustainable burden upon the innocent people in the Lebanon, particularly women and children. So I easily and readily identify myself with the plea of the honourable member and trust that all governments, and men and women of goodwill around the world, will exercise their influence to try to bring about a situation where, at long last, some peace, decency and opportunity for sane living can return to that tragic country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put a question to you, Madam Speaker. I draw your attention to the fact that several members, including the honourable members for Forde, Hawker, Petrie and Fisher, all of whom hold marginal electorates, have moved their seats in the House in order to appear on television with the honourable member for Kingston, sitting behind the Treasurer during tonight's performance. Have you as Speaker agreed to these changes? If so, why? Will such members as the honourable members for Prospect and Corio regain their seats from those with marginal seats at some time tomorrow?

—Let me tell the honourable member for Mayo that these things are normally arranged following a request from a Whip on either side. The Chair has concurred in this case. The members have moved, and that is that.
—Will they be moving back?
—I have not been notified whether they will be moving back. When I discover whether they will or will not, I will let the honourable member know.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation, Madam Speaker.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Madam Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I claim to have been misrepresented in an article in the Melbourne Herald on Tuesday, 11 April, on page 5, entitled `Liberals May Reveal the Mysteries of Preselection'. My complaint is about the position of the photograph, and the title under that photograph, which says, `Mr Shipton-televised demise'. The author did not even have the courtesy to add the word `political'. The article was written in poor taste. Madam Speaker, I report to you that I am in good health, fighting fit and, to use the words of Mark Twain, `The report of my death was an exaggeration'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I was misrepresented quite deliberately by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during an answer he gave to a question from the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan). It is a misrepresentation in which the Prime Minister has indulged in the past.
—Can the honourable member get to the point where he was misrepresented?

—I will, but it is relevant to the misrepresentation to remind the Parliament of that. The Prime Minister said that the only occasion on which I expressed any pleasure, or a smile crossed my face, in relation to economic matters was whenever there was any bad economic news for this country. Even in the heat and turmoil of political debate in this place that is a dastardly unfounded charge. I have never expressed pleasure at economic pain inflicted on ordinary Australians, and it is a complete misrepresentation of the position for the Prime Minister to suggest otherwise. He sought to buttress that claim by reference to a quotation which owes its origins to an interview I gave in Washington in 1986 to Anne Summers of the Australian Financial Review. It subsequently appeared under the heading ` ``Times Will Suit Me''-Howard'. That reference has been constantly used by the Prime Minister and the Government to suggest that I took some relish in the economic difficulty that Australia suffered in 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: The context of those remarks and the context of that statement was entirely to the effect that the sorts of policies I espoused in 1986, which I still espouse, were more likely to remedy Australia's problems than the policies then espoused by the Government and now practised by the Government. At no stage did I seek to derive any comfort-personal, political or otherwise-from the economic difficulties of my country. I regard it as beyond the bounds of reasonable criticism in politics for the Prime Minister or anybody else to allege that I will ever in my political life draw any comfort from the suffering of ordinary Australians and their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to clarify an answer to a question I gave earlier.
—Does the Minister wish to add to an answer?

—Yes. I understood the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) to be asking me about the statistics quoted in a document published by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Certainly, those statistics were correct. He then went on to ask a question in respect of employment and the cause of employment. I misunderstood him and believed he was asking me whether immigrants had benefited from the growth in employment figures. Having misunderstood that, I make it clear to the House that it is true that immigrants have benefited from the growth in employment figures. Those increasing employment figures flow from the policies of the Government, not the intake in immigration.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The chaos in Australian aviation because of the failure of the Government's policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems all too often in this place that we are debating the failure of the Government's policies in aviation. Today we have confronting the travelling public of Australia a crisis at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. It is not of recent origin; it has been in place for some time and is only one of a number of problems. The crisis today arises as a result of an industrial dispute. As in many industrial disputes, many charges, countercharges and allegations have been made by the parties. The air traffic controllers have been accused of being irresponsible and avaricious. The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has been accused of being tardy and derelict in its responsibilities to address the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The real question is: What is the Government's responsibility in this area? The problem for Australia is that this dispute is embarrassing and particularly expensive. It really amounts to a failure of this Government's industrial relations policy. It is very appropriate that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) is here to address this issue because it is a direct result of his failure to act, while Minister for Industrial Relations, that his statutory authority is now having so much difficulty addressing, solving and resolving this problem.

The dispute is essentially very simple. It is about pay and conditions. It is about air traffic controllers who are in a position to use industrial muscle to hold to ransom their employer and the travelling public. What has happened to date is that the Industrial Relations Commission has ordered the controllers to end their bans and limitations on overtime and work reasonable amounts of overtime. Their reaction has been to ignore that order from the Commission. The Civil Aviation Authority has proceeded to stand down air traffic controllers. We were told in the House today by the Minister that a controller was stood down last night and that the Minister anticipated that other controllers would be stood down this afternoon.

The Minister went on to say that certain action would be taken to have a bans clause inserted in the air traffic controllers' award. That is where the credibility of the Government falls in a total heap, and why it is appropriate for the Minister to explain with a straight face-I was amazed that the Minister was able to give that answer with a straight face-why he can advocate a policy which, when he was Minister for Industrial Relations, he said was totally moribund. In 1987 the Minister, when introducing the Government's ill-starred industrial relations policy, said:

An essential element of any industrial relations system which provides benefits and protections to registered organisations and their members is that there should be an effective means of ensuring adherence to the principles on which the system is founded and compliance with the decisions of its institutions.
I remind the Minister that the Industrial Relations Commission has already ordered that bans and limitations be lifted. The Minister, at the same time, went on to say:
. . . the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund . . .

These are the clauses which the Minister in Question Time, not half an hour ago, said he would rely upon to resolve this dispute in Sydney. His words were: `. . . long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process'. We do not have to remind honourable members what happened to the replacement by a new direction and injunction process. It did not happen. It did not happen for a very good reason: the relationship of this Government with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).
Let me spell out exactly why it did not happen. We have a quote from Simon Crean, who aspires to be a member of this House. He said:
They can still introduce a Bill, but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.

Mr Crean, who is not yet a member of this House, says that the Government can introduce a Bill but it must be one that does not do anything about compliance. Responding to what Simon says, the then Minister for Industrial Relations and present Minister for Transport and Communications, who has told us today how he will solve this dispute with moribund provisions, said:
We do not believe it appropriate to be amending the provisions within the arbitration system now.

The chickens have come home to roost. In his current capacity, the Minister for Transport and Communications faces an industrial dispute. He proposes to resolve it; yet his course of action has been condemned by his own words. I wish him luck; for the future of industrial relations in this country, I hope sincerely that he establishes a precedent and successfully uses the bans provisions. But I do not think he will and I am not sure that he is serious about it. I am sure that he has grave doubts and reservations about the effectiveness of the course of action that he has advocated here today. What it amounts to is that as Minister for Industrial Relations he failed to act and now he is reaping the consequences.

One solution to this dispute would be for the Government to acknowledge the poverty of its industrial relations policy and adopt the course of action advocated by the coalition parties. That would mean repudiating the claims the Government has been making for six years, claims that are based on rhetoric rather than on effective industrial relations. What the Government really needs to do is to introduce effective enforcement and compliance provisions to the industrial relations laws of Australia. It is essential that the Government move in the direction advocated by the Opposition and provide for the ability of parties to a dispute to seek an injunction from the Federal Court-an injunction from a real court that can be enforced and enforced effectively with penalties. Only then will trade unions, employers and officers and members of those unions take the Government's position seriously in such disputes. Until the playing field is level and both sides of industrial relations are forced to comply with the same obligations and have the same responsibilities before the law of this country, we will see a continual rerun of the disputes we have at present.

This dispute is really only the tip of the iceberg in terms of this Government's inability to deal with the very complex and urgent issues facing aviation today. We have a crisis with the air traffic controllers. There are many other disputes that arise directly as a result of this Government's policy failures. We have a problem with Qantas Airways Ltd. Qantas recently wrote to its customers saying, `We are having difficulty with the Government's wages policy. It makes it extremely difficult for us to recruit the appropriate number of skilled tradesmen to maintain our fleet'. That is the Government's own airline-the Government is the only shareholder in Qantas. Qantas is saying that the wages policy is inappropriate. We have a problem with airworthiness surveyors and the issue of safety. There is a major problem with attracting to the all government service and to the industry as a whole qualified staff to maintain the safety standards and the Government's own regulations for aviation. That, of course, comes back to the problem of the wages policy, which is a very serious problem.

To give honourable members some idea of the magnitude of the problem, let me refer to the airworthiness surveyor's claim that fewer than 140 of the 193 existing airworthiness positions in the Civil Aviation Authority are filled because it cannot attract and retain suitably qualified people with the present working conditions. The CAA mounted a major national advertising campaign. Under the Government's wage fixing guidelines, it was able to attract one applicant. Much the same problem arises with air traffic control. One of the issues in dispute relates to support provided to air traffic controllers for data processing. There was a shortage of people qualified to perform that function and air traffic controllers were required to work overtime to fulfil that function. The Civil Aviation Authority embarked on a recruitment campaign which resulted in its recruiting 10 additional officers who were trained. I am told that of those 10 recruits only one took up a position. What happened to the other nine? Because of the inadequate pay and conditions, they sought other positions not only within government but also outside it.

We have example after example of how the Government's centralised, rigid and inflexible approach to industrial relations and wage fixing is causing problem after problem in aviation. The chaos in aviation continues. Not only will this former Minister for Industrial Relations who is now the Minister for Transport and Communications not acknowledge the difficulty he faces because of his failure to respond to the industrial relations problems but he is also failing to address issues that are critical to the future development of aviation in Australia. We want to hear from the Minister today exactly how he will settle this dispute-not the glib answer we got at Question Time, but an explanation of a procedure that will work, a procedure that he does have faith in.

We also need to know what he proposes to do to address Qantas's problems in terms of skilled maintenance people. Already we have a situation where Qantas is forced to have its aircraft serviced overseas by United Airlines. Qantas is not happy with the standard of that service. It has removed aircraft from operation and it has told the travelling public that that is because it is not happy with the service provided. For the first time in its operating history, Qantas has questions concerning its safety and has suffered safety incidents with aircraft in Australia and overseas. That is a direct result of this Government's approach to the labour market issues.

We also need to know this Government's answers for the capital funding of Qantas and of Australian Airlines. It is no good saying these issues will be dealt with by a committee. That is the approach that was used for industrial relations. The Government has thought of a course of action, it knows what that course of action is and it knows in its own heart what should be done. But when it is confronted with opposition over industrial relations from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and from the left wing of the Labor Party in the case of capital funding for Qantas and Australian Airlines, the Government has backed down and walked away from the issue. The lesson that should be recognised by the Minister at present is that the chickens do come home to roost. Inaction today will be repaid by a crisis in the future.

We have seen the crisis at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport today. We will see it again and again in the future because of the failure of this Government to address the policy questions that must be addressed. We saw how difficult it was for this Government to come to grips with the airport capacity at Sydney. The procrastination and the internal turmoil regarding the decision on the third runway was just a sight to behold. The final decision is not even clearcut. It is almost a Clayton's decision. It is the decision one has when one is not having a decision. With a nod and a wink, the right wing of the Labor Party of New South Wales is saying, `Well, Cabinet may have decided to build the third runway but don't worry. We will have an environmental impact study (EIS) and everything will be all right'.

The Minister has determined a timetable which very conveniently takes this EIS beyond the last possible date for the next Federal election. That is extremely convenient for marginal seatholders in the area and people who have already begun to campaign against this runway. The Minister's excuse for that long timetable is to provide an opportunity for public comment. Looking at the detail of the timetable, we see that only one of the 18 months is available for public comment. Where is the Minister's response to the offer from the New South Wales Government to accelerate and expedite that environmental impact study? What is the Government's response to the ongoing problem at Sydney? Despite the decision to build that third runway there is still inadequate capacity. The Government's decision has not improved or increased the capacity of the airport. It will still hit a crisis point in 1991. There will still be no runway and there will still be delays.

What has the Government done about union bans? Only a couple of weeks ago we were treated to the spectacle of the Builders Workers Industrial Union not only banning work on the third runway but also making claims against building the international terminal. What was the Government's response to that? It has problems with the two-airline agreement. The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) says that, despite de- regulation, Australia will still have two airlines. There are massive industry complaints about the CAA and the FAC, with no Government response. The real problem is that the Government just will not address the issues.

We could, of course, debate the waterfront and coastal shipping, but we do not have time. What the Minister must tell us today is why in 1987 he said that the provisions and the compliance procedures were inadequate, yet today he says they will work. He must tell us exactly how he is going to solve this problem and how he will enforce compliance on air traffic controllers. The country cannot afford a continuation of a very expensive dispute that is costing the airlines and the travelling public a lot of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) was obviously battling to find a way to fill in his 15 minutes. He even wanted to start talking about the waterfront, which seemed to have little to do with the chaos in Australian aviation because of the failure of the Government's policies, which was the topic that he put up for discussion. There is a serious dispute involving air traffic controllers at Sydney; there is not chaos in the aviation industry in general. The aviation industry has grown spectacularly in the last several years. During this Government's period in office there has been an explosion in activity in the aviation industry, associated particularly with the growth of tourism. There has also been an explosion of aviation activity in many other countries. That has put great pressure on that industry in terms of its infrastructure and having sufficient skilled staff to service the demands of the customers. Of course, that shows up in various ways.

SPEECH.PARA: It shows up in respect of the shortage in some areas of skilled staff. There has been a shortage involving air traffic controllers, particularly support staff rather than air traffic controllers as such, and some maintenance workers for Qantas Airways Ltd have been mentioned, as have some other people employed by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The domestic airlines also have found it difficult to achieve the staff levels that they want. But the airlines do not have that problem on their own. It is something which is not confined to the aviation industry. As everyone knows, the economy has been growing very strongly. There has been extraordinarily rapid growth in employment and there has been great pressure on demand for skilled labour. One of the key aspects of the Government's success in that respect has been that, when there has been enormous pressure on employers to bid staff away from each other, to retain or attract skilled labour, we have not had what would have happened in normal times, when that kind of activity would have taken place on a large scale, leading to a spectacular wages blow-out.

One of the great successes of the Government's accord has been in the context of that kind of labour market. With the shortages showing up on various fronts, including the aviation industry, this country has not had in any respect the kind of wages blow-out which would have occurred under the previous Government's policies or which would occur, if the Opposition were to get back into government at some future time, under the then Government's industrial relations policies. What is preventing a spectacular wages blow-out at the present time is the accord, which has the support of the trade union movement, which has helped us through extremely difficult times and which will deliver responsible wages outcomes and enable the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in combination to ensure that wage and salary earners generally have their real incomes protected and in some ways enhanced. The package to be announced tonight by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will elaborate on that aspect.

The dispute which is the main focus of the address by the honourable member for Richmond is a serious one. It is, as he said, almost solely about wages. The log of claims which the air traffic controllers produced went to matters beyond wages, but most of those matters have been satisfactorily addressed. It is the wages issue which remains unaddressed. It was addressed by the CAA and the Federal union of air traffic controllers, and by the end of March there was an agreement about the process which would take place to bring about award restructuring for air traffic controllers, who would then be among the first group of employees in this country to achieve increases from the award restructuring process. It was agreed that a case would be put to the Industrial Relations Commission by the end of March, and that was done. A little more work needs to be done on that before it can be finalised and accepted by the Commission, but it was hoped that, in the context of the review of award restructuring which is taking place at present, the Commission would consider the air traffic controllers' case along with several others, including other aviation industry employees and employees from some other areas.

That agreed process between the CAA, the employer and the union for the air traffic controllers has been put in great jeopardy by the actions of one section of the air traffic controllers-the air traffic controllers at Sydney, who constitute a sizeable proportion of the total union. Those people in Sydney have decided to ignore the approach of their Federal union and simply to put in a claim for a wage increase of up to 42 per cent. An increase of 42 per cent is absolutely beyond the pale. It is way beyond what there could be any reasonable expectation of achieving through award restructuring or any other sensible wages policy, but that is what they have claimed. It is the refusal of the Civil Aviation Authority to consider a claim of that dimension, and indeed to consider any claim outside the award restructuring context, which has led to the current dispute, causing disruption in the aviation industry and leading to great difficulty for passengers and the airlines.

As I have said in Question Time on a couple of occasions, the Government has addressed that dispute with the appropriate measures. It has sought to explain to the air traffic controllers in Sydney that their claims are well outside the bounds of reasonableness and outside the wage fixing principles and therefore could not possibly be accepted by the Government. We have explained to them that they are putting their prospects of an early award restructuring increase in great jeopardy by pursuing the current course and have indicated to them that there is no way that the Government will allow their continual closing down of the airport through refusing to undertake extended duties to continue and create great difficulties in the industry. The Government and the CAA have agreed that the appropriate course is to obtain stand-down clauses. They were obtained yesterday and have been utilised yesterday and today. The next step, as I indicated at Question Time, was to say that if this action continues the Government will take action to put a bans clause in the award, which will mean that if the bans and limitations continue there will be a possibility of fines or penalties of up to $500 a day being imposed on the union and the individuals concerned.

That process is in accord with the procedures provided for in the Industrial Relations Act. The honourable member for Richmond sought to get some comfort from the fact that at some stage I said something rather critical about bans clauses and indicated that another process would be preferable. Of course, that is history and I do not deny that I said those words, but what he got absolutely wrong was the reason that the Government withdrew its original intention to have a directions process put in the Act. He said that was because the ACTU would not tolerate it. The reason that we withdrew it was that the employers would not tolerate it. The employers insisted that the approach to penalties which we had in the original industrial relations legislation was one which they would not accept. It was on that basis that the Government withdrew the approach to penalties provided for in that package and went back to the bans clause approach.

I think that the directions procedure would have been better but, given the circumstances that we faced, circumstances of considerable entrenched opposition from the employers, we decided it was best not to proceed on a course of which they would be extremely critical and obviously totally unaccepting. In those circumstances the Government has to rely on the bans clause. The bans clause was moribund for years because private employers would not use it. What the Government is doing here is making sure that it is used, if necessary. We do not want to use it, of course, but, if it is necessary, clearly it will have to be used. That action will be taken this afternoon. We will not allow a situation to continue in which air traffic controllers take industrial action which causes continual chaos with the closing down of Australia's most important airport-Sydney Airport. That situation must be brought to a head. We will do that.

The honourable member for Richmond mentioned maintenance problems. Qantas has had problems in relation to maintenance staff and other skill shortages. I have mentioned that those have not been confined to Qantas. They have been sought to be addressed by Qantas by the appropriate means-that is, through award restructuring. Qantas is one of the first groups which would achieve increases for its maintenance employees through award restructuring. Indeed, its case is before the Industrial Relations Commission at present. I expect that aviation industry maintenance staff, including Qantas aviation maintenance staff, will be among the first groups in the country to achieve an increase through the award restructuring process. Qantas, in its handling of this matter, has not conducted itself in total accord with good industrial relations policy. I have been somewhat critical of it in the way it has gone about it. Nevertheless, taking the matter through the award restructuring process is the way to go.

The honourable member for Richmond also indicated that there was something wrong with the way the Government was approaching this issue. He seemed to indicate that what we should do is throw a lot of money at the staff. He said that there was a skill shortage problem because of our wages policy; that we were too restrictive; we were not giving staff enough pay. He said, by implication, that if they were given big fat wage increases that would fix the problem. We know that that is the sort of wages policy which the Opposition has had in the past. Under its policy in 1982-83 there was an 18 per cent wages blow-out. That is what happened under the Fraser Government. Its policies were to abuse unions, continually threatening enormously tough action but, on the other hand, being utterly powerless to do much while wages blew out periodically through the total incapacity of that Government to produce a proper industrial relations policy.

The Hawke Government has not only achieved very good industrial relations outcomes in the sense of a level of industrial disputes which is 40 per cent of that which applied under the previous Government-there has been a massive reduction in the amount of time off as a result of industrial disputation-but also it has had a controlled wages policy. We have not had the booms and enormous surges which the previous Government's wages policy gave us and which would occur again if it were to get back into government. We heard from the honourable member for Richmond the kinds of things that the Opposition would do. Its solution, if there is a problem, a bit of a shortage, is to say, `Throw some money at it. Give them a big increase. Don't worry about the fact that everyone down the road will do the same thing. They'll try to make sure that they keep their staff in the factory down the road and they'll make sure that the one up the road from them keeps up with them' and so on. Under the Opposition there would be a round of large wage increases while everyone tried to retain and attract staff. That is the kind of wages system which the Opposition would advocate. That is what has brought Australia undone time and time again.

What is happening with the award restructuring approach is that we are giving a wage increase in a sensible way and are addressing the need to attract people to become more skilled. We want to give them a career path-an incentive to gain more skills and get wage increases by moving up a career path into high levels of skills. That is a very sensible combination of a controlled wages policy and skill development policy. There is nothing in what the Opposition has produced either in opposition or in government which would indicate that it could possibly deliver such a wages policy.

The honourable member for Richmond said that the Government had not addressed Qantas's capital funding problems. There is no way that Qantas is being inhibited by its capital structure in acquiring any aircraft that it wants to acquire at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.

—The honourable member said he would tell us what to do about Qantas's capital funding. There is no problem about capital funding. Obviously, over the next several years-if Qantas expanded in the way that it sees itself likely to want to expand-there could be a capital funding problem. However, that matter is being addressed. There is no problem now. Qantas is not being inhibited one iota from acquiring aircraft that it needs to obtain to expand its fleet and to keep up with its share of the business by its capital structure. The fact that there could be a longer term problem is being addressed thoroughly by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also said that there was a Clayton's decision on the third runway because there was to be an environmental impact study (EIS). The obvious implication from that is that the Opposition would disregard the EIS and not abide by the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. It would just go through some Clayton's EIS instead of adhering properly to the processes of an environmental impact study to enable us to be sure that we would not be adversely damaging the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the domestic and international travelling public of Australia, the airlines, the tourism infrastructure of Australia, the travel agents, the travel operators, and, indeed, industry in Australia, there is no joy to be had from the speech just made by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). In actual fact, the situation is the direct opposite. To sum it up we must look at the newspaper headlines of the last few days which read: `Nation's airlines face chaos'; `Willis ignored by airport controllers'; `No work on runway threat by unions'; `Third runway: union work bans'; `Warning of ALP runway fiddle'; `Six-hour airport closure will hit Queensland hard'; `Tourists in strife as air strikes hit'; and today's editorial in the Brisbane Courier-Mail says `Airport chaos has to end'. Those headlines say it all. They are indicative of the problems that each and every Australian faces in terms of the provision of international aviation services. That has to stop.

SPEECH.PARA: Never before have we been in the state in which we are in at the moment. We are turning away people coming to Australia as tourists-people who will provide foreign income for us, who will help reduce our balance of payments. Never before have we heard of our second biggest industry, in terms of foreign earnings, being destroyed by lack of action of the Government. The Government's lack of action does not just apply to the present work bans that are hitting Sydney Airport. It refers to the last six years of absolute decay in the aviation industry in Australia. It is about time that that was fairly and squarely addressed and resolved.

There is a state of chaos. Can honourable members imagine a situation, as occurred yesterday, when Sydney Airport was closed and flights had to be diverted to Brisbane and Melbourne? Can they imagine, as was reported today, 13 flights being transferred to Brisbane from Sydney? What happened then? Thirteen jumbo jets sat on the ground. The Courier-Mail described the airport as resembling a supermarket car park. What is worse, I would estimate that there would have been at least 5,000 international travellers on board, some of whom had come from as far away as the United Kingdom and the west coast of the United States. Five thousand international travellers into Australia sat on the ground, locked up in an aeroplane for 2 1/2 hours. That happened because we did not have the facilities to handle it. Time and time again, Minister after Minister has told us that the present situation in Brisbane is perfectly adequate; nothing will be done. Time and time again the Federal Airports Corporation has put off the construction of an international terminal there. Not only can Brisbane not handle its present traffic, when there is chaos around it cannot make any real contribution to the situation at hand.

So that I will not be parochial, I will quote a little gem from the intellectual giants of the Minister's Department. When an Air India flight was diverted from Sydney to Melbourne yesterday, some of its passengers were destined to go to Melbourne. What happened? Those passengers were locked up in the transit hall and told that they could not get out, that they had to go to Sydney and fly back again. That story appears on the front page of a newspaper. It was only when that was exposed on a Melbourne radio station that the authorities relented and let 12 passengers out of the transit lounge, even though their ticket said `destination Melbourne' and not Sydney. That is the type of thing we face at the moment.

A monthly edition of a very influential international magazine to which I subscribe, Business Traveller, arrived on my desk yesterday. One of the feature articles is entitled `G'day mate, please wait'. This magazine has a circulation around the world of approximately 1.2 million copies. I would like to take a little time today to quote some of this article. `Things move slowly at the hub . . . in this look at Sydney's Kingsford Smith which was originally designed for B-707 operations' is the introduction. It reads:
Sydney airport is the major hub for most of the south Pacific as well as Australia-but unfortunately, like the wheel, things move much slower at the hub than near the rim.
Long-notorious for its seriously inadequate international terminal . . . the airport is an unpredictable feature on your travel itinerary.
A political debate is raging over the need for an extra runway or a new airport about 60km out of town . . .

Some improvements to the terminal have recently been completed, but these only make it almost adequate to cope with current traffic flow and at peak periods it still resembles the fringes of a war zone. Most mornings, almost on the dot of 6am when the nightly noise curfew is lifted, the wheels of a wide-body, longhaul international jet touch down on the runway. It is followed within minutes by a gaggle of others and they all race for the international terminal like chickens at feeding time.
At this point, experienced foot-soldiers in the frequent traveller infantry can be seen peering out of their aircraft windows towards the terminal to size up the combat zone awaiting them.

If your aircraft is one of the first to the terminal, this is one of those times when it really is worth pushing your way off the aircraft as rapidly as possible and then sprinting . . . to the customs and immigration check.
The article goes on to advise travellers to avoid the inbound duty free shop because it is an absolute rip-off. The article continues:

By this time however, you are close to the customs barrier and a glance around will help you size up the tactical situation and check whether following jets have yet disgorged their shock troops onto the beach-head-or whether you are in the last wave.
It says that recent modifications to the terminal have helped a bit. Although one now has to pay for one's baggage trolley, the article says:

The performance of the baggage carousels has been improved by fitting more powerful motors to the conveyor belts feeding them. This appears to have put an end to the old farce of overloaded belts grinding to a halt, forcing men in overalls to climb up and down through various orifices to get things moving again. The system is still a bit of a lash-up however and flight numbers are sometimes switched around, forcing you to scramble from one over-crowded carousel to the next.
It then gives a few clues on how one can do a bit of queue jumping to get through immigration and customs.

I will not read the rest of the article, but the same story applies to people leaving Sydney. This is the premier airport of Australia. This is the major international gateway. This is the gateway that is handling 52 per cent of the business. This is the problem that has been totally and utterly ignored by this Government for the last six years. We will hear that there are all sorts of plans for the international terminal; but the point is that, no matter whether we look at Sydney, Brisbane or some of the other major developments at airports in Australia, the plain facts of the situation are that they have all come too late and that all the predictions of the Government in terms of international airline growth to Australia have been dead, motherless wrong for years.

I was delighted to see the other day that perhaps by the year 2000 we could have up to five million international visitors. That figure came from one of the government departments. Do government departments never check any of the other predictions? Have they not seen the figures of the International Civil Aviation Organisation, which predicts that by the turn of the century there will be six million international visitors coming to Australia? I really wonder where the departments get their information from. I really wonder about the competence of the people who do these forward projections on the growth of aviation into Australia. As I say, on every prediction they have made so far they seem to be dead, motherless wrong.

The problem in relation to publications such as Business Traveller, which has a world-wide circulation, is that once a destination is bad mouthed the word will get around pretty quickly. Already we have seen a move by the international airlines to get out of Sydney, to get out of the major gateway and go to other ports, particularly Cairns and Brisbane. That is great, as long as Cairns and Brisbane can handle that extra traffic. I am a great believer in allowing people to come through the front door of Australia rather than the tradesman's entrance, Sydney. That is exactly what Sydney international airport is, it is a tradesman's entrance. It is an absolute disgrace.

At a time when we are screaming for international money, when we are trying to solve the balance of payments crisis, when we have an industry which has been boosted not only by the Government but also by the private sector and we have tourists coming to Australia by the millions, we are doing the best we can to scare them away.

Never let us forget that, despite what the Government says, there is only one industry in Australia that is providing long term jobs for the young people of this country, and that is tourism. The longer we go on with this rubbish, the longer we restrict the number of international airlines coming into Australia, the longer we delay the development of these airports, the longer we take to get things right, those jobs will be going down the gurgler at a faster and faster rate of knots. There is chaos in the Australian aviation industry. There has been very little government guidance. The whole thing is an absolute disgrace. The sooner this Government goes and we get some competent management into the place, the better. Otherwise Australia really is in trouble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, what we have had from the other side is a litany of problems being enunciated without any offers of solutions. What we have seen is the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) reeling off newspaper articles, reeling off headings and talking about the difficulties experienced by tourists coming into this country and getting through Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, without offering any solutions. They conveniently forget many of the facts that can be clearly outlined to the people of Australia to show what this Government is doing about them. Let us go to a couple of them straightaway.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the honourable member for Fadden said that the problems at Sydney Airport, presumably because of the terminal position and so on, are turning tourists away. It might be news to him, since he emphasised in his contribution today the question of tourism into this country, that one of his colleagues on that side of the House, the shadow spokesman on tourism, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), put out a press release the other day saying that the problem for tourists coming into this country is not the airport but the high cost of accommodation in the tourist industry being charged by the hoteliers in Sydney. What does he say about that? Does he agree with that? Does he give that any credence at all? Is that a problem facing the Australian tourism industry? Is that at the heart of why tourists are not coming here? The answer probably is in the affirmative.

Secondly, the honourable member for Fadden talked about the timetables of international carriers and said that come 6 o'clock the curfew is lifted, the bell is rung and all the airport activity is stirred up, the international aircraft come in and the domestic aircraft start to depart. Why is that? It is because international carriers choose to manage their timetabling in such as way as to meet the requirements of the curfew at Sydney because of environmental considerations that this Government has for the residents of the Sydney region. They choose, therefore, to put those people in as soon as possible.

Time and time again this Government has endeavoured to negotiate with those international carriers over the opportunity to space out the times of landing throughout the whole day. But it has not been successful because those carriers do not choose to do that. It is not because this Government has not endeavoured to influence those decisions.

The other thing that was said was that the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has completely abrogated its responsibilities in respect of the terminal. What the honourable member for Fadden conveniently did not say was that the FAC has already been authorised to spend $214m to double the size of the existing international terminal. Why did he not say that? Why did he not say that the FAC is already spending $40m, as of now, to make improvements in that system? Why were those facts not outlined in his complaints about this Government's supposed lack of initiative and lack of effort? He spoke absolute rubbish. He does not say it simply because his claims are not founded in fact. If one looks at what this Government is doing one can see that those problems have been recognised; but, unlike the Opposition, we have put forward solutions and we are achieving our objectives.

Believe it or not, this matter of public importance is supposedly about the chaos at Sydney Airport that has been brought about by an industrial dispute. What the honourable member for Fadden neglected to say, when talking about the present airline dispute there, was that in 1977 there was an absolutely massive and chaotic air traffic controllers strike. The solution offered then by those opposite, who were in government at the time, was-guess what-buckets full of money. They said, `Here you are, boys. We don't care. Here are buckets full of money. Let's go'. What effect did that have? As the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) said in his contribution today, it exploded the wages system.

The Government, of course, through its consultation rather than confrontation policies, has always believed that Australia's economic interest is at the forefront. We have always believed that the process through the accord and negotiation around the table between the trade unions, leaders of the trade union movement and our Government is the most effective way to achieve a rational and sensible wages policy. We know that the Opposition does not have a wages policy other than that if there is a strike it will give in to industrial blackmail. It says, `We'll throw buckets full of money at it. That's the way we'll get over it. Then we'll forget about it for the time being. When the time comes around again, when another union determines that it perhaps will go outside wage guidelines to achieve its own particular ends, we'll throw more money that way'. What a great and sensible policy that is!

What did we see in 1982-83? We saw some great results-a wages explosion. The end result was that employers could not keep up with that wages explosion and 500,000 people were thrown on the unemployment scrap heap, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) constantly reminds the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), as he was responsible for most of it.

Quite clearly, this matter of public importance today emphasises one important matter-that is, the question of balance between consultation and confrontation. This Government is always in the forefront of consultation. No better has that been demonstrated than in this question of industrial relations. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) adequately covered that area in his contribution today and I do not propose to add anything further. But some comments were made about the process of the decision to have a third runway placed at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport as a result of the chaos that has occurred in Sydney because of problems over the last two years. Let me say one or two things about that process. I refer particularly to the proposed environmental impact statement (EIS) because some comments were made about a group on this side of the House and its involvement in that. The first thing that needs to be said is that, unlike those opposite and unlike what Greiner might do in New South Wales, we are proposing a rational environmental impact statement process which will draw out all the necessary information in a physical environmental and social environmental sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you want that for? You have got an airport there now.

—The honourable member for Maranoa is asking why we need an EIS. Out in the cow country where he comes from, where there are not too many people and not too many planes flying around, it would not affect the cattle but it affects the people around Sydney. People's lives are affected by aircraft flying around all day. This Government has taken a rational approach to that. We have a curfew. We have looked at that curfew and, for the benefit of the travelling public, and Australia's balance of payments, because of the tourists who come in and spend money, we have revised that matter. But the environmental impact statement needs to look at a range of options.
—Like what?

—It needs to consider the noise exposure forecast and the footprints that develop around the new runway proposals. Who is likely to be affected? If honourable members opposite took the opportunity to have a look at some of the proposals that have been put forward for the various spacings of the parallel runways they would see that, in the past, people who have not been affected by noise suddenly may be. Do honourable members opposite not think that we at least owe them the opportunity to come forward and put their views? This Government does. This Government believes in public participation in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to put the lie to another thing that was raised by the honourable member for Richmond. He said that only one month will be available for the discussion of this EIS. That is simply not true. The resolution and the press statement put out by the Minister stated a minimum of one month. The Government and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) have already indicated that that process will be extended, certainly to a minimum of three months. That is something that we on this side of the House would applaud because we believe that the residents of the Sydney region who could be affected by increased noise exposure have the right and obligation, and should have the opportunity, to put those views to this Government.

According to the Liberals of New South Wales, the EIS process should take no more than three months. Having been involved in such a process in a previous capacity, I have to say; `What absolute nonsense!'. They have conveniently forgotten that the EIS process to choose a second Sydney Airport site took approximately two years to complete. As part of that process, things like noise exposure forecasts, biosystems, problems about obtaining fill and the necessity for looking at social and economic consequences were looked at. All of that has to be addressed once again in this proposal. We simply cannot say that we want a third runway, a parallel runway, and pull the fill out of Botany Bay or put a drag line and a pump system right out to sea or go to some of the nearby bays and dredge all the sand up with no effect on the environment at all. We could do that if we were in the National Party or in the Greiner Liberal Party in New South Wales. This Government does not work that way. This Government will ensure that the environment is not affected and that an appropriate solution is developed.

This Government has demonstrated to the travelling public its commitment to a third runway in a number of ways. It has taken the decision to build a second airport and it has chosen the site. Did the Liberals ever do that? No, they did not. They did absolutely nothing. This Government has taken the decision in respect of a third runway and an appropriate EIS is being developed along those lines. It has taken a decision not to be subjected to industrial blackmail by a small group of aircraft controllers who have launched nothing more than a wages grab, and it has done it appropriately. What would honourable members opposite do? Would they give in? Would they throw more money at this group like they did in 1977? If that is their industrial relations policy we are in big trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.
