DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1988-89APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was defending myself against the accusations of the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) when he suggested that the criticisms directed to the Australian Statistician and the Australian Commissioner of Taxation were misplaced and ill-founded. I made reference to the fact that the Australian Statistician had disappeared overseas during the week that Senate Estimates Committee C was holding an inquiry into the Department of the Treasury. I also said that that Committee had adjourned its inquiry for the following week pending Mr Castles's return to Australia.

—I do not want to take up too much of the honourable member's time, but he is supposed to address the matter that is before the Chair and not rehearse a speech made at the second reading stage. In the third reading debate he can talk to the Bill that has been adopted on the second reading.
—We are dealing with Appropriation Bills. Mr Deputy Speaker, you were not here at the time and I can understand your not being totally familiar with the events of the Parliament just before--

—It does not require me to be familiar with what happened before one o'clock; it requires me to know what the Standing Orders are. They state that the honourable member shall address the Bill before the Chair rather than rehearse a speech appropriate to the second reading.
—I am not rehearsing anything.
—He does not have to rehearse it; he is too good.
—I do not have to rehearse anything.

—The honourable member for Mitchell does not need to interject either. The honourable member for Moreton needs to stick to what is before the Chair and not go through what would normally have been a second reading contribution.
—That is a matter of consideration.
—It is a matter of fact.

—I will help you, Mr Deputy Speaker, by saying that it is a matter of direction. The point I am trying to make is that the criticisms that were made at that time which were associated with the Appropriation Bills were well directed and totally justified. Let me refer quickly to the Hansard of Senate Estimates Committee C on 18 October 1988. The Minister Assisting the Treasurer advised that Committee by way of a letter:

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the request from the Senate Estimates Committee C that the Statistician, Mr Ian Castles, be recalled from leave to attend these meetings, I am unwilling to do so. I find the current `Acting Statistician' arrangements adequate in these circumstances.
Yet the week before Senator Shirley Walters expressed the view that it was most desirable that Mr Castles be present at that Committee. Mr McLennan, who was the Acting Statistician, said:
I could second that.

So there was a desire by both the Bureau and the Opposition to permit Mr Castles to appear. My view is that if the Government is going to play funny games with the commissions and statutory authorities of this country, of course the heads of those bodies will come under fire. If the Government is going to keep them away from the watchful eye--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Moreton is out of order. He will stick to what is in the Bill, not what should be or could be, but what is specifically in the Bill. He will not debate the issue which should have been debated at the second reading stage.

—All right. I think I will let my comments on the Australian Statistician stand. I am about to move onto another very important part of the Appropriation Bills-that is, the means whereby Australia collects the cash. The Australian Taxation Office makes it possible for funds to be gathered to make these Appropriation Bills eventuate. Mr Deputy Speaker, I take heed of your advice and abandon all comments about the Australian Statistician's office.
—It is in the Bill.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will cease interjecting.
—He was assisting me.
—He was not assisting the Chair.
—The honourable member for Mitchell drew to my attention the fact that in the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) there is an additional appropriation of $7,217,000 for the Australian Statistician's office.

—Order! As I have said to the honourable member, he can speak to the matters that are in the Bill. He cannot argue for or against a matter as he has done in a second reading debate. At the second reading stage we make up our mind as to whether we will have the matter. The House has now decided on the matter.
—Really, this would have all been over had I had a clear run. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not reflecting on your duties.
—That would not be wise.

—I will allude briefly to the Bill in accordance with your direction, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the allocation of $7,217,000. The Government needs a lot of this extra money because of the utter bungling that the Australian Statistician has gone through in the last year. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has been conducting a household expenditure survey which has required several visits from its collectors. People are refusing to do the survey because thousands of people are aware of the debate last year and they are encouraging their friends not to do the surveys.

SPEECH.PARA: When members of the Bureau appeared before the Senate Estimates committee the other day they said that they had only had a few people causing difficulties. I am getting people at the rate of three to five per week every week from all over Australia ringing me and saying, `Mr Cameron, we have heard of the Opposition's views on this survey. What should I do?'. I say, `I am aware of the Appropriation Bill allocating another $7m. The reason for this is that the Government has to finance the extra calls and the persuasive measures that the Bureau has had to adopt because it is not fulfilling the requirements of this Act'. What really gets in my craw is the fact that this Government is prepared to stand by statutory authorities which do not follow the law.

The Australian Taxation Office is the collector of the funds that make the appropriations possible. In recent times we have had the introduction of the tax file number. There is a law in this land which specifically requires-Mr Deputy Speaker, you probably presided over the introduction of the legislation-that if the date for the introduction of what is called the introductory procedures of the tax file number extends beyond 31 March, there should be a proclamation. Members on the government side of the Parliament and members on this side of the Parliament all voted for it, the Senate endorsed it and yet come 31 March the Australian Taxation Commissioner puts out a press statement saying that the people in the Tax Office are reasonable and that they are not going to worry if the public took a few extra days to put their tax file numbers in. Quite frankly, as far as I see things, the law of the land applies to every individual and the Taxation Commissioner, as big-hearted as he might wish to appear to be, has no right to disregard the decisions of this Parliament and, on his own initiative, disregard the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Moreton has no right to disregard the Standing Orders. He might relate his remark to the appropriation of money to the Tax Office which appears on page 36 of the Bill.

—I am talking about the additional money that we are told will be forthcoming as a result of the tax file number which makes these appropriations possible. I wish it were as easy for me to get through this debate as it is for the Taxation Commissioner to skirt the law and to conduct the affairs of the nation as he sees fit rather than in accordance with the dictates of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: For my own peace, I will conclude my comments on this matter. I say to the Taxation Commissioner: no man in Australia's history has bored into the little man if he made a little mistake or a big mistake, whether he is an honest or dishonest taxpayer, more than the Commissioner. It is all the same; they are screwed into the ground to teach them a lesson. The laws of this nation apply as equally to John Citizen as they do to Mr Boucher and there is a requirement for him to follow the law, the decisions of this Parliament, and not to interpret the Acts of Parliament as he wishes. I suspect that I will be followed by the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer. Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope that you are as tough on him as you have been on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-What we heard in the concluding remarks of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) was just a continuation of the harassment of public servants. The law is there for everyone in this nation. If he has a genuine complaint--
—I had one last week.

—Will you be quiet, little man. The honourable member sits there all the time interjecting. He should get up on his feet and participate in the debate. He will not do that. We just hear him chirp, chirp, chirp like a little monkey.
—Order! The Minister will not respond to the interjections. The honourable member for Mitchell will cease interjecting.

—The honourable member for Moreton has been on this crusade for years. He has been chipping away, attacking public servants, whoever they are. It is a pretty cheap sort of stunt. If he has a genuine problem on behalf of his constituents and he feels that somebody has been treated not in a manner he should have been treated, I am all with him. But I have heard him in debate after debate for month after month, year after year. There must be some other things happening in the electorate of Moreton besides that. He can go to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We should have a look at the Hansard and see how many questions he asked of the Treasurer on these matters.
—I asked one last week.

—The honourable member asked one and he fled overseas for three months to the United Nations so that he would not be here. He asked a question about the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey last year.
—Order! The Minister will speak to the matter before the Chair. The honourable member for Moreton will cease interjecting, as will the honourable member for Mitchell.
—I asked one.
—I warn the honourable member for Mitchell.

—There is a proper way to do this. Every officer of the Public Service has a responsibility to carry out his obligations in a manner that is in accord with the law, in a manner that is acceptable to the community and to members of this Parliament. I think we are all as one on that view, but we do not see that in this case and that has not been the tenor of the problems raised by the honourable member over the years.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with some of the correspondence. There has been an occasional letter about the matter that he has raised. But there has been in respect of the household expenditure survey, for which funds are appropriated in these Bills through the Australian Bureau of Statistics, a continuing campaign of harassment, of denigration of the conduct of that survey. Members of the Opposition around Australia have participated in letter writing to the newspapers, in phone-ins to radio stations, in generating public concern about a survey that they think is a useful hobbyhorse to get onto to create disquiet in the community and, essentially, to frighten aged people. I find that whole exercise quite despicable. Every member in this House should ask why these surveys are conducted. The methods, the laws and the provisions under which this survey is being carried out are those legislated by the Fraser Government, not by this Government; it is the legislation of the Fraser Government, with which we agree. The household survey is used--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is getting away from the matter before the Chair.

—I realise that, Mr Deputy Speaker, but prior to your coming into the Chair, these matters were all raised by the honourable member before lunch. I am trying to answer them and keep within the Standing Orders as directly as you would like me to do.
—We are not going to have a wide-ranging debate here.

—In those circumstances I will do my very best to curtail my remarks and keep within the confines of the points that you have made earlier, Mr Deputy Speaker. But they were raised earlier in the third reading debate.
—We are not going to have a debate on the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, with respect, they were raised in the third reading debate by the honourable member before lunch.
—That, in a sense, is irrelevant.

—I understand that. The honourable member accused me of sending the Statistician overseas when he was requested to appear before the Senate Committee. The point is that I gave approval for the Statistician to attend the International Association of Statistics meeting on 23 August 1988, long before the date was set for him to appear before the Senate Estimates Committee. Subsequent to his attendance at that Association meeting, Mr Castles was made President-elect of that important global association. He is now the President. That is a recognition of Australia's efforts and achievements in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: So Mr Castles was not sent abroad to escape appearance before the Estimates Committee. I thought that in the public interest, given the information and evidence that was available, I could not possibly justify the expenditure of public money to bring him home to attend that Estimates Committee to provide information that could be provided by his Deputy. The accusation was made that the survey is illegal. I will read one line from the Attorney-General's response to the Statistician: `In my opinion the two surveys were not significantly different'. That has been the thrust of what the Opposition has been complaining about. The surveys were not different. They are the Attorney's words.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a cooked-up statement. You know that. That was blatantly dishonest, that whole affair on 18 August.
—What the honourable member is saying is that the Attorney-General is a liar.
—I am saying that the Statistician did not tell the Attorney-General the true facts and that his subsequent opinion was based on false premises.

—I am sorry, but the honourable member had his day in court. He was wrong. I do not want to advert to the matter any further. The advice is on the record. The Opposition has conducted a campaign of harassment. This survey is extremely important. It has been carried out over the years by successive governments. The Bureau does not carry out the survey just for something to do. The survey is essential to the formulation of social welfare policies. The conduct of the survey is essential to the development of the consumer price index (CPI), its accuracy and its appropriateness. It is important to every one of the three million pensioners in this country. They want to have confidence that the CPI adjustment is accurate and up to date with expenditure patterns. That is a major use of the survey.

SPEECH.PARA: The survey is used in the development of information on the cost of health care and the cost of education and the impact of such costs on different sorts of households. It is used to assess the level of social disadvantage in the community, to help understand the nature of poverty and to identify the types of households that are in poverty. It is used extensively by industry in the development of its planning. It is used by the housing industry to monitor expenditure on house purchases. It is used by large manufacturers and manufacturing industry groups to assess the size of the market for their products and to analyse the characteristics of householders in the market. It is used by service industries, such as the insurance, child-care, health and tourism industries, to analyse expenditure data relating to them and the characteristics of consumers. It is used by the meat industry to analyse changes in consumer preferences, for example, for red meat, poultry or fish. There is extensive use of the survey across the private and public sectors. It is an important survey.

Over a year and a half the Opposition has run a deliberate campaign to undermine and put down this very important survey. What the Opposition is really doing is attacking the beneficiaries of that survey, those for whom the information is used-to determine their pensions, for example-and those who use the information in respect of industry activities. I recommend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented. I will stick faithfully--
—I did not mention the honourable member for Moreton.
—The Minister for Industrial Relations referred to me `fleeing overseas' to the United Nations for three months.
—Order! Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In accordance with the goodwill being extended to me by you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will stick to the area of misrepresentation. The Minister said that I fled overseas to the United Nations for three months. In fact, after having placed a formal complaint before the Australian Ombudsman early in August, I received his response in a letter at 4.50 p.m. on the night of 15 September. I was due to fly out of Brisbane the next morning for New York. I immediately accepted the fact that I had a responsibility to express my views in writing, and I shortened my stay in New York by a week to enable me to prepare a proper submission. All I am saying in view of the Minister's claims of my recklessness is: Fair go, Minister, that self-imposed delay cost me heaps. I would have been happy to have been in the United States for that extra week.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 makes a number of amendments to existing legislation and repeals some outdated and unused legislation. The minor administrative amendments are to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 and the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Collection Act 1964. The Bill also repeals the South Australian Grant (Fruit Canneries) Act 1971; the States Grants (Fruit-growing Reconstruction) Acts of 1972, 1973, 1974 and 1976; the Victoria Grant (Shepparton Preserving Company Limited) Act 1971; and the Wheat Industry Stabilization Fund (Disposal) Act 1962. The only significant changes will be made to the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987. The present Plant Variety Rights Act does not recognise the practical difference between propagation from seed and the faster process of asexual reproduction. Asexual propagation of plants can take place from either cuttings or tissue culture and reproduction is much faster via this method than it is through the sexual propagation of plants from seeds.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment, people can buy a few protected plants and asexually propagate dozens or even hundreds of plants in a short time. While these plants cannot be sold, what they produce, such as flowers and fruit, can be sold. This amendment protects the holders of plant rights, by giving them the sole right either to asexually propagate their plants themselves or license others to do so for the purpose of using the produce commercially. The holder of the plant right will not be able to refuse a licence to asexually propagate for the commercial production of flowers, fruit or other products, unless the person refuses to comply with reasonable licence provisions. This does not affect the person who wants to asexually propagate plants for his or her own use, or even to give away, but it will prevent the sale of any of the plants' produce. That is the amendment to the Plant Variety Rights Act.
The changes to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 simply clarify the position that all late payers of milk fat levies, including State milk authorities, will be liable to 20 per cent interest.

The amendments to the Livestock Slaughter Levy Collection Act 1964 will allow the cost of collecting these funds to come from different funds. Currently, funds collected through livestock slaughter levies are allocated to more than one fund. This amendment will allow the industry to decide from which fund the cost of the actual levy collection will be paid. For example, the industry may want to pay the costs, or at least part of them, from the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account.

The next amendment is to the Tobacco Marketing Act 1965. This will change the name of the Australian Tobacco Board to the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee. The new name of the Board will closely reflect its role of advising Ministers, on a Federal and State level, on prices and quotas and separates it from the other statutory authorities which actually handle and sell product. The Board administers the industry's stabilisation plan, which runs out in 1993. The Board is virtually a negotiating forum and has no role in the receipt, handling or sale of tobacco. These functions are carried out by the State marketing boards. Complementary State legislation is needed for the name change, so it will not become effective for six months in order to allow the States time to alter their legislation.

This Bill repeals the States Grants (Fruit Canneries) Act 1976; the State Grants (Fruit-growing Reconstruction) Acts of 1972, 1973, 1974, 1976 and the Victoria Grant (Shepparton Preserving Company Limited) Act 1971. The Bills I have just referred to were introduced to provide some assistance at a time when there were dramatic adjustment problems in the canned fruit industry and, for that matter, the fresh fruit export industry, following the United Kingdom's entry into the European Economic Community (EEC) in the early 1970s. In fact, I made my maiden speech in this place on one of those Bills. Since then, exports of canned fruit have been cut by over 50 per cent, by not only the entry of the United Kingdom to the EEC but also the application of a common agricultural policy, particularly what is known as the Mediterranean policy, which provides considerable assistance for the growing and processing of deciduous canned fruits in countries such as Greece, Italy and now, more recently, Spain. Added to this is the external tariff which was subsequently placed on the imports of any canned fruit from Australia.

Today, the canned fruit industry, in its very heavily rationalised and restructured form, is facing the loss of another market, the largest market for canned fruit, the Canadian market. It is our most profitable market with over $30m of exports. This loss is because the United States-Canada free trade agreement, which came into effect on 1 January, will give, over a period of time, preference to Californian fruit or, perhaps more correctly, remove the old Canada-Australia Trade Agreement (CANATA) or Commonwealth preference, from Australian fruit. Since 1 January a 1 1/2 per cent preferential tariff has been put in place for United States fruit against Australian and that will increase over the years ahead until there is no advantage whatsoever for Australia, in theory. In fact there will be a disadvantage for Australia.

I pay considerable credit here to the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), who has been arguing, and continues to argue, with his Canadian counterparts that the CANATA provisions should not be overruled by the United States-Canada agreement. He has been arguing that we have existing rights not only for canned fruit but also for a number of other products. In this case I am speaking about canned fruit because it is the product most affected and Canada is the biggest market following the substantial loss of the European market over the last 15 or 16 years.

I was here last week with a deputation from the canning fruit industry to see the Minister, who indicated at that time that he would be involving the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in representations to Mr Mulroney, his counterpart in Canada. I note that that is taking place and I commend the Minister for that action. I am concerned that it has taken this long for Ministers in addition to the Minister for Trade Negotiations to become involved in this very serious trade dispute, which not only has repercussions for canned fruit, sugar and so forth, but also is a precedent for the overriding of existing Australian bilateral trade agreements by new trade agreements which will no doubt come in in those countries with which we trade and have existing trade agreements.

It is very important that pressure on the Canadians be maintained at the highest possible level. I include the Prime Minister, on a continuing basis; the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). The last Minister was present at that deputation last week, together with Mr Duffy.

Another potential blow, or problem area, for primary producers, Australia's agricultural exporters, comes this week with a request by the United States Agricultural Secretary, Mr Clayton Yeutter, that Congress increase spending on the export enhancement program (EEP) to $US1.1 billion from the current level of $US750m. These are mind-boggling figures. The United States is prepared to back from its taxpayers the subsidised exports of United States agricultural products. That means that, in this coming year, Australian farmers will have to compete against United States subsidies to a level of $A1.3 billion. How can Australian farmers, without government subsidies-I am not arguing for government subsidies in Australia-be expected to trade in this type of corrupt world market?

Mr John Allwright, the National Farmers Federation President, together with the executive officer and director, Mr Rick Farley, who are now in the United States talking to United States officials, have indicated that not only is the United States preparing to play it tough in world agricultural trade, but also it will be at least two years before the United States itself allows any better access for Australian exports to that country, which are presently severely restricted. I refer, in particular, to beef and sugar. Despite the initial success of the Cairns Group in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) round, the negotiations which have just concluded in Geneva, where the United States and the European Community said they would place a freeze on agricultural subsidies and come back with a plan next year to start to reduce this assistance the following year, there are obviously still problems ahead for our exports.

I commend again the Minister for Trade Negotiations and Australian officials who have been involved in the very long and painful process of the GATT Uruguay Round and, for that matter, the Cairns Group and the concept of the Cairns Group, which has made a very positive impact on obtaining the hope for sense in world agricultural trade. However, there is a continuing danger for Australia. It is obviously a very fragile peace or truce or arrangement between the United States and Europeans at present. That is indicated on the one hand by the budget-the gunfire, if honourable members like-that the United States is lining up with its EEP subsidy, with which it would very quickly and very obviously take on the Europeans in any sort of trade war. Such a trade war would be to our obvious detriment because we would be caught in it, as we have been, for example, with wheat sales.

The Europeans themselves have been arguing-although I am pleased that I have not noticed that argument in the reporting of the agreement in Geneva in the last few days-that as part of the consideration of the reductions to be negotiated next year, their slow progress to a more sensible and commercial agricultural support policy which began in 1985 should be taken into account. That is an absurd proposition because it means that the Europeans who caused most of the trouble-they are not alone in this; the Americans played their part too-by building up to the peak in 1984 could now argue that because they are becoming somewhat more sensible that is a virtue, rather than merely a reduction in nonsensical behaviour, and therefore a plus for them in these discussions. We certainly cannot allow that ambit claim to be accepted.

The United States $1.1 billion EEP budget will mean that the United States, in pursuit of its trade goals, has the ability to export a range of agricultural products to world markets at much lower prices than Australia can, even though US farmers receive price assistance which means that they still produce products, particularly some types of grain, at above the world price. It is then sold at a dumped price against the rest of the world. For example, two very recent sales of wheat from the United States-one to China and the other to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics-were with EEP subsidies of $US21 and $US25 per tonne, which means an export subsidy and a reduction in the price of $A25 to $A30 per tonne, which is a reduction not only in the sense of those initial sales, but also in the average export price of all sales of wheat taking place, with ramifications for Australian farmers and our balance of trade.

Whilst I said earlier that Australian farmers are quite prepared and able, because of their efficiency, to compete against any country on a fair basis, I did not mean that when the United States and the Europeans subsidised their exports it was fair to expect our farmers to have to trade down to those corrupt world prices or to accept those corrupt world prices as the basis for our domestic market price. It calls into question the tactics of the Government in its international trade negotiations. I have certainly been genuinely commendatory in my acknowledgment of the work done by the Minister for Trade Negotiations in particular, but I call into question the tactics of the Government in reducing the distorting effects of agricultural support policies in other countries. Ahead of any real negotiations, Australia has already reduced its very modest level of assistance or tariff protection for a range of agricultural export industries when the Europeans and the Americans, who have far greater levels of assistance, as indicated by their export subsidies apart from their home support price systems, have not yielded anything. There will obviously be some very hard bargaining before they do.

There is now quite a dilemma for the Government because, on the one hand, the Government and our officials have to argue that we cannot accept the European claim that anything the Europeans have done since 1985 should be taken into account because of the greater commonsense in these support price systems, and on the other we will want to argue next year that other countries should take into account the reductions in a range of our tariff measures which, as I said, are already very modest measures and below those of manufacturing industry in Australia. To be consistent, we cannot argue that the changes that have taken place in Australia since 1986 should be taken into account in any consideration of reductions in assistance or protection in this country. The dilemma for the Government shows that its tactics have been wrong. It should not have done anything in this country until the other countries were prepared to negotiate. We should have put our proposals on the table at the same time as other countries. We could then have been completely clean or able to argue against the tactics of the Europeans in going back to 1985.

Another industry that has been mentioned in this debate because of one or two Acts that are being amended is the dairy industry. It has also undergone dramatic change following the entry of the United Kingdom into the European Community and the subsequent EC price support programs. The dairy program was the major feature of the common agricultural policy for many years. That program or policy provided domestic prices in the European Community of over twice the world price. Once there is the level of artificial support, there is an inevitable explosion in production. We saw that with a range of products in Europe and with sugar, for example, in the United States, although sugar may not be a completely true example for other reasons. Because of the high prices, consumption decreased in Europe and export subsidies or restitutions were necessary to get rid of a surplus product, which was dumped, in many cases into our traditional export markets, taking away those markets and corrupting the world price. Now, 15 or 16 years after that situation began, less than half the former number of dairy farmers remain in Australia, and they are very efficient farmers. There is now some return to a genuine and more commercial market internationally for dairy products. This follows the more sensible policies that Europe is now following with regard to the dairy industry.

However, with the changes, we now face another potentially accelerated period of adjustment for the Australian dairy industry because the Government has accelerated the complete introduction of the closer economic relations arrangement with New Zealand. It was to have been completed in 1995; it was then to be in 1992; and it will now be in July 1990. It comes also at a time when the New Zealanders, who have had their butter quota to Europe reduced, have nevertheless been given a compensatory increase in price by a reduction, as I understand it, of the external tariff payable on that product entering Europe, so that the value of that reduced tonnage is much the same. Under the pooling arrangements for dairy products in New Zealand, the industry has a great ability to marginally price not only into third markets in competition with Australian dairy products, but also into the Australian market after July next year. This was compounded by the decision of this Government-and I believe it was a wrong decision-to allow the New Zealand Dairy Corporation to be the monopoly trader of New Zealand dairy products to Australia. I think that is a contradiction. If a free trade agreement is being established between Australia and New Zealand-that is, an extension of the domestic market from Australia to cover New Zealand and from New Zealand to cover Australia-and there are no monopoly arrangements in New Zealand, the monopoly arrangements of an exporter should not be allowed to prevail in Australia. That practice increases the marginal pricing power and other less than fair trading possibilities for the New Zealanders in Australia.

We already have one example of that before us at the moment. This is why it is so necessary for this Government to be more vigilant about fair trading arrangements with imports than it has been to date. I refer specifically to the decision to allow low fat dairy products from New Zealand to be sold in Australia. The introduction of low fat margarines and low fat butters is a positive step; it is sensible and it is what the consumer wants. Therefore the consumer should have these products. However, it is wrong to allow New Zealand low fat dairy products, such as butter, to be sold in Australia when it is not allowed to be sold in New Zealand and when as yet we have no food standard to allow it to be formally sold in Australia. Therefore, no Australian company is allowed to sell it. At the same time, Australia, which has developed dairy blends-that is, combinations of margarine, vegetable oils and butter to allow greater spreadability-is not allowed to sell those products in New Zealand. I think that a little bit of fairness is a good thing in a genuine closer economic relationship.

The current marketing arrangement, quite often called the Kerin plan-and I think some credit should be given to the Opposition because there is at least as much Opposition input into that final plan as positive input by the Minister-runs out in 1992. That plan provides some degree of stability to an industry in a period of rapid change and adjustment. I acknowledge the contribution of that plan, but I believe the industry deserves to have some acknowledgment from both the Government and the Opposition as to their policies for the dairy industry in this country after 1992. This will be a period of adjustment and pressure from New Zealand and the rest of the world if the trade negotiations break down.

The coalition parties have a commitment to be prepared to discuss with the industry the continuation of appropriate arrangements beyond 1992 for the benefit of a world-efficient dairy industry in Australia. The Opposition parties do not oppose this legislation, but my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who is shadow Minister for science, will move an amendment in relation to the other section of this legislation which deals with minerals and energy rather than primary industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As explained by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 covers many aspects of the primary industry sector. He referred to the beef and tobacco industries, plant variety rights, and the fruit and canning industries. He also dwelt a little on the dairy industry. I am pleased that in general the Opposition is supporting the proposals put forward by the Government because these amendments are desirable. It will be interesting to see the argument put forward in favour of the Opposition's amendment. I support the amending legislation put forward by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin).

SPEECH.PARA: I want to canvass another issue in this debate, however. Whilst all these matters are vital to those in the primary industries sector, there is another matter that is raising its head-I shall not suggest it is an ugly head, but it is one which is causing grave concern. The issue to which I refer is one that is affecting rural Australia particularly, but also provincial and metropolitan Australia. That is the issue of land being bought up by foreigners and the ultimate effect that this will have on all industries: the beef industry, the dairy industry-it goes right across the spectrum of the primary sector. I tried to get some up to date figures and I found it was very difficult. However, I am able to show that in Queensland alone in 1985-86 some $70m worth of purchases took place involving 685,000 hectares of land. This increased the next year to $36m worth of purchases involving another 215,000 hectares across Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order which relates to relevance. The legislation before the House has two primary industry components: plant variety rights and tobacco marketing. I fail to see how the issue of foreign ownership of land comes within the ambit of this legislation.
—There has been a broad-ranging debate on this legislation and I do not see that there is relevance in the honourable member's point of order.

—I take your point, Mr Deputy Speaker, because had the member for Gippsland been here to listen to his own Deputy Leader he would have understood that he canvassed very widely-I think correctly-the Cairns Group and a number of international issues that really had no direct relevance to the Bill. As a member who represents a country area, I would suggest that what I have to say is of very great importance to the honourable member's constituents as it is to mine. It relates to the beef industry and the dairy industry which are covered by the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not dwell on the figures I have except to say that in 1985-86 some $44m was spent across Australia and 3.1 million hectares were purchased by foreign interests. In 1986-87 this grew to $143m worth of purchases involving another half a million hectares. In 1983 5.9 per cent of Australia was owned by foreigners. There are some claims now that that has risen to some 10 per cent. There is a real concern and that concern is widespread. Sometimes it is based on misinformation; sometimes it is based on a threat to the livelihood of young farmers who are saying, `As these foreign interests come into our country, they will pay top prices for land and, as a young person, I will never be able to start my own property or have my own farm'. That concern goes right across the nation.

In my area the Cattlemen's Union of Australia has mixed attitudes to this. It has been monitoring very closely foreign investment and whilst it has stated that it is not opposed to this, it is concerned about investment that results in domination of any industry-again I refer to the Bill because this does relate to the beef industry in part. The concern of the Cattlemen's Union relates to the domination of the beef industry. Other industry leaders have expressed reservations where the investors are developing an ability to exert undue market power. If one talks to the average Australian one realises that this is an issue; in fact it may be the most significant sleeper issue in the political arena at this moment. It is being aroused, regrettably, by people who have racist tendencies. Some people are targetting, for whatever reason, the Japanese. Others are simply pursuing the issue because they take a pro nationalistic stance and I can understand that.

It has been a political issue in my own State of Queensland for a long time. When I held the position of Leader of the Opposition in the Queensland Parliament, it was part of our policy to set up a land register. I note that Mike Ahern has now acted correctly to set up a land register. As honourable members know, Mike Ahern is a National Party member, but he has seen the need, as have the beef industry and others linked with agricultural industries across this nation, to monitor land ownership. I sometimes smile at what Mr Ahern is trying to do in view of the conflict and contrast that exists in this House where his counterparts in the National Party are locked into a Liberal Party policy which will do away with the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) if the coalition ever gets into power. It must create some interesting times in the National's party room when this issue is raised by the member for Gippsland who, no doubt, would want to protect land in his electorate. The Liberals tend to pursue an open gate policy. I worry about this because it will be an open gate policy irrespective of the consequences; an open gate policy in tourism, in commercial investment, in any aspects of land, in the domestic real estate area and in the primary industries area, in particular. Whilst on the one hand Federal National Party members in Queensland are saying that they are concerned about this issue, on the other hand they are locked into the coalition position.

I believe that the Australian people have the right to know the extent of foreign ownership in this country. They have a right to know how much substance there is in the claims that one hectare in every 10 hectares of land in this country is now owned by foreigners. We have a right to know how much of the real estate in our capital cities-the prime central real estate-is owned by foreign investors. The present Government has taken a reasonably positive approach here, in that it argues for a national interest measure. It is arguing for a community need measure. At the same time, there has been some deregulation under this Government and I believe members of the Government are raising the eyebrow a little as to how far the deregulation will go. We hark back to Gough Whitlam's time, when his Government put down strict guidelines or rules for foreign investment, rules that said, `The test shall be in the national interest'.

The fear I have here, and it is echoed across the nation, is that the test is no longer to be in the national interest; instead, it is not to be against the national interest. So it is a negative test. As long as something is not against the national interest it could be allowed. I suggest that that is getting very close to having no rules at all. I know that people who represent rural electorates are concerned and are starting to voice their concern. In the past, under the Australian Labor Party in 1972-74, there was the need for local equity, Australian equity. That has been very much cast aside, with the main exception of the mineral industries.

The Government's policy, as I said, is to encourage foreign investment at the moment, and there is an economic need for that. It is stressing the national interest aspect. It is arguing that it must be consistent with the needs of the community and it is looking at issues one by one. Honourable members may realise that there is a requirement for a compulsory review of any proposal which directly involves a foreign power. So if a foreign government or its agency is involved in some purchase plan or investment plan, it is compelled to go before the FIRB and be reviewed. This also is true with some foreign takeovers and other already foreign-owned companies, land or projects in this nation.

The general threshold of review has been raised. In the agricultural area it is only $3m, which means that anything under $3m does not have to go before the Board. In manufacturing the threshold is $5m and in some mineral areas and for some new agricultural products it is now $10m. I suggest that a lot of properties throughout this nation could be bought for less than $3m and a lot of manufacturing firms could be bought for less than $5m. In fact, it is on the record that that is happening. Abattoirs have been purchased. Whilst I appreciate that the equity test still exists in the mineral industry and whilst I appreciate that we as a government, through the initiatives of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last year, moved to prohibit investment in established residential property, I suggest to the Government, as a member of that Government, that we are not monitoring enough or, in turn, have not explained what we are doing. So often people out there in the constituencies misunderstand because of the lack of information being provided by the decision makers. I certainly think that is happening here.

That places a responsibility on me as a member of Parliament to ensure that people know. One of the reasons I welcome the chance to speak here is that people will know that something is being done. In fact, at the beef industry level, the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Council-a policy council-has set up a working group on foreign investment. It is looking for a long term strategy. It is taking a very objective look at the meat industry, and whilst this is a specialist study, I would suggest that it is going to have ramifications that will spread right across the market-place and across our nation. Also-and I am pleased with this-the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is monitoring all the applications before the FIRB. I believe most honourable members would welcome this.

Regrettably, we have an increased threshold. We now have the $3m, $5m and $10m marks. Regrettably, the local equity content requirement is being gradually dissipated. Regrettably, the national interest test is now a negative one. I think because of that and because of the moves that are taking place and the pressure that is coming on our government from commercial interest groups and those very involved in the economy, we as members of Parliament and as Australians must ensure that the changes are in the interests of this country. I know that Australia is not a saving country. We rely heavily on overseas investment. We rely enormously on the ability to borrow overseas. I appreciate that there is a need for new capital. There is a need for upgrading our industries; there is a need for new plant and equipment; there is a need for the transfer of new technology, and there is a need for a link between the end users and ourselves as the producers. There is a need for all these things. At the same time there is a misunderstanding or concern in the community.

Since 1987 five Australian abattoirs have been purchased, in this instance by Japanese interests, and they range in every State. Abattoirs in Tasmania and Victoria are linked with the Gilbertson group. We have another one in New South Wales and some in Queensland. People are worried because they see vertical integration and vertical take- overs. People are concerned that foreigners will own the grazing land; that they will then own the feedlots; that they will then own the abattoirs; and that, because of their foreign links in the market as the end users, they will have an enormous say as to the price and return in dollar terms to this country. On the other side of the story there are some very valuable advantages. In the Gilbertson group in Victoria and Tasmania, where the company Itoman has taken a 40 per cent share, there has been a diversification in the industry, and it is now tapping other markets. A new trade link has been established in Japan. I am pleased that at least there has been a retention of Australian ownership in that case. But in the Oakey case in my own State of Queensland, Nippon-Hand now owns 100 per cent of that abattoir.

I appreciate again that the abattoir is moving into the high quality lot fed beef market. It is able to compete with the United States of America. It is very important to us to be able to sell our meat, but I question whether the real return that this country is getting from Oakey is only a few jobs. If that is the case, one must question whether it meets the community need. Is that in the national interest? The Macksville abattoir in New South Wales is a different matter. The Midco abattoir there has been purchased by a consortium of Mitsubishi and Hannan. There is new plant and new technology. The company was going bankrupt. It was in receivership. Now it is majority owned by the Japanese but the abattoir is fully operational and is a major regional employer. There are massive work force gains there and an industry that was dying, or almost dead, has been retrieved and revived.

In Kilcoy in Queensland there is another approach-a joint venture with an Australian company and three Japanese companies, notably the firm Nozaki, which is a specialist meat importer and marketer. There is value here in that Nozaki is opening up and expanding the markets. It is also establishing large-scale feedlots to meet the Japanese standards. Again there are some pluses. In the Forbes works in New South Wales, the Lachley Valley abattoir was council-owned and was non-viable, but it has been totally re-established with new technology. It is totally owned by Mitsubishi and Hannan. Here again the local authority has kept a hand in the abattoir because it owns the land.

I have presented five cases to the House, some of which have massive advantages to Australia, of an industry that was almost dead having been revived; another instance where the abattoir is still Australian-owned; and another one where there is a joint venture. We need to tell the Australian-people that foreign investment can have major advantages, but we have to explain them and ensure that the national benefits are there.

Most people know that no Australian can go to Japan and buy one inch of land. One just cannot go to Malaysia, Indonesia or Thailand and buy land. For that reason I personally advocate that we should not have freehold land sales. If foreigners are to come into this country and purchase land, let it be on a leasehold basis. Let the Government at least protect the title of that land so that we can set down conditions and control the use of the land at the State government level. There are many advantages in foreign investment, as I said, and I acknowledge that, but I believe that as a nation we ought to be pushing for or urging joint ventures. We ought to ensure that there is equity investment. We ought to frown on those proposals that are being set up by private enterprise here which are foreign owned and where the money is being borrowed offshore. In the long term that process has negative economic consequences for this nation in terms of our national account. Whilst these, I suppose, can be weighed up with the new skills, the new technology and the technology transfer that takes place, we have to continue to monitor. We have to ensure that there are no collusive activities taking place in this country.

We have to be wary of the monopoly that can develop in certain industries whereby an undue influence can be exerted in terms of market power. I appreciate that fortunately in this country with the Labor Government in power, we have the Trade Practices Commission. I would be very concerned if certain members of the Liberal Party got their way and did away with the Trade Practices Commission because within the terms of the Trade Practices Act we have powers to stop the monopolistic activities of foreign companies or, in fact, any company. We have the powers to stop collusive activity. Let us hope that that never takes place, irrespective of who is in government in this country. There has been a winding down of the activities of the Foreign Investment Review Board because the thresholds are being raised.

In conclusion, I make a few specific points. We ought to throw out the negative test-that is, get rid of the requirement that is being placed on companies to show only that what they are doing is not against the nation's interest; that as long as it is not against the nation's interest it is okay. That is a twisted, difficult to understand, negative test. I believe the test should be that investment shall be in the interest of the nation-not that someone has to prove that it is against the nation's interest: it must positively be in our nation's interest. If that is the case, new technology and its transfer, the upgrading of equipment, new skills, new markets, the end user links and new investment will all come to the fore. I do not want to frighten away valuable foreign investment, but I would argue over and over again the need for an effective monitoring system to monitor the degree and characteristics of foreign investment both in primary industry and manufacturing. There is a need for in-depth and ongoing analysis of the proposals to ensure that this national interest measure prevails.

There is also a need to try to do something to maintain the family farms. That is important because people are moving away from country areas because the family farms have been bought by corporations. Our nation's strength has been small business people, the small farmer. Yet if we continue to allow companies to move in, with massive foreign investment behind them, the family farmer will disappear.

I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for allowing me to canvass these issues. They are important to every Australian, regardless of his or her political persuasion, to ensure that this country is run in the interests of every Australian. I fear that unless we continue to monitor very carefully the quality, degree and character of investment moving into this country-in many instances it is encouraged and welcomed-we will be the long term losers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to direct my comments on the omnibus Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which is before the House, to those sections relating to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act. Six principal Acts are amended so as to allow for the determination of the level of application and rental fees, registration fees and securities by regulation for petroleum exploration rather than by amendment of the principal Act. The adjustment of those fees and securities for the explorers can be made at times so as to more closely reflect actual administrative costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Later I shall move an amendment, which has been circulated in my name, which, if carried, will ensure that the fees that are set by regulation rather than, as previously, by amendment to the principal Acts do not exceed the minimum administrative costs incurred by the Commonwealth, the States or the Northern Territory in carrying out their respective obligations under the legislation. I believe that an amendment of this order will ensure that the discretionary power vested in the Minister will not become an instrument for raising revenue, nor in any way discourage the petroleum exploration industry from expanding its exploration efforts.

I wish to make some comments about the battle for energy security in Australia. By 1998 we will be paying 10 times the present shortfall between crude oil imports and exports. This will amount to an annual bill of $5 1/2 billion for imported oil. This is a result of our level of crude oil self-sufficiency dropping from the 1985-86 level of 96 per cent to only 28 per cent by the year 2000. Yet even those figures have a conservative base to them. They assume that the per barrel price is settled at about $US20. That cannot be anticipated, given the fragility of the economic environment in which oil producers operate.

Let us look at four such variables which may very well mean that the price is not constant at $US20 per barrel. Firstly, exchange rates vary widely. Secondly, the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries will strengthen its grip on the international oil market in the 1990s with the probable impact of an increase in oil prices. Thirdly, growth rates and, therefore, energy demand, especially in the transport sector, could outstrip our expectations. Fourthly, rates of recovery of oil reserves are affected adversely by high interest rates which compromise investment strategy. So if by the year 2000 we are paying only $5 1/2 billion for imported oil, we shall be very fortunate.

Quite possibly we may never close the gulf that is opening between oil imports and exports. But an intelligent energy policy can work to contain the blow-out in oil imports. The oil reserves are there. The innovative and efficient petroleum industry is there. What is not there, however, is the government policy to provide producers with the incentive and motivation to maximise their exploration efforts. As with its approach to so many other areas of its industry policy, the Labor Government has mortgaged the future of this country for its own short term political goals.

Between 1982 and 1987 the Commonwealth extracted from the domestic oil industry some $18 billion in oil and liquefied petroleum gas excise and resource rent royalties alone. It is so dependent on the revenue from our oil industry that it cannot bring itself to provide relief to encourage exploration so that in future Australia can be more self-reliant in oil.

The Government has saddled the petroleum industry with an oppressive, secondary taxation regime which saps the industry of its investment capital-investment capital which in other circumstances would provide for greater exploration activity. I will say this many times during my address to this House this evening, as I have on other occasions: exploration activity is dependent on the level of government taxation of the oil industry. Even with some tinkering with the excise charge structure last year, the Bass Strait operators-Esso and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-effectively are paying the Government a tax rate of 82 per cent on their net revenues from Bass Strait gas and oil. That is grossly inequitable and, given Australia's longer term needs, it is a disastrous policy miscalculation.

If we are to win the battle for energy security and economic stability, it is essential to encourage the industry to further its exploration efforts. If we are to retain just 50 per cent self-sufficiency in the 1990s, we will have to double our current level of discovery. In actual fact, at the present rate we will be down to 28 per cent self-sufficiency in oil by the year 2000. Maybe it is too much to expect the general public to understand fully the implications of that dependence on oil imports, but there is no excuse of any kind for a responsible government, with all its access to information, ignoring the increased dependence on oil imports. Why is the Government so paralysed that it is unable to provide the incentives for further exploration for oil in Australia? The answer is as simple as it is tragic. It is so dependent on taxation from the oil industry that it cannot see beyond the next election.

Quite frankly, the future standard of living of all Australians is being held hostage to this Government's expediency. We simply have to promote domestic prospectivity. More reserves exist in Bass Strait. It is only the Government's taxing regime which treats that area as a dry basin in terms of prospectivity. Indeed, the secondary taxation policy of the Government basically writes off the prospectivity of huge areas, both on-shore and off-shore, which have not even been marginally explored as yet. There is oil on and off shore in Australia. The simple fact is that nobody has any incentive to go exploring for it.

Given these facts, it is even more appalling that as every year slips by our growing energy dependence on foreign oil producers becomes even more apparent. In 1989 the production level from proven and producing fields returned Australia 564,370 barrels per day. In 1991 that will drop to 447,900 barrels per day. In 1995 it will drop further to 261,540 barrels per day. In 1998, at the end of the decade, we will be producing in Australia a mere 178,890 barrels per day. In more general terms, while we currently produce some 200 million barrels of crude oil a year, we need to import only some 25 million barrels a year. In 1993 we will produce only 120 million barrels. We will need to import 125 million barrels. Yet in 1998 our domestic industry-in the policy framework of the present Government-will be able to produce only 74 million barrels of crude oil. At this point we will be importing over 200 million barrels of crude oil per year. It is at that time that we will be at our most vulnerable. The impact on our balance of payments will be devastating.

In the face of these developments the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who fully acknowledges our deteriorating import profile, has taken no serious measures to boost domestic exploration rates. He, like his colleagues in the Government, is complacent. He contends that the commodity prices for the energy and minerals sector will reach such a level in the 1990s that they will offset the $5 1/2 billion that we will be paying out for oil imports. Can honourable members honestly believe that a Minister for resources in Australia would be so naive and, frankly, so stupid as to believe that our $5 1/2 billion import bill by the year 2000 will be met by increased commodity prices for all of our other mineral exports? It is such a gamble. Even if it were to come about, it is such a risk.

Such a claim by the Minister on behalf of the Government assumes a favourable economic environment based on stable international growth rates and favourable exchange rates. Even assuming that our future import bills could be offset by other tradeable energy commodities-by the way, will this include uranium?-what strategy is there for this national prosperity? Where is the strategy? How can the Government dismiss the problem of declining oil self-sufficiency by pretending that our mineral extracts sales in 15 years' time will offset the import bill? We cannot reduce it to one sentence. Where is the proof of that? Where is the structured policy?
The lunacy of this situation is not lost on the rest of the world. The international and independent consultancy firm Petroconsultants observed in its newsletter of 3 April 1989:

Petroleum exploration and production in Australia must not continue to be treated as non-strategic . . . There are serious economic flaws in treating local crude as another commodity which, when deficient in future supply, will simply be bought on open markets, imported and paid via use of surpluses generated from non-oil resources and export development.

But the Minister's complacency extends even further still. He is exposed to advice within his Department that claims the impact of the pending $5 1/2 billion annual import bill will have little direct impact on our economic development generally. It is almost hard to believe that such advice would be given to the Minister. This claim emanates from public statements from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Rural Economics (ABARE), which argues that there:
is no obvious link between levels of self-sufficiency (of crude oil supply) and national economic performance.

We have ABARE telling the Government that there is no linkage between economic performance and oil self-sufficiency. It is an extraordinary claim and one which even a first year economics student at secondary school would reject. To justify its claim the Bureau makes recourse to the examples of the economies of West Germany and Japan. By the way, in case it has been missed by the Bureau, those countries have no natural crude oil reserves at all. What parallel is there between Australia's economic context and the economic context of West Germany and Japan? Japan enjoyed almost a $90 billion trade surplus in 1987. Australia presently suffers under a $120 billion foreign debt.

Neither the Minister nor his sources of advice betray any active interest in taking any special policy initiatives to extend the life of our crude oil reserves and limit the impact of the pending balance of payments blow-out. It is quite the opposite. Government policies have served to cripple the oil producers, whose exploration efforts are threatened as a consequence. The industry has struggled under adverse economic conditions for a lengthy period of time. It has struggled to maintain its exploration and production efforts at a time of very low average annual oil prices. It has struggled in a hostile macro-economic setting of rising Australian-United States exchange rates on top of depressed prices.

From August 1987 to October 1988 world oil prices fell by 39 per cent. In Australian dollar terms they fell by 47 per cent. Stronger world prices have been offset by the appreciation of the Australian dollar over the past year or so. As a consequence, the vast bulk of the smaller scale producers, such as Santos Ltd, have recorded sales revenue losses of up to 30 per cent in the past year. These problems have been compounded by the high interest rates and rising levels of inflation which have undermined investment strategy, as they have for all businesses in Australia. It is these problems which have led the industry to resort to costly shut-downs which have so far cost the Government $70m in lost export income as well as lost import replacement income. Approximately 65,000 barrels of crude oil production per day were locked in on the Cobia and Flounder fields in Bass Strait between September 1988 and January of this year as it was simply, and understandably, uneconomic to continue production. The Government's proposal to make adjustments to the top rates of marginal excise at that time in order to retain a continued revenue flow did not expand the capital requirements of the industry, nor meet the deeper problems which bedevil the industry.

In addition to the onerous secondary taxation burden, the industry also labours under an extremely high cost structure which threatens exploration rates. It costs the domestic industry $6m to drill an average depth off-shore well. In the United States the same well costs only $1 1/2m. Similarly, on-shore wells are three times as expensive to drill in Australia than they are in the United States. In addition, labour costs and work practices contribute considerably to the comparative cost disadvantage of oil exploration in Australia. The enormous add-on cost imposed by work practices on the wharves, such as those in the ports of Melbourne and Westernport Bay, as well as the ineffective industrial system, which is meant to regulate union conduct, have stifled the productivity of the oil production industry.

Recently we have witnessed the multimillion dollar losses incurred by Esso-BHP as a result of work bans by wharf linesmen who earn $60 an hour. The strike action cost the industry between $10m and $15m. In another case in recent weeks the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union brought work on a construction barge in Bass Strait to a standstill while it negotiated, in breach of its agreements, a $7,000 lump sum payment for five casual welders who had been employed-wait for it-for only 11 days. Eleven days work is involved and the union thinks that those men are entitled to a $7,000 lump sum payment. That strike cost the joint operators over $4m. The industry is calling out for micro-economic reform: reform of work practices, reform of the industrial relation system as well as reform of the sheltered coastal shipping system, all of which threaten the long term viability of local producers. The impact of these problems for the continuation of domestic exploration efforts by the oil industry is already in evidence.

Let me summarise. This Government is abdicating its responsibilities in regard to oil self-sufficiency. It is a matter almost of bewilderment that it fails to take note of the looming disaster for this country by the end of the century. Time will pass quickly and by 1998 we will find ourselves producing only 28 per cent of our oil needs. We will require at least $5 1/2 billion in import costs to make up the remaining 78 per cent. Unless the Government fundamentally restructures its tax regime in regard to the oil industry there will not be any further or any successful exploration for oil, either onshore or offshore. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the view that fees and securities to be set by regulation in respect of petroleum exploration activities should never exceed the relevant minimum administrative costs incurred by the Commonwealth, the States or the Northern Territory in carrying out their respective obligations under the legislation'.
This amendment is designed to ensure that the Government does not set fees for petroleum exploration that exceed administrative costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sharp

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.
