PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am introducing the Bill pursuant to the Commonwealth's obligations under the cooperative companies and securities scheme. A detailed description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. For the benefit of honourable members, I will explain the role of this Bill in the context of the Commonwealth's own proposals to regulate companies and the securities and futures industries in Australia.

The introduction of this Bill in no way diminishes the Government's commitment to the passage and early implementation of the national corporations legislation. That legislation was passed by the House of Representatives in September last year and was introduced into the Senate on 14 October 1988. With the Government's support the legislation was referred to a Joint select committee of Parliament, which has been giving detailed consideration to the legislation in the light of comments from the public. The committee's report will be tabled in this Parliament shortly. The Government will be moving to give the report full consideration as a matter of the highest priority to enable the debate to proceed in the Senate on the Bills at an early stage. The Government is concerned to avoid any confusion or uncertainty which may occur through delay in proceeding with the Commonwealth's proposals.

In the meantime, the Government has indicated its commitment to amending the existing cooperative scheme legislation in accordance with decisions of the Ministerial Council. It is important that the existing scheme of regulation, including provisions for the protection of investors, be maintained pending the commencement of the national legislation. The Bill I am introducing today represents part of that commitment. In accordance with the formal agreement governing the cooperative scheme, this Bill has been agreed to by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. If passed by this Parliament the Bill will, in addition to altering the law of the Australian Capital Territory, have the effect of automatically amending the corresponding legislation of the States and the Northern Territory.
Outline of Proposals

The Bill contains provisions which will enable a company to repurchase its own shares in certain circumstances. The Ministerial Council released an exposure draft Bill in relation to this proposal in September 1988. Many valuable comments were made in submissions received from the public on the exposure draft Bill. The Ministerial Council responded to the public comments by making a number of significant amendments to the proposals. The Ministerial Council is now satisfied that the buy-back provisions in this Bill will enable companies to purchase their own shares without compromising the interests of shareholders and creditors. The Government will be giving consideration to the inclusion of corresponding amendments on buy-backs in the Corporations Bill after that Bill is passed by the Parliament.

The Bill also includes important deregulatory proposals that are adopted from the national Corporations Bill. The licensing of representatives of securities and futures dealers and advisers will be discontinued as provided in the Corporations Bill. At the same time, securities and futures dealers and advisers will be given increased responsibility for the conduct of their representatives. Provisions have also been included to remove existing delays in the transfer and registration of securities occasioned by unnecessary procedures. The Bill gives legislative support for the pilot testing by the Australian Stock Exchange of a new share transfer and registration system known as the flexible accelerated security transfer system, or FAST.

Other provisions in the Bill enable the inspection of computer generated documents and resolve problems experienced by the corporate affairs commissions with the retrieval of information in annual returns. Importantly, the Bill contains the legislative basis for the new proposal to give the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) additional funding and support from the 1989-90 financial year. The Bill will enable charges to be made for the performance of certain functions by the NCSC and State corporate affairs commissions which more accurately reflect the actual resources devoted to those functions. I will now outline in greater detail some of the features of the Bill.
Share Buy-backs

The reforms contained in this Bill which give companies a power to buy back their shares have their genesis in the report of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee entitled A Company's Purchase of its own Shares, published in September 1987. The Australian business community has strongly argued for the removal of the current statutory prohibition on share buy-backs contained in section 129 of the Companies Act 1981 and for the introduction of a regime which permits greater flexibility in the arrangement of a company's capital structure, in line with procedures available under the law of other major overseas commercial centres such as the United States and the United Kingdom.

In the development of these proposals, the Ministerial Council has been particularly concerned to ensure that shareholders and creditors are not exposed to some forms of abuse of share buy-back procedures which have been experienced in overseas jurisdictions. The exposure draft Bill attracted substantial comment from the business community which was taken into account by the Ministerial Council in reaching a settled position on the provisions in this Bill.

Because of this concern about possible abuse and because buy-backs are difficult activities to regulate, public companies generally have been confined to an aggregate 10 per cent annual limit on the amount of the share capital that can be reclaimed in any of the following ways:
(i) Pari passu offers to shareholders on a proportional basis;

(ii) Selective purchases approved by a resolution of 75 per cent of the shareholders of the company, excluding the vendor shareholder, with an expert's opinion that the price is fair and reasonable; and
(iii) On-market purchases regulated by Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) listing rules.

Strong representations were received supporting the use of on-market purchases and the Ministerial Council has decided to include provisions in the Bill allowing that method of self-purchase. The provisions will not be proclaimed until the ASX, in consultation with the NCSC, has devised listing rules which satisfy the Ministerial Council that shareholders will be given appropriate protection.

The Ministerial Council has been concerned about the use of interposed companies and cross-shareholdings to achieve `indirect' buy-backs. The Bill contains provisions to regulate such arrangements to ensure that they are not used to circumvent the buy-back provisions. At the same time, the Ministerial Council has responded to the concerns expressed by the business community that cross-shareholdings can be a common and legitimate commercial relationship between companies. Both concerns have been met in this Bill. Under the Bill, in addition to the procedures described above, companies will be permitted to hold a 10 per cent indirect interest in their own shares through cross-shareholding arrangements. However, over the 10 per cent threshold, it will be open to the NCSC to examine all the relevant factors of a particular arrangement and to intervene if it considers the cross-shareholding transaction is unacceptable. The Bill sets out the criteria for NCSC intervention.

In response to submissions from business, the financial assistance validation procedure in section 129 (10) of the Companies Act will be retained to permit legitimate commercial usage. specific anti-avoidance provisions will be inserted to prevent the use of section 129 (10) for `backdoor' buy-backs. The Bill provides that the section 129 (10) validation procedure cannot operate if it os used for the purpose of avoiding the buy-back provisions of the Bill.
FAST and Licensing of Investment Advisers

As mentioned above, the amendments to the Securities Industry Act 1980 relating to the simplification of the share transfer system-FAST-and the reform of the licensing system, adopt the corresponding initiatives that are presently contained in the Commonwealth's Corporations Bill. The FAST system will allow shares to be transferred without share certificates and without transfer signatures thus reducing the amount of paperwork and procedural steps in the share transfer process. At the same time, the protection already afforded investors by the national guarantee fund will be reinforced by extending protection to shareholders for any losses arising from unauthorised transfers. A limited number of companies representing a range of large and small listed companies will participate in a pilot scheme to be run by the Australian Stock Exchange. If successful, the pilot scheme is expected to lead to the full operation of FAST. The provisions facilitating the pilot scheme were exposed for public comment in December 1988. The provisions contained in this Bill have been slightly modified following public submissions and further discussions with the Australian Stock Exchange and representatives of the business community. The companies participating in the pilot scheme are to be commended for their willingness to participate in a somewhat costly program. If the pilot scheme is successful, the entire Australian community will benefit from a streamlined system for the transfer of securities.

The Bill also introduces reforms to the existing securities and futures industry licensing systems that have been adopted from the Corporations Bill. The licensing of representatives of securities dealers and advisers and of futures brokers and advisers will be discontinued. To ensure that proper responsibility is taken for the activities of their representatives, dealers, brokers and advisers will be made more fully liable for the conduct of persons who are, in fact, their representatives. Securities dealers and advisers and futures brokers and advisers will still require a licence. The Bill, like the national corporations legislation, contains additional sanctions against persons who act as dealers, brokers or advisers without obtaining a licence. The Bill will enable clients of such persons to rescind agreements made with the unlicensed person, provided third party rights are not adversely affected, and to recover any commission paid to the unlicensed person. In addition, the NCSC will be given power to ban undesirable persons from acting as participants in the securities or futures industries.
Computerisation

Presently, the public searching of Corporate Affairs Commission records takes place by manual inspection of original documents or microfiche transparencies of those documents. The Bill contains amendments to enable the use of computer-generated documents, or the display of information on a visual display unit, to satisfy most, if not all, company searches. In conjunction with this proposal, it is proposed that, to save administrative costs, microfiche transparencies and original documents will no longer be made available for inspection. Section 31 of the Companies Act will be amended to give effect to this decision, which does not affect a person's right to obtain a certified copy of a document. A new section 31a will also be included in the Companies Act to clarify the rights of a person to inspect registers maintained by the Commission. At present the Act does not expressly provide that a person may inspect or search those registers.
Annual Return

In 1985 the Companies Act was amended to enable the NCSC to partly complete the annual return of a company using information kept on computer. The partly completed annual return would then be served on the company, which was expected to complete it and lodge it with the NCSC. Experience has shown that as many as 40 per cent of companies have preferred to disregard the returns served on them by the NCSC and, instead, prepare returns using their own computer or word processing facilities. The processing of such returns has caused problems for the NSCS-mainly because information is presented in a different format from that used by the NCSC-and it is proposed that section 263 be amended to require companies to complete the annual return served on them by the NCSC.
Funding of National Companies and Securities Commission

The Ministerial Council decided at its meeting on 2 March 1989 that the very necessary additional resources required by the NCSC should be funded through revised or increased fees in those areas where the actual cost of performing certain functions is not met by the fees presently able to be charged for those functions. For example, the current maximum fee chargeable for labour intensive functions such as the registration of prospectuses and take-over documents and the granting of applications for exemption from requirements is $1,000. The decision included targeting those parts of the business community that are the principal `users' of NCSC services, and imposing additional fees on the annual returns of listed corporations and on licence holders in the securities and futures industries.

The amendments to the various cooperative scheme Fees Acts contained in this Bill will give effect to the decision of the Ministerial Council. The amendments to the various Fees Acts will permit the making of regulations prescribing the revised fees. The major changes include:
increasing the maximum amount that can be prescribed to $5,000;
enabling fees to be prescribed in terms other than monetary amounts-for example, percentages;
permitting more than one fee to be prescribed in respect of each matter;
imposing a limit of $25,000 on the size of the fee that can be charged for any one matter;
allowing the Commission to require payment of a deposit when the amount of a fee cannot be ascertained prior to carrying out the function; and
giving a power to prescribe a fee for supplying, or for other parties accessing, information kept on the Commission's computer.

Not all the increased fees will necessarily be directly related to the actual service provided. For example, a prospectus registration fee may be based on a proportion of the amount to be raised or an annual return fee may be based on the capitalisation of a listed corporation. Thus the amendments recognise there may be a taxation component to the fee. In accordance with usual Commonwealth parliamentary practice, the authority for imposing that part of any fee which includes an element of a tax will be contained in separate `fees: taxation component' Bills under each of the principal pieces of scheme legislation.
Other Amendments

The Bill amends a number of other provisions in the Companies Act and makes extensive amendments to the Fees Act for each of the substantive pieces of cooperative scheme legislation. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and the four associated fees taxation component Bills.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIMITATION OF LIABILITY FOR MARITIME CLAIMS BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Bill will greatly increase the amount of compensation available to victims of a maritime accident. Australia is currently party to the International Convention relating to the Limitation of the Liability of Owners of Seagoing Ships, 1957 and its 1979 Protocol. The Convention and Protocol, which are implemented by part VIIIa of the Navigation Act 1912, establish upper limits for claims arising from a maritime incident in which loss of life, personal injury or property damage occurs. In response to widespread concern that the limits set by the 1957 Convention were too low, in 1976 a diplomatic conference adopted the Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims. This Convention entered into force internationally on 1 December 1986. Sixteen countries are now party to the Convention, including the United Kingdom, Japan, Liberia, the Scandinavian countries, France and the Federal Republic of Germany.

The Bill will enable Australia to become a party to the 1976 Convention. The inadequacy of the 1957 Convention is demonstrated by the fact that the total amount of the compensation fund for claims involving an incident to a ship of 10,000 gross tonnage would be only about $3.22m. If there were 193 claimants-the number of people killed in the Herald of Free Enterprise disaster in 1987 in Belgium-the average amount per passenger would be $16,700. The equivalent figures for passenger claims under the 1976 Convention would be $39m and $202,000, a twelvefold increase.

At the seventy-fifth meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council in December 1987, Federal, State and Northern Territory Transport Ministers agreed that Australia should accede to the 1976 Convention. Article 6 of the Convention establishes upper limits for two types of claims: claims for loss of life or personal injury and property claims. These limits are expressed in units of account. A unit of account is the special drawing right of the International Monetary Fund. For personal claims, liability for claims concerning ships with tonnage not exceeding 500 tonnes is limited to 333,000 units of account, or about $520,000. For larger ships, further units of account are added for each tonne in excess of 500, on a sliding scale. Therefore, the limit for a ship of 10,000 gross tonnage would be 3,914,000 units of account or about $6.1m.

For property claims-that is, claims such as for damage to other ships, property or harbour works-the system of determining the upper limit is similar. The limit for a ship of 500 gross tonnage is 167,000 units of account or about $260,000; for a ship of 10,000 gross tonnage it is 1,753,500 units of account or about $2.7m. On top of this, article 7 of the 1976 Convention provides for the establishment of a separate fund for loss of life or personal injury to passengers. Here the shipowner's liability is limited to 46,666 units of account multiplied by the number of passengers the ship's certificate authorises it to carry to a maxiumum of 25 million units of account. Therefore, the maximum compensation available to passengers on the Abel Tasman would be about $39m. As a trade-off for the vastly increased amounts of compensation available, the Convention provides for a virtually unbreakable system of limiting liability. It declares that a person will be deprived of his ability to limit liability only if it is proved that the loss resulted from his personal act or omission, committed with the intent to cause such a loss, or recklessly and with knowledge that such loss would probably result.

There are several other issues I should mention. First, unlike the 1957 Convention, the 1976 Convention does not permit State parties to exclude damage to harbour works, basins and waterways and aids to navigation from liability. However, parties are permitted to give such claims priority over other property claims in their national law. The Bill includes such a provision. Secondly, the Convention provides that a State party may regulate the system of limitation of liability to apply to ships intended for navigation on inland waterways or which are less than 300 gross tonnage. The Bill is to apply to all seagoing ships, of whatever size. The Bill also contains a savings clause, which will permit any valid State or Northern Territory law which may be passed to apply the Convention's provisions to ships coming within the legislative competence of that State or Territory to the exclusion of Commonwealth law. Thirdly, the Bill provides for the exclusion of limitation for claims in respect of salvage or wreck removal.

Finally, I would mention that the Bill provides for commencement on a day to be fixed by proclamation. This is necessary to allow for Australia's accession to the 1976 Convention and denunciation of the 1957 Convention and 1979 Protocol to coincide with the commencement of the Act. When this Bill receives royal assent, the process for denunciation of the Convention and Protocol will be initiated. As the denunciation becomes effective one year after lodgment of the instrument with the depositary, I anticipate that this Bill will be proclaimed in the second half of 1990. The Bill therefore provides for proclamation to take place within 18 months of royal assent. I commend the Bill to the House. I understand that the explanatory memorandum has been delayed as a result of some printing problem. It will be circulated as soon as it is available.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments proposed by the Government and to reject the amendment moved by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). In this debate I wish to cover a couple of subjects in relation to this omnibus Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. The first issue I wish to raise is in relation to the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987. That Act, of course, gives the grantee of those rights the sole right to propagate and sell plants and reproductive material. However, it does not stop someone else from propagating the variety if he or she is going to sell the product of the plant, that is, fruit, cut flowers or grain but not the plants.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment gives the breeder sole right to asexually propagate, or license others to asexually propagate, the variety for the commercial production of cut flowers, fruit and other products. Overseas countries and the International Union for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants (UPOV) Convention have included similar provisions in the plant variety rights (PVR) legislation.

Several issues have been raised in relation to this amendment. The amendment itself is widely supported. There has been opposition from some consumer groups and groups opposed to PVR from its inception. The issues they have raised are not specifically related to this amendment and have already been examined by the Senate inquiry and the Lazenby Committee. There is no intention to cover sale of product. This will continue to be safeguarded by subsections 38 (1) (b) and (c). Civil liberties are protected by the consumer protection provisions in section 39 of the PVR Act and subsection 12 (3) of the amendment. The PVR Act does not apply to people who propagate and grow varieties in their own gardens for their own use, which is something we have heard much about for many years in the run up to the Plant Variety Rights legislation. It does not do that. If someone unwittingly sells a protected variety, for example at a fete, subsection 43 (3) of the Act protects him from liability for damages.

Without the amendment, breeders are putting a high price on the few plants they sell to the growers and the growers are trying to recover this up-front cost quickly before others gain access to the variety. Restricting the amendment to ornamentals is not justified as the development of, and access to, new horticultural varieties is important to Australian primary industry.

Other sections of the omnibus Bill relate to the dairy industry. We have heard comments from the Opposition in relation to that issue. The Act imposes levies on producers to provide funds for various reasons. The Dairy Produce Act 1986 provides for this liability to be passed onto purchasers of milk in line with industry practice. The Act imposes a penalty of 20 per cent per annum on those who do not pay the Commonwealth the milk fat levies when they become due.

However, the current provisions, sections 62 and 63 of the Act, are not precise enough to ensure that all purchasers, including State milk authorities, are liable for the late payment penalty, as was intended by the Act. Such a situation arose when the New South Wales Dairy Corporation refused to pay the levy on behalf of New South Wales producers during the interstate milk war with Victoria in 1987. Whilst the levy was eventually paid, the penalty was not. This debt to the Commonwealth was remitted by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) on the basis of legal advice that recovery might not be successful, given the imprecise wording of the Act.

The amendment does not represent a change in existing policy. It merely clarifies the original intention of the Act that all persons responsible for paying the milk fat levies should also be liable to a penalty should they fail to pay the levies by the due date. The Minister retains the right, under section 67 of the Act, to remit the penalty where its imposition would prove to be anomalous or inequitable. There are no pending recovery actions awaiting the passage of the amending legislation. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference (ADIC), which includes the New South Wales dairy industry, supports the proposed amendments.

While I am talking about the Dairy Produce Act 1986, it is of interest to look at what has occurred with the Kerin plan in relation to the dairy industry, a very important industry in my electorate of McMillan. It is also an important industry in the electorate of the honourable member for Gippsland, who today talked about the energy side of things and Bass Strait oil. In relation to the dairy industry, I would like to put a quote on record today from one of my local newspapers. This newspaper is produced in an area where, three years ago, when we were attempting to introduce these deregulatory reforms to the dairy industry, there was a very large meeting at Warragul, which was attended by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and by me. We were there to put the case on behalf of the Government. Many supporters of the Opposition parties, particularly the National Party, were present. They were doing their very best to destroy and break down those reforms which were coming forward. They even went to the extent of kicking in the side of the Minister's car as he attempted to leave the area. It was very heartening to see, on the front page of the local newspaper, the Warragul Gazette, this week a report by the manager of Allowrie's Drouin company, a company which has developed a factory in that area and has taken over one of the old cooperatives. The article reads as follows:
The dairy industry is performing well bringing good times to both farmers and the wider community, according to Allowrie's Drouin manager, Dale Thompson.
Mr Thompson made the comments yesterday while announcing a company price step up for farmers of 10 cents a kilogram.
He said the price would be paid on all manufactured milk supplied for the period July 1988 to the end of June 1989.

`In line with the company's policy of paying the highest possible price up front, payment of the step up will be paid immediately and included with suppliers returns for March 1989 and paid on April 15,' Mr Thompson said.
Mr Thompson said the overall industry was looking better than it was a year ago, with his company now paying prices about 30 per cent higher than at the same time last year.
That is further evidence that this Government's policies in relation to deregulation in that industry, and the efforts it has put into it, are certainly paying off. Mr Thompson went on to say:
`It all helps to put the price up in the domestic market . . .

`The season is only in April and we would expect our price to be in the order of $6.00 by the end of the year,' he said. Current price is $4.96 kg. Mr Thompson said the higher prices now being paid by suppliers was also helping local communities through flow on effects.
Farmers were making capital and other improvements to their properties, buying new equipment and servicing loans which all helped with the local money supply, he said.

It is very heartening to be able to stand in this House and report something like that to the Parliament, when one considers that our opponents on the Opposition benches, who for so long had the opportunity to make those deregulatory changes in those industries, failed to do so. They are still failing to produce policies anything like the deregulated approach sensibly put into place by this Government.

I listened intently to the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Gippsland, speaking about Bass Strait oil and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act and related subsidiary Acts. He talked strongly about the need to develop further wells in Bass Strait and the need to produce our own oil here in Australia. I agree with him, in that there is a great need for us to remain as self-sufficient in oil as we possibly can. He and I share a boundary between our electorates and we both have the same coastline, the Gippsland coast in Bass Strait, where the great bulk of Australia's oil is produced. That oil has been a boon to Australia for many years. Under the regulations imposed by previous governments, not by this Government, there has been oil production for a long time in Bass Strait. Australia has been able to reap the wealth of that oil, which has been produced very cheaply. Levies and excises have been imposed upon that oil production, to the extent that we have been able to have a very good road building program in this country. In fact the amount of money that has been produced from that area has been very significant in the development of our nation over the years. Current low world petrol and oil prices are good for Australia, but not to the extent that those prices can make it profitable for many exploration companies to drill lots of wells. That has to be taken into consideration. We will not be able to rely on oil from Bass Strait in the quantities we have been used to. As the honourable member for Gippsland said, there will be a reduction in the amount of oil that will be coming from there, and there is a need in Australia for the development of drilling and penetration into other areas in the search for oil.

It gives me great pleasure today to support these omnibus amendments made by the Government. They tidy up measures in relation to many of the Acts that have been put in place by the Government. They revise and improve upon the policies that the Government has in place. I look forward to the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tonight, when we will clearly be able to see the benefits of a hard row of five years of putting Australia back on its feet following the Government's inheritance of a substantial mess created by past Budget policies in Australia, coupled with a collapse in commodity prices during the last five years.

As an article in my local newspaper said, we are now seeing an improvement in the rural sector. That improvement is feeding through to the rest of the community, and we look forward to tonight, when not just the rural sector will share in that improvement in income; some of it will be available to others in the nation who have also tightened their belts over the last four or five years to assist the economy of Australia. With those comments I support the amendments being made by the Government. I reject the amendment put forward by the honourable member for Gippsland.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRADE PRACTICES (INTERNATIONAL LINER CARGO SHIPPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices (International Liner Cargo Shipping) Amendment Bill is an extremely complex and specialised Bill. It deals with trade practices legislation as it applies to what are colloquially known as shipping conferences. The Opposition will not oppose this legislation, although we will comment upon some aspects of it and will move a second reading amendment which draws attention to the failure of the Government to achieve any worthwhile progress in the area of micro-economic reform as it affects transport.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is about not only liner conferences, but also the Labor Government's in- ability to make tough decisions about the future of Australia's transport systems. This Bill, intended to make international liner cargo shipping more competitive, has been sitting around on the drawing boards and drafting tables of this Government since 1984. It should be held up as a symbol of the Government's inability to seriously pursue a program of structural reform. The very fact that it has taken that long to get the Bill to the House, and it is in such a condition now it is here, indicates the Government's capacity to address these issues. As I said, the Bill has come to this place late, and does not do all the things it could or should do to make international liner cargo shipping more competitive. It has been badly drafted, and I believe that later on in this debate we will see a series of Government amendments.

The Government's rhetoric on micro- economic reform is really so many hollow words. Following the 1987 election the Treasurer (Mr Keating) took control of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) from Senator Button, and proclaimed that micro-economic reform would be the main game for the Hawke Government's third term of office. In macro-economic policy the Government has addressed questions relating to the banking and financial system, as well as the Australian dollar. These measures have exposed Australia to greater international competition and, in so doing, forced Australian business to compete internationally. The economy has benefited greatly from some of these policies, but most were introduced during the first two years of the Hawke Government's six years in office. Since then the Government has rested on its laurels and done precious little.

The Government has failed to maintain the momentum of economic reform at a time when it is vitally important that the structure of Australian industry change so that we can maintain our international economic position and our relative wealth. Anyone who is aware of the complaints of the Australian electorate at the present time will understand that our relative wealth is not being maintained and that, in fact, we are facing significant declines in real living standards. That is very much the responsibility of the Government for not addressing the problem and acting to minimise the impact of changing world circumstances on Australia and its people.

This Government, which is big on micro-economic reform rhetoric, has baulked and stumbled on restructuring the Australian economy when it has been confronted with broader inefficiencies. The most outstanding failure is the absence of reform in our transport systems. The Government has had a number of reports from the IAC and the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) identifying inefficiencies in rail, international shipping, ports, the waterfront and coastal shipping. Even last week we saw the latest report on coastal shipping from the Inter-State Commission. The immediate reaction from the unions was to veto the report and indicate that they would have nothing to do with it. Our friend Mr Kelty from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) was supportive. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told the unions, `Don't worry about it, fellows. It is going to be pigeonholed'. We have even seen a member of this place from South Australia call on the Government to do nothing about the Inter-State Commission report. The dumping of the report shows the Government's attitude. It took two years of study and heaven only knows what it cost to produce. Regardless of the effort that was put into it by the people who work for the Commission and those in both sides of the industry, the Government has dumped the report because the trade unions did not like it, notwithstanding the cost of waterfront inefficiency to the entire Australian economy.

The IAC recently calculated that reforms in these areas could produce savings of approximately $3.2 billion in transport costs which would, in turn, increase Australia's gross domestic product by 2.3 per cent or $6 billion. By simply addressing the question of micro-economic reform we could achieve an increase in gross domestic product of 2.3 per cent or add to our total production in this country some $6 billion. That is a lot of money which would have a big impact on the relative standard of living of Australians.

Progress on implementing these reforms has been slow. That is an extremely generous description, as I would say that progress has been non-existent. The Government has dropped its plans to include, in tonight's statement from the Treasurer, a progress report on its micro-economic reforms simply because it has nothing to say. The only piece of legislation to which it could allude would be the one we are debating here which, as I have said, is flawed and will be amended at the committee stage.

In terms of the big picture which the Treasurer talks about so fondly from time to time, this is probably not even the artist's signature on the bottom right hand corner. The Treasurer will be giving tax cuts in his economic statement tonight, we are told, no doubt as a lead-up to an early election, but the fact remains that a 3 per cent tax cut could very easily come about if the Government lived up to its commitment to reform transport. The Government has neither the political courage nor the capacity to address these issues and to carry out its micro-economic reform. It will take an expedient approach, an economically irresponsible approach, and seek to buy votes in the most economically detrimental way possible-by simply giving tax cuts when the economy is in trouble.

I do not think that anyone who is in any way informed about the economic debate would deny the fact that our economy is in trouble. I refer anyone who wishes to debate this to those little summaries under the heading of `State of the Nation' which appear in some of the popular newspapers from time to time and ask him or her to consider the level of interest rates, our balance of payments deficit, the rate of inflation, the trend in inflation and the trend in unemployment. That person will come to the conclusion that Australia's economy is in trouble. The only people who are responsible for that are those who sit on the other side of the chamber. Although Government members would like to deny it, they have been governing this country for some six years. If one makes one's bed, one has to lie in it. Australia today is very much the product of the Hawke Labor Government and `the world's greatest Treasurer'-Mr Keating.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has noted that those nations which have pursued micro-economic reform have the best productivity performances and that has consequently led to higher real wages and higher profits. One of the real issues in the political debate today is the real level of wages in this country and the real standard of living. The OECD is pointing out that had this Government addressed those issues, achieved micro-economic reform and reaped the benefits that have been pointed to by the Industries Assistance Commission and the Economic Planning Advisory Council in terms of cost savings and growth in gross domestic product, there would have been a substantial increase in the real standard of living of all Australians.

The current account deficit has reached $11 billion for the first eight months of 1988-89. That is a 35 per cent deterioration on the same period last year. This deterioration has occurred despite an improvement of some 15 per cent in our terms of trade. The improvement in our terms of trade has little to do with government policy; it relates to international demand for products. It is the result of rises in world prices for agricultural and mineral commodities which, of course, are significant exports for Australia-they comprise about 70 per cent of our export earnings. Although Australia currently basks in record prices for most of its commodity exports it has not given a thought to the micro-economic reforms that are needed to sustain us through the 1990s. The Government seems to think, like Micawber, that something will turn up. It has squandered the opportunity presented by the commodity boom to address the structural problems in our economy.

The Treasurer's attitude is that everything is on track. The reality is that everything is not on track. Australia would be an economic basket case if it were not for the international boom in commodity prices. This boom has enabled the Government to pursue an ostrich policy on economic reform because such reform is just too hard for it to face. It means coming to grips, face to face, with its friends in the trade union movement and telling them in some particular industries that no-one has a place in the sun; that everyone has to work for a living and that one section of the trade union movement-and I cite particularly the waterfront and coastal shipping-has to work as hard for its income as any other section of that movement; that work practices must be addressed in all sections of the labour force; that they cannot just concentrate on the easy areas and ignore the hard ones because in ignoring the hard ones they will let the opportunity for maximum progress go by.

This is the time when this Government should be boosting production by reforming the economy and reforming labour markets. It should especially reform the transport sector. It should not wait until commodity prices drop. It should not wait for another seven lean years. It is amazing that a government, motivated by such blatantly political considerations, could let slip the opportunity to address a significant problem. This country now has a monthly current account deficit of $1,500m. This has occurred when things are good. What will be the size of that deficit if our trading position declines, there is a world recession and the demand for our primary products and mineral exports declines? What will our current account deficit be like in those circumstances?

Inflation is rising well beyond that of our major trading partners and interest rates are crippling. In fact, the interest bill for a small business has gone up about 30 per cent as a result of this Government's excessive concentration on monetary policies and the dollar is reaching the point of being uncompetitively high. The Treasurer tells us that interest rates could rise even more. Today in this place the Prime Minister was reluctant to be drawn on that question and I believe that he showed some embarrassment when reminded of his promise at the time of the Western Australian State election that interest rates would fall. Since then they have gone in only one direction-and that is straight up. Most of the financial community agrees that interest rates are likely to continue to rise for the foreseeable future, that there is no respite in sight for hard-pressed home buyers, small business or business in general. That, of course, affects the ability of the Australian economy to compete. If one is in competition with business overseas and one's interest rate costs are considerably higher than theirs, one will have problems. If one is considering going into a joint venture arrangement with, say, the Japanese in Australia and the cost of one's funds is 17, 18, 19 or even 20 per cent while the cost of funds to the foreign joint venturer is in single figures, one's ability to be an equal partner and contribute the necessary capital to maintain equity in that joint venture is that much diminished. The Government understands that but it is just not prepared to address the issue.

Australia is in the unique situation of demanding that its farmers and other exporters compete with the subsidised lunacy of the world market. I know that the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding), who is at the table, shares my views that this is subsidised lunacy. At the same time it insists that the farmers use inefficient ports, inefficient rail systems, inefficient handling and processing sectors. All the while these farmers must pay heavy taxes on machinery in terms of tariffs, fuel-and taxes on fuel continue to rise-spare parts, steel and fertiliser. It is hardly a level playing field; it is exploiting the capacity of an industry to adjust; it is unfairly placing more pressure for adjustment on one sector of the economy than another. If Australia aspires to healthy economic progress in the 1990s it must begin supporting the exporters and the way to do that is to introduce the micro-economic reform that everybody, including this Government and the more rational members of its Ministry, knows that we desperately need to achieve.

All the waterside and shipping rorts are possible because the Government has eliminated competition in these industries. Thus some shipping and stevedoring companies have been able to pass excess costs on to their business customers-that is, the shippers-and the costs are then passed on to taxpayers through lost export earnings. In other areas of the transport sector, the Government has failed to act. Increasing levels of tourism and consequently competition among international and domestic airlines is leading to the expansion of airline fleets. This year it is expected that Australia's airlines will spend $2 billion on new aircraft and associated costs in a move to meet the projected growth rates of the 1990s. By far the biggest buyer of new aircraft will be the national carrier, Qantas Airways Ltd, which has on order six new Boeing 747-400s and a Boeing 767-300. All those aircraft are due for delivery this calendar year. The approximate cost of the aircraft and associated equipment and spares is $1.62 billion. That represents a cost of $1.62 billion on Australia's current account deficit for this year. That amount would not be there if Qantas were allowed more flexibility and independence in determining and implementing its commercial and financial strategies.

One of the simplest things this Government could do in terms of reforming the transport sector would be to move to address the capital inadequacies of its own airlines. There is a desperate need to provide extra capital for both Qantas and Australian Airlines but the Government cannot even address such a simple issue. Some sections of the Government know that now is the time to privatise the airlines, to float the capital, to extract the maximum share premium and to minimise the cost of capital to the airlines, but because of the objections of a section of the left wing of the Labor Party, nothing has been done. I alluded earlier to the estimated cost of transport inefficiencies. A recent Business Council of Australia (BCA) report on transport showed that reform would result in gross domestic product rising by some $6 billion or 2.3 per cent. The flow-on effect would be a rise in real consumption of 2 per cent; that is, an increase of 2 per cent in our standards of living. Employment would rise by 17,000 new jobs.

This Government prides itself on talking about its success in job creation, but today we saw an example of the truth of that claim. Most of the growth in employment in this country is a function of the growth in the population. The Minister for the Arts and Territories was generous enough to acknowledge that in his response to a question we put. Not only would there be 17,000 new jobs created, but investment would grow by some 4 per cent, real wages would rise by 2.5 per cent and the Government's surplus could increase by over $1 billion, which could be taken over the longer term as a 3 per cent cut in income tax. This is what the Government is making the Australian public forgo simply because it will not address the issues of reform in transport.

In terms of this Government's credentials in deregulation, it is interesting to examine the case of Qantas. In the Government's reform package of May last year, an exercise similar to that to which the House is about to be treated tonight, the Government proposed further controls on Qantas-this is a deregulatory government-in particular in relation to industrial relations coordination, financial targets and the appointment of the company's chief executive. Since the 1984 guidelines for Qantas were agreed between the Qantas board and the then Minister for Transport, Qantas has been under the onerous terms of Loan Council control. Yet the Government has continued to claim responsibility for improving Qantas's flexibility and its ability to compete effectively. The Government has imposed the Loan Council on Qantas and restricted its ability to raise capital, forced it to rely on borrowings, and forced it to sell aircraft and lease them back, yet the Government keeps claiming-without any justification-that it has increased the airline's flexibility and its competitive capacity. I suggest that what has happened is the reverse.

The Government's interference in Qantas's affairs has placed very serious impediments on the airline's flexibility and competitiveness. Qantas is suffering under the ineptitude of this Government to undertake the privatisation policy it came to government with. We know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer are in favour of privatisation. Qantas has, in essence, been hijacked by the left wing of the Labor Party, which already holds this Government hostage because of its commitment to irrational and totally outmoded economic concepts and ideas. What afflicts Qantas and Australian Airlines also is the economic terrorism of a political minority that wields more power that its actual numbers should allow in a truly free and open society. If the Government is serious about micro-economic reform, and in particular about making Qantas flexible and competitive, it should immediately begin the privatisation of the airline, making its stock available to its employees and the Australian public. I would invite the Government to consider the Opposition's policy on this if it is bereft of ideas as to how to go about it.

It is instructive to examine the comments that have been made by the Chairman of Australian Airlines. Last year the Chairman of the airline, Mr Ted Harris-who is an eminent Australian, well known to the Prime Minister-recommended to this Government that it either inject some $240m into Australian Airlines over the next three years or seek private capital for the airline. The Government has chosen to ignore the comments of the Chairman and to do nothing. Of course, that will begin to show in time and it may have had some impact on the decision of the managing director to seek employment elsewhere. It will undoubtedly have an impact on the ability of the Government to attract the replacement chief executive officer. I was talking about what Mr Harris said. Let us see exactly what he said:

Full or partial ownership would need to be contemplated if the Government is not prepared to further invest in Australian or is not prepared to lift Government controls which inhibit managerial flexibility and effectiveness.

I emphasise the words `to lift Government controls which inhibit managerial flexibility and effectiveness'. Importantly, those were the very words that were used in a report on Australian Airlines by an advisory group that included a number of Labor Party hopefuls like Mr Kelty and Mr Peter Redlich. The advisory group also included the then head of the Department of Transport and Communications, Dr Peter Wilenski. Significantly, this Government has been unable to follow the advice of the Secretary to the Department of Transport on airline privatisation. It has also been unable to listen to the heads of its airlines, Australian Airlines and Qantas. The words of Mr Harris have of course been echoed by Mr Leslie, the Chairman of Qantas. Nor has the Government been able to listen to the advice of pro-privatisation members of its own party or the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Since the Government has proved deaf to the advice of so many people and organisations, independent ones as well as those from its own camp, we need to ask just who has the ear of this Government and what its excuse is for no action. The answer is frightening, for it is not experts that the Government listens to; it is not economists; it is not departmental heads; it is not the chairman or the directors of the airlines; and it is not the management of the airlines: it is an ideological faction of its own party that even the majority of party members disagree with, but it is a faction with considerable power. It is part of the Labor Party's political trade-off.

No matter what price the Australian community is forced to pay, no matter what price Australian Airlines and Qantas are forced to pay, the Government will pursue its own factional deals and accommodations. It is about time this Government overcame the hysterical approach of the left wing and other internal opponents of privatisation and provided for the privatisation of 100 per cent of Qantas and also addressed the capital needs of Australian Airlines so that they have the necessary funds to enable them to compete effectively in the future. Privatisation of both airlines right now is the most rational and sensible thing to do.

To privatise Australian Airlines after deregulation would be putting into the marketplace an airline with inadequate capitalisation to compete against a very dominant airline in the form of Ansett Airlines of Australia. The Australian Airlines advisory group last year said that the airline will be significantly weakened and commercially untenable once deregulation begins in 1990 if it cannot raise the extra capital it needs and if the Government does not ease the restrictions currently hampering its operations. That is my point exactly. The Government has been given that advice. That advice is accepted around the industry, yet the Government is not prepared to act. What is it trying to do-make sure that Australian Airlines remains the poor relation of the Australian air transport system? It has come down to the issue of either privatise or perish. This is the issue for the airlines, particularly in the case of Qantas. Qantas is under considerable market pressure and the Government just does not seem to recognise its moral obligation, if not its economic obligation, to at least allow the airline to compete with both hands, instead of having one hand, if not both, tied behind its back.

The question of funding the airlines, the question of micro-economic reform, is very much on the political agenda of this country at present. Hence the Bill that is before the House. The only answer that the Government has to micro-economic reform is an outdated, late, badly drafted piece of legislation addressing liner conferences. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) raises his eyebrows and queries why I say the legislation is badly drafted. As late as last Monday night Cabinet was considering whether it would move amendments to this Bill. If Cabinet had been concentrating on this issue, which began in 1984, one would think it would have got the question right and there would be no need for these last-minute amendments. But the consultation process undertaken by the Government has obviously been flawed.

The interests of the conferences have provided both the Government and the Opposition with briefings of their concerns, and some of those concerns have been accommodated in the amendments. The amendments put forward by the conferences have been designed to correct flaws in the legislation. At the committee stage it will be apparent to the House exactly where these flaws are and what superficial treatment the Government gave this legislation, because some of the corrections relate to the definitions of the issues and the matters that the legislation seeks to address. Once again I say that the Bill in itself is not particularly impressive when one remembers the length of time taken in its preparation. As I said at the beginning of my remarks, the Opposition will not be opposing the Bill. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House regrets the fact that the Government has failed to achieve micro-economic reform in the transport sector, a matter of such vital importance to the Australian economy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and urge the Government to take note of the inherent wisdom contained in the amendment.
—Order! That is all that is required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) canvassed a very broad range of issues with some apparent nexus to this legislation and I will respond to some of his points. The first and most fundamental point to make is that it is only since 1983 that there has been any overall framework, any medium to long term view, underpinning a significant and far-reaching structural change in the Australian economy. One can go through a number of areas of significant import in relation to those current and proposed changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is the taxation system. The taxation system has been completely modernised and, in my submission, it puts Australian corporations and business in a much better position to respond to the challenges that they face currently. Personal income tax rates have also been reduced dramatically to boost incentive. Company tax rates have been slashed to match those elsewhere in the world. That factor is most significant and one that, unfortunately, some of our major corporations still tend to ignore when they seek to utilise tax havens around the world to forgo the payment of taxation which Australia has an entitlement to expect. The double taxation of company dividends has been abolished and, as a result, companies can more easily mobilise capital investment. That was an ongoing problem in Australia's postwar period. Tax cheats have finally been brought to account.

Right across the taxation policy spectrum there have been significant changes; indeed, I would submit, unprecedented changes. The end result is that the tax rort industry has been brought to account to a large extent. The tax loopholes and rorts that former governments appeared willing to countenance have been closed. There is now a greater acceptance of a moral dimension to the conduct of the taxation system. When I became a member of parliament in 1983 it was not uncommon to hear from people across all walks of life the argument, `Why should I pay tax when other people, by using technical devices and highly paid lawyers and accountants, avoid paying their fair share of taxation?'. Of course, it was the ordinary pay as you earn income earner who carried the burden. The Government has transformed that unacceptable circumstance to a system where now we have, I believe, one of the most efficient taxation systems in the world and one that takes account of issues such as equity and incentive.

When we talk about macro-economic reforms, we must remember that this country's banking industry has been absolutely transformed to one where very few observers would say other than that there is a very high level of competition. Certainly there are some problems in that sector of the economy, but the competitive forces operating there are leading to the possibility of garnering greater levels of capital. In so doing, they make possible an increased export capacity in Australian industry. Import controls and tariffs have been progressively reduced and, therefore, have opened up Australian industry to the forces of international competition. Australians, if they have learnt nothing over the last few years, certainly understand that attempting to hide our manufacturing sector behind artificial tariff barriers and quotas leads, in the final analysis, to complacency and inefficiencies and, by definition, higher prices to Australian consumers. Specific programs have been adopted for the car industry, the steel industry and the heavy engineering sector to modernise Australia's industrial base, to make it more export orientated.

In the industrial relations arena, the accord has gone a great deal further than simply providing a basis for wage restraint. Of course, it has been described as a state of mind. In national wage cases in 1988 and 1989 the commitments to fundamental reviews of award structures to eliminate restrictive practices, encourage training and multiskilling and develop career paths, will go close to having their culmination in the House this evening. This link provides a vehicle for addressing a wide range of issues designed to improve flexibility and efficiency in the workplace and should be the high water mark in terms of micro-economic reform in this country's postwar period. It is a little hard to listen to Opposition members who have a highly developed sense of criticism. When we reflect on their time in office perhaps they will realise that very few, if any, of those areas were addressed. Some of the problems with which we are grappling currently have been compounded by those years of inactivity and the years of abdication of political and economic leadership in the postwar period, substantially under conservative governments.

Education has been one of the Government's great areas of reform and achievement. There have been massive changes. Retention rates have improved quite dramatically. They are still below those in comparable countries but they are moving very rapidly in the right direction. In my electorate in the western suburbs of Melbourne there has been a dramatic improvement in retention rates. For the first time ever, young working class kids have a realistic prospect of not only going through to complete their secondary education but, increasingly, having the opportunity presented to them to pursue formal tertiary studies. In that context I should take the opportunity of bringing to the House's attention a document put together by me and one of my State parliamentary colleagues in Victoria-a joint submission to the Federal-State working party on higher education in the western region-which canvasses some of the issues. I hope that in the next couple of weeks that will culminate in an in-principle decision to develop a university of technology in the western region of Melbourne.

When the Hawke Labor Government came to office in 1983 there were some compelling statistics. I had the benefit of hearing the many statistics cited by the honourable member for Richmond. It is worth reflecting on the fact that when we came to office the inflation rate was 11 per cent; the unemployment rate was over 10 per cent; and industrial disputation was chronically high, in an ongoing way. There are some instances, such as the contemporary issue of the air traffic controllers which has caused enormous dislocation and has been rightly condemned by government, of industrial disputation nowadays, but in those days there was a chronic and ongoing series of industrial disputes. As a result, Australia was very much at the top of the international comparative industrial disputation list. That situation has been turned absolutely on its head. The level of industrial disputation, with the exception of some isolated events, has decreased quite dramatically. Compared with 11 per cent inflation when we came to office, inflation is now around 7 per cent. An ingredient in that figure is the unprecedented level of house prices. It is open to legitimate debate as to whether and in what form house prices ought to be included in the consumer price index. Obviously, a review in relation to that is under way at the moment.

The unemployment figure in 1983 was well over 10 per cent. If that were discounted for the increased participation rate, that is, the number of women who are now entering the work force and who previously would have been staying at home, the actual unemployment figure would be around 3 per cent, which would go very close to being an Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development record in terms of the turnaround over that period of time. One ought not to underestimate the import of those figures. If we are talking about an employment rate in excess of 10 per cent, that sounds well and good. It is a stark figure, a round figure and a memorable one. The important thing to reflect upon is what that figure means in terms of institutionalised misery. We have all heard of the misery index. We have to go back to the last years of the previous Government to see it reach its high point.

This Government has an unprecedented record in terms of employment creation and employment growth. As I indicated, were that increased participation rate to be removed and were we to compare like with like, we would be comparing a figure of nearly 10 per cent at the end of the Fraser Government with a figure of some 3 per cent today, under the Hawke Labor Government. That, of itself, is one of the most significant records of this Government. In terms of fiscal policy, real Budget outlays-not the rhetoric, but the reality-will fall for the third year in succession. The Federal Budget will be in surplus for the second year in succession, with the public sector borrowing requirement retained at zero.

It needs to be stated that this degree of fiscal discipline is unmatched in the 35 years during which comparable records have been kept. Once again, it is the substitution of decisions and outcomes rather than the rhetoric we hear from the Opposition. It is an embarrassing record if we compare some of those statistics with its period in office. Obviously, domestic demand is now running well above the Budget forecast. That increased level of demand has resulted, of course, in a higher than anticipated import growth, but particularly in the import of capital goods. The Australian Bureau of Statistics private capital expenditure survey that I have available to me reaffirms strong investment growth last year. There is an expectation that that will continue. The survey showed real growth of 10 per cent in 1987-88, expected nominal growth of 17 per cent in 1988-89 and expected nominal growth of 28 per cent in 1989-90.

In the first half of 1988-89 the value of hotel and factory approvals increased by over 50 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year. That is, of course, indicative of a massive increase in investment in our infrastructure. To take one example, the value of hotel approvals obviously is related to the dramatically increased number of tourists coming to this country. It is obviously putting our tourism industry on a footing to ensure that we can maximise our long term returns from that industry.

Factory approvals are up by over 50 per cent. I do not need to remind the House what that means. It clearly means a revival across the spectrum of industry, and, perhaps most importantly, it means a revival in our manufacturing sector. Comparing the first seven months of this financial year with the same period last financial year, we find that imports of transport equipment, excluding road vehicles, rose by some 112 per cent. There was, of course, a blip there caused by the import of civil aircraft. But, even though that figure increased some threefold, obviously that is being done to facilitate the massively increased air traffic levels associated, once again, with the tourism boom. Previously booms in Australia have led to fiscal and wage blow-outs that inevitably not only shatter job opportunities-they usually lead to massive job shedding-but also, by definition, shatter business profitability and confidence.

If we look at the history of Australia, there is an ongoing theme-boom and bust; boom and bust. The boom has as an almost inevitable corollary a wage explosion. The end result of that is that the short term gain of a few extra dollars in the pocket means that inflation levels tend to go through the roof. All the other major economic indices turn nasty, with the end result of business bankruptcies and large scale unemployment. The difference here is that this Government has a wages policy that can get us through those periods of too great demand and has already done so on previous occasions.

The reality is that in the next few weeks and months the existence of a coherent wages policy will ensure that this Government, unlike any-I stress the word `any'-of its predecessors, should be able to ensure that the wage outcome is kept within realistic levels. Tonight, of course, the contribution by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this House will go a long way towards articulating precisely what the Government intends doing in that area. It stands in absolutely stark contrast to the Opposition, which in this crucially important policy area is still yet to put a coherent policy package together. It is my submission that, even were it able to do so, it would be incapable of implementing it because of its attitude to the organised union movement in this country. This time, in addition to fiscal and wage responsibility, the investment surge to which I have referred will create a capacity to help alleviate our balance of payments constraint. In that context, the mistakes of the past, of previous conservative governments, will not be repeated. This Government has a strategy. It is probably the first government in the history of Federation, in a non-wartime context, to have a broad-ranging strategy encompassing those policy areas to which I have adverted.

The Australian economy is being restructured. In 1986-87 and 1987-88 service exports rose in real terms by 9.5 per cent and 13.5 per cent respectively. Over the same years manufactured exports rose by 32.5 per cent and 9.4 per cent respectively. This restructuring is absolutely fundamental. It does not necessarily imply popularity from time to time, but equally it is absolutely essential and it is increasingly understood by Australians to be just that.

The continued program of micro-economic reform, plus our current investment boom and our fiscal and monetary policies, will see growth ease to sustainable levels and should see Australia well placed to deal with the challenges of the future. Across that whole range of policy areas we can be marked out as being quite different from the Opposition. First and foremost, we are prepared. That will become manifest over the next few weeks in relation to the Treasurer's contribution this evening and the subsequent contributions by supporting Ministers during the month of May. Clearly we are prepared to grapple with some of these hard issues. Clearly that is absolutely essential to the future of this country. Until the Opposition is prepared to come into this House with coherent policies and an overall framework, its rhetoric will be treated, as it has been in the past, as just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak on the Trade Practices (International Liner Cargo Shipping) Amendment Bill and the amendment I would like to agree with the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), who said that there was a difference between his side of politics and the coalition parties. To that I would say, `Viva la difference'. May it always be so. On return to government we will have the mammoth task of reversing the trends which we have witnessed under the present Government-a government which has imposed on this country record levels of taxation never before experienced and which could not possibly have been foreseen.

SPEECH.PARA: Commensurate with those record levels of taxation we have seen spending of a degree not foreseeable even as far back as the years of the Fraser Government. Hand in hand with that has gone record trade deficits and balance of payments deficits which will provide a challenge to the incoming Howard Government-one I might assure the House that will be met, but not without some difficulty. On return to government we will maintain the difference between us and the Australian Labor Party and we will set about creating the circumstances in which record levels of interest can be reduced for the benefit of home owners, potential home owners and businesses throughout the land.

The Bill deals with the application of trade practices legislation to the important function of the shipping of goods to and from Australia. It goes without saying that Australia is a significant trading nation and should be more significant in the future. The importance of shipping to that trade is clear, yet Australia is not a great shipping nation. Despite a number of fine harbours and large coastal cities, maritime transport, as it has developed in Australia, has been a burden to the efficiency of Australian trade rather than the comparative advantage which it should represent.

From the earliest days of the Australian colonies a lot of the sea traffic to and from Australia was naval rather than commercial. I have no doubt that this contributed to the development of a waterfront dominated by monopolies and mercantilist style exclusive rights rather than competition and commercial considerations. The spirit of mercantilism still pervades much of the Australian transport industry with special privileges given to government sanctioned carriers of goods such as grains. Also, there are tightly controlled craft unions dominating entry into the industry and excluding competitive labour as well as outdated legislation protecting the whole structure from direct outside competition.

As with much of Australia's protectionist past, these institutions are now being seriously challenged. In the air, the two-airline policy will soon end. On land, the State government enforced monopolies on rail transport are threatened with competition from efficient and competitive road transport. The big question facing government which is raised in this Bill is how the shipping industry, in all its many facets, will respond to the growing necessity for deregulation, lower costs and eventually open competition.

The legislation before the House deals with the consideration of one of the areas of a very complex Australian shipping industry. The conference system is a feature of liner shipping throughout the world. To the extent that these cartel-like conference arrangements can survive without the direct support of government, our legislation should not interfere unduly with those schemes. However, the Government should not actively support or protect these arrangements through the extension of privileges which are not universally available.

The legislation offers a partial withdrawal of the special position enjoyed by liner conferences which maintains continuity with the present position and, hopefully, will improve the lot of Australian flag carriers in the future. The legislation does not address the reasons the conference arrangements might lead to the better provision of regular, competitive services to Australia than an open market would allow. Of course, one reason is that the Australian shipping market is so hampered by uncompetitive practices on the waterfront and in coastal shipping that the market for shipping transport, as a consequence, is less profitable and, to that extent, would be undersupplied. The unfortunate need for the conference system is intimately linked to the enormous local problems which Australia has on its waterfront. These issues are now at the forefront of political debate although they have been a cause of economic decline for a much longer period.

With the Labor Government now floundering as it tries to avoid the consequences of its inability to reform the productive sectors of the Australian economy, the reform of the waterfront has become a test case of the ability of this Government to achieve some micro-economic reform. The wider importance of the waterfront is that it encapsulates the deepest problems of the Australian economy. The rejuvenation of the Australian shipping industry is inextricably linked with an end to the industrial relations disaster which has reigned under the accord between this Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The waterfront is the textbook example of the failure of centralised wage fixing to produce either industrial harmony or economic benefits.

It would be difficult to exaggerate the magnitude of the failure of government policy to deal with problems on the waterfront and with maritime industries generally. The Government has been held hostage by the vested interests of the powerful trade unions on the waterfront and in the maritime industries and by local carriers as well who are afraid of competition from overseas.

The two-volume conclusions and recommendations of the Inter-State Commission's waterfront investigation effectively illustrate the depth of the problems which the ISC sought to address. It is worth repeating the long list which the ISC gave of the `classic symptoms of an imperfect market', as represented by the present situation on the waterfront. They include ineffective management; poor work force training and career arrangements; introspective industrial attitudes; poor response to user needs; poor information flows to users and between links in the transport chain; lack of supply and demand balance often reflected in congestion and queues or in under-utilisation of expensive facilities; diffusion of governmental responsibility; abuse of monopoly power reflected particularly in port authority pricing and investment policies; and a tendency for matters to improve considerably while they are under investigation but to lapse once the pressure is removed. That report also states:

To this litany can be added high costs, endemic unreliability, a high level of industrial disputation, inappropriate manning levels and work practices, poor discipline, poor motivation throughout the industry, and a pervasive lack of competition.

I know that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) is excited about this debate as I can see that he is listening to it, although occasionally he is trying to stifle a yawn. When one adds that most port facilities are run by government authorities at one level or another, it is clear that the great industry which once formed the basis of the growth of free world trade and prosperity is, in Australia, a victim of government interventionism at almost every point in its development and operation. It is little wonder that international shipowners are unwilling to service Australia without the protection of the conference arrangements which presently exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder at all.

—It is no wonder at all. I am pleased to see that the honourable member is paying attention. At the same time, the work force on the wharves has declined considerably but is still at a level which is far too high.
—It is not productive.
