—It is not productive, as my colleague suggests, and it is overmanned to an alarming extent. The legacy of the trade unions' activities on the waterfront is jobs for the privileged few at the expense of the employment of many more.
—Some are more equal than others.

—I will take the honourable member's word for that. The effects of this reverberate around the economy. Exports cost more to deliver to customers and imports cost consumers more than they should. Waterfront problems hinder trade, which would contribute to reducing the poor current account deficit which I mentioned earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's record on the waterfront flies in the face of claims that it has improved industrial disputation and managed to prompt a restructuring of industry. The ISC criticisms of the waterfront reinforce what the Opposition has been saying for many years about the problems in industrial relations and those problems manifest themselves in a number of industries. The response of the Government to the ISC report will test the ability of the Government to resist the pressure of the powerful waterfront unions such as the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. The Waterside Workers Federation and the ACTU have already stated their opposition to the proposals of the ISC despite the significant support for workers which the report recommends. The only rational motive which the trade unions can have for opposing the recommendations offered by the ISC is to defend and preserve their own influence and power. Under its proposals the ISC wants to reduce the dominance of the Waterside Workers Federation through the renegotiation of awards, the introduction of new stand down provisions which allow employers to stand down workers as soon as industrial action makes further work impossible, and the encouragement of new workplace-based certified agreements. The suggested move to enterprise-based employment would reduce the hegemony of the industry-wide unions which currently do so much to hinder competition. Employees would directly benefit from a generous retirement and redundancy program funded by the Commonwealth, yet the ACTU and the Waterside Workers Federation resist.

The report also suggests that as many as 1,000 new employees should enter the industry. The maritime and waterfront unions are insistent on maintaining their power at the expense of everyone in Australia and, in particular, all those who are excluded from working on the waterfront by a classic exercise in labour market protection. It is worthwhile considering just how wide the effects of maritime transport are on the whole of Australian industry, the whole of our economy. Not only are our imports dearer and our exports less competitive, but those manufactured goods which use materials produced overseas or components made in other countries are also less competitive. The profits of primary producers are reduced as they bear the burden of shipping costs.

While coastal shipping remains so inefficient in Australia, a number of other economic distortions emerge. There are too many examples of how much cheaper it is to bring goods by sea from another country than to ship between ports within Australia. The legislation before us does not address these wider problems with the Australian shipping industry which provides the backdrop to the arrangements which we have for international liner shipping. In line with the related recommendations in the ISC report, this Bill seeks the wider application of trade practices legislation to maritime trade. This will go some small way to ensure competition between non-conference carriers.

However, there are some problems with the detail of the legislation and the way in which the Government is going about achieving what are acknowledged desirable goals. First, the Bill omits any precise definition of what a conference actually is. Given this omission, everything which follows must be somewhat uncertain. A `conference agreement' is only defined as an agreement between members of a conference, although it is acknowledged that all conference agreements will be registered and publicly available. We are, in fact, offering the protection of an agreement with a party or parties that are not all that well defined. Similarly, the definitions of market power for the application of trade practices legislation, and those in division 9 of this Bill, are not all that clear. Division 9 of the Bill deals with the power of the Minister and various other bodies over liner carriers which are not part of conference arrangements. It is in this context that the definition of substantial market power must be clarified. I hope the Minister can do this in his summing up.

I have one other problem with the way the Government has gone about setting up this legislation. It is probably in keeping with the Government's corporatist approach, but the Bill gives official negotiating recognition to a `designated peak shipper body' and designated secondary shipper bodies. This approach to arrangements with international ocean carriers is a long way from the market-based approach which would be ideal. It provides no incentives to move away from the cartel-like structures of the liner shipping industry. This Government's automatic reaction to any problem seems to be to set up a committee or an association and we will deal with them. It uses the terminology and structures of its trade union masters and failed industry plans to pile new responsibilities on employers and businesses.

In summary, this Bill is a step in the right direction as far as international liner shipping is concerned. It should by no means be seen as an end in itself since the conference system has helped allow Australia to avoid fixing up major problems with our hopelessly inefficient waterfront and maritime industries. It is essential to the future of Australian industry for the Government to achieve micro-economic reform in transportation. Unfortunately the Government is hindered in that task because it is beholden to the powers of the trade union interests as represented by the ACTU and as manifested in these industries. It is likely that genuine reform will have to await the impending victory of a coalition government under John Howard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the contributions of members of the Opposition to this debate, one might have thought that the idea of free and active competition was somehow a virtue that they have a monopoly on. Unfortunately monopolies were things which they were only too comfortable with during their long period of Government in the Menzies years. In fact, the whole attack on the rorts and the monopolies, the structure of industry and the overcentralisation of control by too few was brought about by Labor Party legislation. The Trade Practices Act, which was the first legislation brought in to smash monopolies, to break down cartelisation, to make sure that the market trades efficiently, was Labor legislation and the legislation that is coming in today, that gives us a better shake in the world trading area, to make sure that some of the inefficiencies that can be caused by too extreme cartelisation, is again Labor Party legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is one of the peculiarities that we are being continually berated by the rural socialists about issues of freeing up the waterfront and the like when honourable members opposite persist with romantic nostalgia about some of the worst kinds of rorts in the marketing of some rural products. It is a disgrace in terms of intellectual coherence that they can come in here blithely and speak slightly of the interests of the working people of this nation and yet put forward proposals which are a framework to protect inefficient rural enterprises, to socialise loss and to maximise private gain.

The Government is rigorously looking at competition and at micro-economic reform. Today we are dealing with international shipping. International shipping is an area of Australia's trade in which Australian carriers hold a only minority share, far too small a share in my view and, I am sure, in the view of many of my colleagues. Part of our response in the Bill is to protect the fledgling Australian shipping industry and to make sure that it is not pushed under by unfair competition. Provisions in the Bill make sure that the traders that can exert huge market influence on the international shipping sector, the major cartels, which are known in the shipping area as conferences, are not able to conduct secret agreements and hide behind the previous exemptions in the Trade Practices Act, protecting them from the scrutiny to which other sectors of the industry are subject.

Today we have heard a huge beat-up about the waterfront. This Bill is a huge step forward for Australia in the international trading sector. The Government plainly has on its agenda micro-economic reform of the waterfront. It has reports before it and is studying them. We get from the Opposition a strange, perverted, backhanded compliment-one line in a speech that says `You might be doing something good in this Bill'-then a discussion ensues, entirely disconnected with the substance of the debate. Opposition speakers ramble on about anything that happens to cross their minds and do not focus on the crucial issue of international trade.

We see two significant reforms in this area. The most significant of those reforms is to take away some of the protections which the conferences, the cartels, the major shipping companies, working together have had. We recognise that, obviously, major shipping companies have to continue to play a significant part in world trade. They have great advantages in being able to offer reliable and predictable services, continuous scheduling, and a price basis that is attractive to Australia. In a sense we allow them to negotiate together in an uncompetitive way.

In this Bill we restrict, or take away, some of the uncompetitive elements and expose to public scrutiny any remaining elements that we permit. The Bill will mean that essentially our international trading position will be significantly more competitive. It will mean that the rorts and the ramps that have been hidden under the veneer of secrecy will be exposed to public scrutiny. As I think many regulators would say, sunlight is the best antiseptic. If one knows what is going on, very often the worst excesses do not happen.

We have heard the naive statement that we should somehow not allow shippers, the people who are exporting from Australia, to try to exercise some kind of effective market power. The last speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), suggested that we should allow individual shippers only to negotiate with the huge conference shipping lines. What nonsense. That is not competition; that is a prescription for being screwed down every time one does a deal. That is a prescription for Australia losing to the world's shipping conferences. It is not a prescription for the growth of Australia's shipping fleet or for its expansion from about seven or nine per cent to a much higher and more sensible proportion of the shipping fleet being in Australian hands; it is a prescription for the Australian shipping industry to remain moribund and in the control of international cartels.

These measures are important in principle. They are significant. One could hardly expect an opposition that is totally inconsistent in its approach to major issues such as trade practices, the protection of the freedom of trade and consumer protection come in here with a coherent response to this legislation. Let us consider the States which are still in the control of conservative governments. In many of those States there is no consumer protection, no legislation to make sure that the operation of the market is free and informed. The consumer magazine has continually rated some of the consumer affairs Ministers of those conservative States right at the bottom of the barrel. Time after time, the rorts and the ramps are defended by the Opposition when it suits its parochial interests-its local, regional, rural or secular interests. It focuses on those issues while the Government, in a methodical way, considers how best to deal with the realities of the world, how best to cope with the fact that Australia is a relatively small nation with major needs in terms of reliable shipping. Australia is in some ways caught up with a very small national shipping fleet. The Government is considering how to make it work effectively in our national interest.

When one considers the spurious contributions to the debate that have been made by some Opposition speakers one has to say, `It is heads in the sand time. There has been no real focus on the real issues. There has been no attempt to grapple with the hard-nosed problems that Australia faces'. The measure of this Government is that it is not interested in playing to the gallery; it is interested in engineering reforms which will actually work. Mr Deputy Speaker, given the time, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 7.07 to 7.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Speaker, tonight the Australian Labor Party will fulfil the commitment it made in May last year to deliver substantial tax relief in 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: At that time I said the country would be able to afford these tax cuts only if wage increases over the ensuing year were held in check.
The Australian workforce has kept to its side of that bargain.
Tonight we will keep to ours.
From 1 July all taxpayers will pay significantly less tax, particularly low and middle income earners.
This will be achieved while preserving the budget surplus at this year's record level.
But tonight's Statement is about much more than just personal income tax cuts.
It also includes a wide range of measures to increase substantially assistance to families and pensioners.
These are all measures of great substance, carefully directed by the Government to those who deserve them most.
But even more than that, this package cements into place the central element of the Government's economic strategy for 1989-90 and beyond.
It secures the maintenance of sensible wage outcomes in the national interest.
We have sought and won agreement from the Australian Council of Trade Unions that the tax cuts will be accepted as part of next year's wages system.
This means that the tax cuts will take the place of what would otherwise have been very much higher wage cost increases, which would have threatened employment and thrown the economy into recession.
Instead, the tax cuts will play a central role in lowering inflation, enhancing competitiveness and supporting economic growth.
They will also underpin a far-reaching modernisation of the existing system of industrial awards, upgrading productivity and the quality of the working lives of all Australians.
Compare this situation with that of our predecessors.
In 1982 the then Treasurer-the now Leader of the Opposition-made irresponsible tax cuts which were not part of any sensible arrangement to moderate wage rises.
To the contrary, they were paid on top of a wage explosion which ushered in Australia's deepest recession since the 1930s.
He rejected the notion of an orderly and agreed basis for wages growth, preferring industrial confrontation to co-operation.
The dismal result was strikes and wages chaos which destroyed the economy, killing jobs and shutting down businesses all over the country.
Tonight's wage/tax package stands in stark contrast to that mayhem.
It is the very essence of reason and order.
Reason, in that the Government and the workforce can work out and cooperate in an arrangement that is vastly superior to the alternative of a wage explosion followed by a recession.
Order, in that only an orderly arrangement can secure improved living standards while maintaining business investment, growth and progress.
Madam Speaker, this package could only be delivered by a Labor Government.
This Labor Government, through its Accord with the Australian workforce, is the only party which can deliver economic growth without crippling strikes, confrontation and unemployment.
In the last six years the Accord has delivered 1.3 million jobs, a phenomenal 20 per cent increase in employment.
And it did this with a sharp reduction in strikes.
By contrast, in the last six years of the Fraser Government job growth was a miserable 4 per cent, with three times as many strikes.
Indeed, in the last two years in which the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, served as Treasurer, unemployment doubled to 700,000.
That is why, Madam Speaker, Labor not only claims a superior economic strategy and performance-it has proved it.
If we leave you with one single thought tonight it is this: if a Government cannot run wages in Australia it cannot run the Australian economy.
We have shown over six years that we can run a successful wages system.
In complete contrast, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, as Treasurer in 1981 and 1982, comprehensively demonstrated that he could not manage wages policy.
He failed and his failure cost the nation dearly.
The tragedy with the Liberals is that in the seven years since, nothing has changed-they are no further advanced.
If they were in office today, they would have the same wages policy that destroyed the place seven years ago.
THE MEASURES
Madam Speaker, I now turn to the details of the Government's tax and social justice statement, its wage/tax strategy.
At a total cost of $5.7 billion, it consists of tax cuts costing $4.9 billion and, at $710 million, the largest social security package in our history.

Overall, it provides big personal income tax cuts, significant increases in family allowances and pensioner benefits, increases in the Dependent Spouse and Sole Parent Rebates, and a radical restructuring of the Australian award wage system.
These combine to deliver a substantial rise in the disposable income of all Australians.
Families particularly will receive the extra support they deserve, and the least well paid members of the community will benefit from an historic lift in incomes.
Before detailing the changes, I will illustrate how the measures combine to apply in some representative examples.
The key here is to understand that a dollar in tax cuts is a dollar in the hand, whereas a dollar of wages is worth considerably less after tax.
In other words, the tax cuts are equivalent to larger wage rises.
The four examples I will provide are expressed in terms of their equivalent value as wages.

Take first a low income earner on about $290 a week or $15,000 a year, with a dependent spouse and two children, and qualifying for a $20 supplementary payment adjustment to his or her minimum award rate of pay.
On 1 July such a taxpayer will get the equivalent of a $24 a week pay rise from the tax cut and family assistance increases.
Subsequent award restructuring and supplementary wage payments will deliver an additional $40 a week, giving a total wage equivalent increase of $64 a week.
It is as though they received a $64 wage rise.
Second, in the case of a wage earner on $500 a week or $26,000 a year, with a dependent spouse and two children, the comparable wage equivalent increase is $71 a week.
Third, for a two income family with two children on a combined income of $860 per week or $45,000 a year, the increase is equivalent to a wage rise of $121 a week.
And finally, for a single income earner with no dependants on $500 per week, or $26,000 a year, the total wage equivalent increase would be $56 a week.
Madam Speaker, these increases fulfil the Government's commitment to lift real disposable incomes in 1989-90.
Had they all been paid in wages, such rises would have implied a 12 per cent increase in the national wage bill next financial year.
In fact, however, the actual cost of the overall package will be 6 1/2 per cent.
This reflects the efficiency of a `paid for' tax cut in providing a non-inflationary wage increase in place of a straight wage rise.
Putting it more starkly, the workforce will receive increases equivalent to 12 per cent at roughly half the cost to employers and to inflation.
This significant result could only be delivered by a Labor Government through the processes of the Accord.
TAX SCALE AND FAMILY
ASSISTANCE
Madam Speaker, I will now detail the new tax scale and family assistance measures.
I have already illustrated the real benefit of these tax cuts to wage earners.

The tax cuts and family allowance increases are large in their own right-ranging from around $15 a week for a single taxpayer on average weekly earnings to $30 a week for a family taxpayer with the same income.

When this Government came to office in 1983, the lowest tax rate of all was 30 cents in the dollar; after that there was a hefty jump to 46 cents in the dollar; then another steep climb to 60 cents in the dollar.
Labor's new scale has a bottom rate of only 21 cents in the dollar, middle rates of 29 and 39 cents and, up to a $50,000 threshold, a new 47 cent rate.
Above income levels of $50,000 the rate will remain at 49 cents in the dollar until 1 January 1990, when it will come down to the new 47 cent rate.
Given the enormous progress we have already made in cutting the Liberal's punitive 60 per cent rate, it is only fair that people earning more than $50,000 a year wait a little longer this time.
Madam Speaker, we have also acted to reduce tax burdens significantly by increasing a range of tax rebates.
For single income couples with children, the Dependent Spouse Rebate is to be increased from $1,030 to $1,200.
For single income couples without children it will be increased from $830 to $1,000, while the sole parent rebate will be raised from $780 to $940.

To assist families we are raising family allowances to $9 a week for each of the first three children, and to $12 a week for the fourth and any additional children, while the family allowances supplement will be lifted by $3.10 a week for children aged between 13 and 15 years.
As a result we will achieve this year the child poverty benchmarks promised by the Prime Minister-well ahead of the 1990 target.
Moreover, in an historic step, all these rebates and family allowances will be indexed in future to annual movements in the CPI, to preserve their real value permanently.
Madam Speaker, two further key points need to be made about this new tax structure.
The first is that it more than offsets what is known as fiscal drag or bracket creep.
In other words, personal income taxpayers will now be paying less tax than if we had indexed the tax scales for inflation since 1983.
The second point is that because of our past decisions, Commonwealth spending relative to the size of the economy will continue to fall in future years.
It has already fallen to its lowest level in 15 years.
In other words, we have provided real scope for further affordable tax cuts in the years ahead because the public sector will be so much smaller.
AGE PENSIONS
Madam Speaker, I now outline the major reforms the Government is making in assistance to age pensioners.
First, the relationship between the age pension and tax systems is to be made more rational and less confusing.
Many pensioners have said to us that it was unfair that they are allowed to earn up to an extra $40 a week without affecting their pension, but must pay tax if they earn more than $10 a week.
The Government has examined this and will remedy it.
Pensioner tax rebates are to be increased so that age pensioners with earnings within the income test free area of $40 for single pensioners, and $70 for married couples, will pay no tax at all.
When fully phased in by July 1990, this major reform will mean that 80 per cent of Australia's 1.8 million age and service pensioners will be exempt from tax.

For single pensioners, as a first step in 1989-90, the rebate will relieve $25 a week of non-pension income from tax, while in 1990-91 the rebate will be increased to a level which exempts $40 a week.
For married pensioners, the cost of achieving the same objective is smaller and the rebates will be raised in one step in 1989-90.
The second improvement concerns the timing of pension adjustments.
In 1986 pensioners were asked to share the burden of adjustment to the collapse in Australia's export prices by waiting six weeks for pension adjustments.
They have done their fair share.
The Government has decided not only to remove the six week delay, but also to bring forward the indexation of pensions by a further six weeks; a total bring-forward of 12 weeks.
This bring-forward will be implemented in equal instalments over three indexation adjustments beginning in 1989-90.
In other words, after June this year pensions will be indexed at five monthly intervals until the full 12 week bring-forward is in place in September 1990.
These new payment arrangements will apply to all pensioners and beneficiaries and will compensate for price rises much more rapidly.
In addition, Madam Speaker, the 2 per cent discount imposed in 1986-87 for public service and defence force pensioners will be restored from November 1989.
WAGES POLICY
Madam Speaker, I now describe in more detail how the changes fit into wages policy.

I can announce tonight that, on the basis of the tax cuts and assistance measures the Government will deliver from 1 July, the Australian Council of Trade Unions has agreed and accepts that average earnings growth in 1989-90 will be held to around 6 1/2 per cent.
In doing so, the ACTU also has agreed that there will be no claim for a CPI-based across-the-board wage increase in 1989-90.
Madam Speaker, the new wages system will be determined by Justice Maddern and his colleagues on the Industrial Relations Commission in the current proceedings and the Wage Case scheduled for May.

We are envisaging the most far-reaching overhaul of industrial awards since Federation, and the Industrial Relations Commission has a vital role to play in establishing the new wage system and presiding over the orderly change to award structures.

Award restructuring will bring substantial benefits for all parties-for employers, a more flexible, productive and highly trained workforce; and for employees, more interesting, varied and better-paid jobs.
For very low-paid workers, the Commonwealth will support moderate supplementary payment adjustments, phased over two years, to lift their incomes to a reasonable living wage.
Only members of unions prepared to implement genuine award restructuring will be eligible for pay rises.
The tax cuts, by raising take-home pay from 1 July, will establish an environment in which comprehensive award restructuring negotiations can proceed.
We anticipate that wage increases from this process will be paid progressively in two stages, beginning later in 1989.
This new pay system brings about historic changes, including reforms called for by the business community over many years and now able to be implemented under the Accord.
It will make Australian industry much more productive, competitive and better placed to overcome our balance of payments problem.
The Commonwealth will back up the award restructuring process by allocating $12 million to fund its Workplace Reform Program.
The Minister for Employment, Education and Training is announcing tonight new programs to assist training in industry.
FISCAL POLICY
Madam Speaker, like wages policy, budget policy will continue to be deployed fully to bear down on Australia's trade deficit.
Already I have said the 1989-90 Budget will retain a surplus at least equal to this year's forecast of $5.5 billion.
Furthermore, we will budget for an unprecedented fourth consecutive year of real declines in spending.
And we will again ensure the public sector borrowing requirement in Australia is no greater than zero.
Fiscal policy will therefore be kept as tight as a drum.
To this end tonight's Statement includes a first instalment of savings measures for incorporation in the August Budget.
These savings will more than offset the $710 million overall cost of the new policy measures I have announced to assist families and pensioners.
Savings on direct Commonwealth payments totalling about $360 million will be achieved principally from four areas.

There will be a further tightening of procedures to avoid social security abuse; the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will be restructured-I stress without affecting pensioners; a new pathology fee schedule will apply; and Defence spending will be maintained but without a real increase.
Payments to the States will be determined at the Premiers' Conference next month.
But savings against the forward estimates at least equal to the cuts in direct Commonwealth spending will be realised.
The States too must contribute to the national economic and wage strategy from which they materially benefit.
STRUCTURAL REFORMS
Madam Speaker, I turn now to on-going reforms in key areas of the economy designed to remove supply bottlenecks and raise efficiency.
The new wages system opens the way for a dramatic lift in the productivity of Australian industry, as does the continuing boom in business investment.
But further progress in other areas is essential if we are to sustain rising living standards in the future.
Our determination to pursue changes was demonstrated by the structural adjustment measures I announced last May.

It was demonstrated again earlier this week when the Government declared its intention to override restrictive State provisions in order to accelerate the essential deregulations of wheat transport and marketing.
This followed our decision to press ahead with the development of additional capacity at Sydney airport.
In their own ways both these decisions will lift our competitiveness and improve our trading performance.
The Prime Minister has already announced that Ministers will be outlining additional reform measures during May.
Important amongst these will be a statement by the Minister for Transport and Communications detailing fundamental changes to the operations of our ports and coastal shipping.
These are key areas where inefficiencies and bottlenecks have held back our trade effort for decades.
But the Commonwealth alone cannot do all that is needed.
Ports and railways are a State responsibility and we will be seeking from them a meaningful commitment to reform in these areas.
Madam Speaker, this Government already has implemented many fundamental reforms to the tax system.
Tonight I am releasing a comprehensive document which outlines how we will crack down on the use of overseas tax havens by Australian companies.
We have no intention of allowing unscrupulous operators to exploit ordinary taxpayers through sham companies established for the sole purpose of avoiding tax.
ECONOMIC CONTEXT
Madam Speaker, I will conclude with some observations on the economic context of tonight's Statement.
The single most significant development in our economy in the past 12 months has been the huge surge in business investment.
This holds out the prospect of major benefits to Australia through increasing our capacity to produce exports and replace imports.
But the Government has not sought to disguise the fact that this investment phase has also led to substantial tensions in key areas of the economy.
With so much of the new equipment needed by business having to be imported, the balance of payments deficit has not narrowed as we expected.
And with demand running too strongly inflation has not fallen as we had hoped.
We have therefore seen interest rates in Australia rise to higher levels than any of us would like.
However, recent indicators have provided welcome signs that demand is returning to more sustainable rates of growth.
We are confident that this trend will continue as the past tightening of fiscal and monetary policy takes increasing effect.
This should be sufficient to slow demand and cut back the recent lift in imports and lower our current account deficit.
This Government is unequivocally committed to pursuing the strategy necessary to achieve a lasting turnaround in our current account and external debt imbalances.
As a nation we must never lose sight of the fact that both are unsustainably high.
For this reason I reaffirm that monetary policy will continue to play its vital balancing role in our overall economic strategy.
In all of this, tonight's wage/tax package is central.
It imposes a discipline on the key cost area of wages.
Without it Australia would simply return to the high cost recessionary days of the early 1980s.
We have acted decisively to prevent that dismal outcome.

We shall continue to pursue our economic strategy because it is the only strategy-I repeat the only strategy-capable of delivering lower inflation and a lower current account deficit in combination with sustained business activity and higher employment.
I commend the Statement to the House.
I present the following papers:
Economic Statement, April 1989-Ministerial statement, 12 April 1989.
Taxation of foreign source income-An information paper.
and move:
That the House take note of the papers.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (RATES AND REBATES) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill 1989 will amend various taxation Acts to give effect to matters announced earlier tonight by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his economic statement. The Bill will declare the general rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for the 1989-90 and subsequent financial years. It will also declare the rate of fringe benefits tax to apply from 1 April 1990.

Other measures to be implemented by this Bill will increase the maximum levels of the rebates of tax available to taxpayers who support certain dependants and allow those rebates to be indexed annually. The Bill will also allow instalments payable under the quarterly provisional tax system to be reduced to take account of the reduction in tax rates.
Personal Tax Rates

I turn now to the personal income tax rate measures contained in the Bill. The reform of the rate scales will be in two stages. With effect from 1 July 1989, a five-step scale will apply and this will reduce to a four-step scale from 1 January 1990. There is to be no change in the tax-free threshold of $5,100. From 1 July 1989 the existing 24 per cent rate will be reduced to 21 per cent and will apply to income over $5,100 and up to a new threshold level of $17,650. The 29 per cent rate will continue to apply, but in the altered income range $17,651 to $20,600. The existing 40 per cent rate will be reduced to 39 per cent and apply to income from $20,601 to $35,000. For income over $35,000 and up to $50,000 the rate of 49 per cent will be reduced to 47 per cent. Finally, for income over $50,000 the 49 per cent rate will be reduced to 47 per cent from 1 January 1990. To give effect to this decision a composite rate of 48 per cent will apply to that income on assessment for the 1989-90 year of income.

These tax cuts will be reflected in lower pay-as-you-earn deductions from 1 July 1989 and, in the case of income over $50,000, from 1 January 1990. The changes to the rate scale will also affect non-residents with the rate of 29 per cent applying on income up to $20,600 and above that amount reduced rates will apply as for residents. Other rates to be reduced include the rate on unearned income of minors which will be 48 per cent for 1989-90 and 47 per cent for all subsequent years, subject to shading-in arrangements for income just over $416. Also the rate of tax on trustee assessed under section 99a of the Income Tax Assessment Act will be 48 per cent for 1989-90 and 47 per cent in subsequent years. The cost to revenue of the personal tax cuts and the increases I will outline shortly to dependant rebates is $4,900 million in 1989-90 and $5,700 million in 1990-91.
Fringe Benefits Tax Rate

The rate of fringe benefits tax will be reduced to 47 per cent for the year of tax commencing on 1 April 1990 and subsequent years. The cost to revenue is estimated at $55 million in 1990-91 and $60 million in 1991-92.
Dependant Rebates

Increased levels of concessional rebates for dependants are being made available for 1989-90 and subsequent income years. As announced by the Treasurer, the dependant spouse rebate will be increased to $1,000 and to $1,200 where there is a dependent child or student. Similar increases will apply to the rebates for a daughter-housekeeper or a housekeeper. The level of the sole parent rebate is being increased to $940 and the levels of the concessional rebates for an invalid relative, a parent or a parent-in-law are also being increased. There will be a flow-on of these increases to the zone rebates of tax for people in isolated areas.
Indexation of Concessional Rebates

In addition, the Bill will give effect to the announcement that from 1990-91 the concessional rebates referred to earlier will be indexed annually on the basis of movements in the all groups consumer price index.
Quarterly Provisional Tax

The Bill will permit the Commissioner of Taxation to reduce to an appropriate level the amount of a quarterly provisional tax instalment otherwise payable in circumstances such as these where tax cuts have been announced.
I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains a more detailed explanation of the provisions of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
In doing so I ask the Parliament to endorse four historic commitments. The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 would establish:
A secure fair deal for families with children;
A guarantee of adequate standards of income for children;
For the first time maintenance of the real value of family payments; and
Indexation of pensions and benefits at the earliest possible date.

In 1966, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission did away with the basic wage. From that time Australia has not had a wages system that takes account of the costs of children. From that time fair income distribution has been a function exclusively for the tax and social security systems. Since then the social security system has been required to make sure working families have adequate income to care for all children.

Australia owes much to Professor Ronald Henderson for his clear articulation, as early as 1970, that the 1966 moves in the wages system would compel attention in public policy. He spelt out that we would have to address through tax and social security policy the issues of equity between families with and without children and the adequacy of incomes for all families with children. The report of the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty highlighted what issues had to be addressed. The work of that Commission lead to the Whitlam Government converting deductions for children into tax rebates and to the Fraser Government's cashing out the rebates to family allowance.

With the benefit of hindsight we can see that those moves were not sustained. The issues of fairness of the tax treatment of families and adequacy of family income, having been addressed by Henderson, were not further addressed for some years. Not until the Social Security Review were the issues thought through. The issues addressed by the Review include:
First, the balance between horizontal equity measures, such as family allowance, and vertical equity measures, such as family allowance supplement (FAS) and additional pension-benefit;

Secondly, the make-up of families and the importance of adequate provision for all family types-couples with one and two incomes, sole parents, families with pre-school age children, school children and teenagers, families with children with disabilities;
Thirdly, to which family member should particular payments go; and
Fourthly, standards of adequacy for families with inadequate incomes.

Professor Cass's Issues Paper No. 1 of the Social Security Review, Income support for families with children, is the first comprehensive analysis of the detailed policies required to build a fair, secure policy that deals with the issues identified by Henderson 20 years ago. Cass identified short term measures which were demanded by the appalling extent of poverty among families with children. Over the last two years those recommendations have been progressively implemented through the families package: family allowance supplement was introduced, payable to the mother; child disability allowance was introduced, differential rates of payment for younger and older children have been introduced; massive increases in payments per child have occurred; family allowance supplement and family allowance have been integrated into a single payment. Tonight we move from the short term to the long term recommendations of Professor Cass, addressing the more fundamental issues of horizontal equity and sustaining the system into the future.

This Bill proposes the biggest increases in family allowance in history. In 1976 when tax rebates for children were cashed out by the Fraser Government assistance for working families was cut-from $4.50 per week for the first child to $3.50. This was done by converting the tax rebate for the first child of $200 a year into an increase of $3 a week in family allowance to a total of $3.50. In 1982, the Fraser Government gave its first and only family allowance increase-of $1.75 a week to $5.25, a net increase in assistance for the first child of 75c a week in 7 years. Tonight I ask for Parliament's endorsement of a rise of $3.75 a week to $9-an increase of 71 per cent for the first child in every family.

The Bill would massively simplify the family allowance system. The current system of four rates of allowance will be replaced with two rates: $9 a week for the first, second and third children and $12 a week for fourth and subsequent children and for children in institutions. This new simple structure accords with proposals of the Social Security Review-a basic family allowance at a flat rate, with special recognition for larger families. The increases to family allowance would directly benefit almost 2 million families with 3.8 million children.

The family allowance system announced tonight is simple, fair and sustainable. The Bill would index all family allowance payments in line with movements in the consumer price index (CPI). This fair deal for families will not be eroded by inflation. The fair deal for Australian families in this Bill is complemented by the major rises in, and annual indexation of, the dependent spouse rebate and sole parent rebate announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tonight.
In our policy commitments at the last election we promised that `during Labor's third term an adequate living standard for children will be achieved by:
Raising child payments to ensure that total assistance per child moves from its current level of 11 per cent to at least 15 per cent of the combined married rate of pension; and
ensuring that the aggregate payments for older children attain a benchmark of 20 per cent of the combined married rate.'

Tonight, this Labor Government delivers on that promise. That promise was made because of our firm belief that the greatest scourge facing our nation is child poverty, that we must put an end to that, and that there is only one way to do that: to guarantee adequate income for all children. This Bill delivers on our promise, putting behind us the scandal of child poverty.

The levels of child payments set by this Bill are consistent with Australian research on the income needs of families with children. For the first time in Australian history a government has set a standard for child payments that is adequate and will be maintained in real terms. Professor Henderson in the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty recommended payments equivalent to 12 per cent, 15 per cent and 18 per cent of the payments for a married couple respectively for first, second and third children. The package we have announced tonight of 15 per cent of married rate pension for each younger child and 20 per cent for 13- to 15-year-olds goes beyond the Poverty Commission's work, providing for the first time in history a guaranteed income for families at a higher real level than recommended by the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty.

On the basis of the Social Security Review's work, Labor made its commitment to benchmarks for child payments-a commitment to establish enduring relativities between families with children and people without children. For the first time in Australia we have a policy based on what it costs to raise children, rather than on what happens to be available in the Budget pro- cess. That policy that recognises the costs of children has built in what every parent of teenagers knows, and all the research shows: teenagers cost more. In just 18 months we have introduced and won universal acceptance for a higher rate for teenage children. These policies are complemented by the common allowance structure for youth incomes. We have put in place income support of 15 per cent of married rate pension for children up to 12, 20 per cent for 13- to 15-year-olds and 25 per cent for 16- and 17-year-olds, taking account of the Austudy payment. This Bill would implement the guaranteed standards of adequacy from 1 July this year.

Building on Henderson's work, the Social Security Review examined in detail 30 separate studies of equivalence scales-of the relativities of incomes needs or expenditure patterns between different family types and sizes. For younger children family allowance of $9 a week plus family allowance supplement of $24 a week will be payable-a total of $33 a week per child. For 13- to 15-year-olds the increases in family allowance will be added to by a $3.10 increase in family allowance supplement, providing a combined payment of $43.10 per week per child, in comparison to the $15.25 available when we came to government. Reaching those standards means massive real increases in payments for 1.1 million children in low income families. The level of those payments lines up with Australian research on income needs of families. The days of policy based on anecdote, of increases based on what is left over at the end of the Budget process, are behind us. Policy is now based on explicit standards that are available for rigorous scrutiny.

The third commitment I ask of the Parliament this evening is indexation of family payments and maintenance of the standards of adequacy. As a nation we like to think of ourselves as placing our children first. Until tonight the actions of this Parliament have not placed our children first. We have fully indexed payments for adults, offering them some security and protection from the ravages of inflation. Before tonight no government had ever committed itself to maintenance of payments to families with children in real terms. Tonight this Labor Government has done so.

The Bill seeks to index family payments: family allowance, mother's-guardian's allowance, child disability allowance, multiple birth payment and double orphan's pension. The first indexation increase will be on the first payday in 1990. Family allowance will be adjusted in line with the increase in the CPI between December 1988 and the June quarter this year. After that family allowance will be indexed annually with effect from the first payday each calendar year in line with movements in the CPI in the preceding financial year. Mother's-guardian's allowance, child disability allowance, multiple birth payment and double orphan's pension will each be indexed on the first payday in 1990 and each year after that increases will be in line with CPI movements in the preceding financial year.

I have already referred to the real declines in tax and family allowance provisions for families with children under the previous Government. All families suffered in that period because payments and rebates were not adjusted for inflation. For low income families the absence of that adjustment was devastating: 800,000 children-one child in every five-were forced into poverty. Payments for children in low income families were increased in nominal terms only once in 7 years-from $7.50 to $10, a real decline of 35 per cent. Under Labor those payments have been increased every year: In 1983 from $10 to $12; in 1984 from $12 to $14; in 1985 from $14 to $16; in 1986 from $16 to $17; in 1987 from $17 to $22 for younger children and $28 for older children; and in 1988 from $22 to $24 for younger children and $28 to $31 for older children. This Bill proposes a further increase for older children in 1989 from $31 to $34.10 and historic rises in family allowance for all children.

The Bill would guarantee these gains would not be eroded by inflation. On top of family allowance indexation, family allowance supplement, additional pension and additional benefit will be adjusted from the first payday each calendar year. This adjustment will increase rates of FAS and additional pension-benefit whenever necessary to maintain the standards of adequacy. Total payments for children in low income families would be guaranteed as a percentage of married rate pension, which is automatically indexed in line with the CPI. The standards of living of low income families with children will never again be subject to decimation through policy indolence and lethargy of governments. Tonight, all members of this Parliament are asked to step beyond attitudes and to commit themselves to a solid policy-of a secure and fair deal for families.

For the last year we have had vigorous debate in Australia on the appropriate levels and type of provision for families with children. That debate is central to any concern about fairness and equity in our community. To quote Professor Cass:

In a period of restraint on public expenditure it is essential to address the matter of immediate priorities for family assistance. This focuses attention on those approaches which provide greater assistance to low income families by improving adequacy of income-tested payments for pensioners, beneficiaries and low income working families and introducing measures which minimise work disincentives and support the transition to employment.
There she described in 1986 the processes the Government has implemented in the past two years. She went on:

Proposals for reform based on the principle of horizontal equity have the long-term objective of improving and maintaining the disposable incomes of families with children relative to individuals and couples without children . . .

The value at which family allowances might be set is obviously contentious, with the terms of debate set within the outer limits of appropriate assistance with the costs of children on the one hand, and the capacity of government revenue and the willingness of the political process to redistribute to families, on the other hand.

This Bill, together with the Treasurer's announced increases and indexation of family taxation rebates, delivers a fair, sustainable deal for all families with a guarantee of adequate income for all families with children. There is a balance involved-a balance that until tonight Australian public policy has addressed for 20 years in what can only be described as an ad hoc way. The balance we have struck provides a fair distribution of income and provides a guarantee of income for every family which is adequate for them to share fully in the life of our community. It accords with the very essence of social justice.

Sustainable, equitable social reform is never easy, never quick. Tonight's package is a fair, sustainable deal for families. Professor Henderson indicated the need for it 20 years ago. Professor Cass did the detailed work on how to do it and spelt out the process to achieve it. Tonight, we have delivered it. We have delivered for all children-whether they live in one or two parent families, whether one, two or no parents work, or whether they live in institutions.

Just as in family policy we have known of the issues for many years and just as we needed the Social Security Review to look at the detail and work through the detailed processes, so we are entering upon a detailed review of retirement incomes. In October 1988 the Social Security Review released Issues Paper No. 6, Towards a National Retirement Incomes Policy. Following release of that paper, the Government initiated an extensive series of community consultations on retirement income policies. The task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on retirement income has travelled to all States to meet with, and listen to, several thousand pensioners and retired people at some 40 separate meetings. Mr Deputy Speaker, Mr McLeay, I think you, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), the Prime Minister and I got some benefit from listening to aged people, hearing what some of their concerns were and getting some idea of their priorities. The Australian Council of Social Service, in conjunction with the Australian Pensioners Federation, has also undertaken an extensive consultation process to obtain the views of pensioners and the community welfare sector.

The Government has been consulting State governments, trade unions, business, the superannuation industry and relevant national organisations, as well as considering the many written submissions received in response to the Social Security Review's issues paper. I think almost 300 submissions have been received. Tonight we have announced two measures that were recommended by the Social Security Review, the Prime Minister's task force on retirement income, and consultations and submissions received by the Government. These initiatives form part of a phased reform of retirement income to improve adequacy, fairness, security and sustainability.

In addition to recommendations from the Social Security Review and from the subsequent consultations, the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs recommended that the Government should reduce the lag between the release of the CPI figures and the indexation of pension payments. The Government has therefore decided to bring forward pension indexation increases in three stages. Each stage will bring the indexation increase forward by four weeks. The Bill would provide for indexation dates to be 15 November 1989, 18 April 1990, and then Each September and March. Indexation dates would be brought forward in total by 12 weeks.

Consultations on retirement income have also shown quite clearly that the differing free areas for tax and social security confuse many age pensioners. The Government has therefore decided to ensure that the income test free area will become 100 per cent tax free. This will be achieved by setting the pensioner tax rebate at an appropriate level. The Treasurer's announcement tonight that the pension free area is to become tax free is a major reform. No previous government has ever committed itself to a standard for the amount of non-pension income that pensioners can receive without paying tax. This announcement, together with the changes to indexation dates, is a clear statement of the Government's direction in retirement income policy. It will enable people contemplating retirement to plan for their future with the security that their real levels of total income will be protected.

In 1989-90 a single pensioner will be able to receive $25 per week on top of the maximum rate of pension without having to pay tax. In 1990-91 this amount will be increased to $40, so that the income test free area is totally tax free. In 1989-90 married couples will be able to receive $35 per week each tax free. This means that married couples will be able to receive 100 per cent of their pension income test free area without paying any tax. The Government's decision will also mean an extra 75,000 pensioners will not pay provisional tax. This is because all pensioners receiving the pensioner tax rebate are exempted from paying provisional tax.

This Government has repaired the damage done by the previous Government by repairing the income security safety net, by protecting the safety net from inflation through indexation and automatic adjustment and by restoring employment. Last week unemployment benefit number fell to less than 400,000-the lowest figure since 1982. Unfortunately, those who have been unemployed longest are finding it hardest to take advantage of employment growth. New-Start offers a leg up to those people-to end their scarring and exclusion. It is available to long term beneficiaries. With effect from 1 February this year New-Start has been extended to the spouses of long term beneficiaries. This Bill would extend employment entry payment to those spouses.

The Bill also seeks to correct anomaly affecting the payment of child disability allowance. Under the current legislation, in some cases allowance may not be payable where a father is caring for a disabled child. The Bill would make it clear that the family is entitled to the child disability allowance regardless of which parent actually cares for the child.

Experience with the operation of the savings provision introduced with the maintenance income test in June last year has shown the need for refinements in three areas. First, the Government has decided to restore and backdate fully indexation increases to people in the saved category who are receiving spousal maintenance only and have no dependent children. Secondly, income payments received in arrears would be excluded from the definition of `total income' so that people who receive late what they were entitled to all along maintain the benefit of the savings provision. Thirdly, the Bill would close a loophole in the maintenance income test savings provision by ensuring that the previous level of benefit is `saved' only to the extent that the client continues to meet the basic eligibility criteria for the payment. It is being made clear, for example, that if a child ceases to be a dependant for the purpose of the payment of additional benefit, then that component of the entitlement ceases. Entitlement to a one-off double payment of benefit to ex-prisoners will be extended to former long term beneficiaries who reclaim unemployment benefit on release from prison within three months of last receiving unemployment benefit.

The Bill refines rules governing the portability of Australian pensions overseas. This refinement is necessary for the effective negotiation and operation of our reciprocal social security agreements. Broadly speaking, the rate of pension currently paid overseas after 12 months' absence is based on the proportion of a person's working life spent resident in Australia. To date, each agreement has contained this rule within its own text. However, future agreements will apply the rule by reference to our domestic social security legislation. It is necessary, therefore, to set down this mechanism in the Act.

The Bill would increase penalties for the unauthorised disclosure of client information. The penalties currently provided by the Act on summary conviction for unlawful disclosure are up to six months' imprisonment or a $1,000 fine. On indictment, an offender can face a gaol term of up to two years or a fine of up to $5,000. This Bill would raise the fines for breaches of the secrecy provisions contained in the Social Security Act to $3,000 on summary conviction and $12,000 on indictment.

In the last three years we have redesigned and rebuilt the system of income support for families with children. That has involved major changes in the approaches required of the staff in the 220 regional, area and state offices of the Department of Social Security. I place on record the Government's and my own appreciation of the diligence, competence and commitment of all those people who have been charged with delivering those changes. Often they must have thought there were far too many changes. Those changes have been designed by a large number of dedicated professionals in each of the divisions of the central office of the Department.

Regardless of our political differences, I am sure all honourable members have seen the changes in social security in the last three years and will join me in congratulating and thanking the Secretary and his staff. I also wish to place on record my appreciation of the work of Professor Cass as head of the Social Security Review and the many people who have worked for that Review. It is their detailed work which has made tonight's package possible.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since March 1983 what additional capital has the Government provided to Australian National Line.
(2) What have been the trade results of ANL since 1982-83.
(3) Does ANL have a significant foreign exchange risk exposure; if so, to what extent and how does it arise.
(4) Has ANL experienced losses on foreign exchange transactions as a result of movements in the value of the Australian dollar and other currencies; if so, what have been those losses since 1982-83.
(5) Does ANL attempt to hedge this foreign exchange risk; if so, how.
(6) If ANL does not attempt to hedge the risk, why not.
(7) What are the Government's guidelines for foreign exchange in Government business enterprises.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since March 1983 the Government has provided the Australian National Line (ANL) with total additional capital of $160.5m, comprising amounts of $90m in 1982-83 and $70.5m in 1984-85 (of which $60m and $50.5m respectively represented conversion of outstanding Commonwealth loans).
(2) Trade results for ANL since 1982-83 are detailed on page 7 of ANL's Annual Report which was tabled in December 1988. Profit (Loss) from all Sources figures are:

(3) ANL has no significant foreign exchange risk exposure in terms of its assets and liabilities. All overseas borrowings are fully hedged. On day-to-day operational transactions, ANL is a net exporter with foreign based revenues greater than foreign expenditure.

(4) Since 1982-83 ANL has incurred net abnormal/extraordinary foreign exchange losses on overseas borrowings totalling $55.4m as a result of declines in the value of the Australian dollar from the levels prevailing when foreign currency loans were taken out. In addition, exchange losses on day-to-day operations (other than for 1983-84 for which separate figures were not reported), relating mainly to reversion of overseas bank balances and hedging activity, totalled $14.2m.

However, a substantial proportion of the foreign exchange losses explicitly set out in the financial statements is offset by increases implicitly included in higher operating profits because of the same decline in the value of the Australian dollar. ANL's overseas borrowings were made in the same currencies as the revenue streams generated by ANL vessels involved in international trades. Such an approach provides a natural hedge against currencies fluctuations. The improvements in revenue streams, and therefore in operating profits, resulting from a weakening Australian dollar are not (and cannot) be separately highlighted in the financial statements. Assuming other factors remain largely unchanged, ANL currently estimates that over a 12 months period a one cent reduction in the value of the $A against the $US would increase ANL operating profits by approximately $1m.
Generally lower interest rates on foreign borrowings, compared with Australian dollar borrowings, also result in higher profits, and implicitly contribute to offsetting foreign exchange losses.

(5) ANL actively pursues a policy of risk minimisation in its management of foreign exchange exposure. Forward cover or other hedging mechanisms are employed for overseas capital transactions and all overseas borrowings are fully hedged. ANL constantly monitors its forecast revenue and expense streams and, where possible, adopts a policy of matching foreign payments and receipts.
(6) Not applicable.
(7) ANL was provided with guidelines for managing its dealings in foreign exchange in 1986. In summary, these provide:
that it shall generally adopt a risk averse policy in managing exposures, including the use of natural hedges as far as possible

that trading will only be undertaken in categories of transactions involving genuine financial risk exposure arising from activities in the performance of its functions under the Australian Shipping Commission Act 1956; and

that any policy approach for managing financial risk is to be specifically endorsed by Commission resolution before being generally adopted by management and that the Commission be informed at each meeting on all risk averse activities since the previous meeting.

Australia was represented at the last meeting of the Intergovernmental Committee (IGC) of the Convention in 1987 by a senior officer of my Department. That was the only IGC meeting to have been held since the meetings referred to in my earlier answer.

As indicated in the answer given on my behalf in the Senate on 22 August 1988 (Hansard page 26) to question No. 298, it is intended that Australia accede to the Convention in the near future. Australia already meets the Convention's requirements for phonograms (ie. records and tapes). Following the Copyright Law Review Committee's report on performers' protection, the Government has introduced the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 to provide performers with rights and remedies in relation to their performances. If passed, the amendments will meet the requirements of the Rome Convention for performers' protection. Amendments are also proposed to be made to the Copyright (International Protection) Regulations that will meet the Rome Convention requirements for protection of foreign broadcasts emanating from other Convention Countries. When these amendments have been made and brought into operations, the Government will therefore be able to accede to the Rome Convention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he aware of the recommendations contained in the Interim Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody with regard to abolishing the offence of public drunkenness.
(2) Does he see any scope for Commonwealth action in this area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) There is little scope, if any, for direct Commonwealth action, because for relevant purposes the Commonwealth's responsibilities are limited to certain Territories, in particular the Australian Capital Territory and Jervis Bay Territory. In both Territories the offences of being drunk in a public place and being found drunk and disorderly in a public place were abolished in 1983. Instead, the police have a power to detain temporarily, for protective purposes, a person who is disorderly or incapacitated due to being drunk.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, upon notice, on 2 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the Very Fast Train (VFT) Concept Report sponsored jointly by BHP, Elders IXL, Kumagai and TNT.
(2) Has his Department made an assessment of the economic feasibility of the project.
(3) Is the potential environmental impact of the project being assessed.
(4) Is the Government considering contributing funds towards the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) No. Officials are currently reviewing information provided by the VFT Joint Venture (including the Concept Report) and will provide advice to the Government in due course.

(3) In its Concept Report the VFT Joint Venture outlined the processes that will be followed in the feasibility study. These processes include an assessment of the potential environmental impact of the VFT project; the assessment will need to satisfy the environmental requirements of all governments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney- General, upon notice, on 6 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories received an offer, or any other expression of support, from Japan relating to the establishment of an Australian Federal Police Liaison office in Tokyo to keep Australia better informed on the activities of the Japanese criminal syndicate called Yakuza.
(2) Has the Government accepted this offer.
(3) Will the Government establish this office in Tokyo; it not, why not.
(4) Has the Government considered obtaining a presence in Japan to acquaint itself with the activities of the Yakuza.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, has advised me that he did not receive an offer or expression of support from Japan relating to the establishment of an Australian Federal Police Liaison office in Tokyo. Tokyo-based Australian media raised the possibility of Yakuza infiltration of tourism investments during Senator Richardson's visit to Japan in January 1989. Following his return to Australia Senator Richardson referred these allegations to the Minister for Justice.

(3) and (4) The Government will be considering the possibility of establishing additional Australian Federal Police liaison offices overseas. The value of establishing an office in Tokyo will be assessed along with other locations according to operational priorities and in the light of available resources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What policies does the (a) International Monetary Fund (IMF) and (b) World Bank generally require of borrowing countries as conditions for structural adjustment assistance.
(2) What assessments have been made of the effect of those adjustments policies on the poor in developing countries.

(3) What changes have been proposed by the United Nations Children's Fund and the International Labour Organisation to reduce the damaging effects of adjustment policies on the poor in developing countries.

(4) What changes in policies have been proposed by the Executive Director representing Australia at the (a) IMF and (b) World Bank to alleviate the negative effects of IMF or World Bank conditionally on the poor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Structural Adjustment Facility (SAF) and the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) were established by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to provide assistance, on concessional terms, to low income countries facing protracted balance of payments problems. The facilities are intended to support a member's medium term macroeconomic and structural adjustment programs and thereby help establish the conditions necessary for sustained economic growth. With assistance from the staff of the IMF and World Bank, a member seeking funding under SAF and ESAF must develop a three year adjustment program which is set out in a policy framework paper (PFP). The PFP outlines the macroeconomic and structural policy objectives and priorities, and the measures to be adopted during the three year period. The PFP contains a detailed description of the policies and reforms to be implemented in the first year and an assessment of the member's financing needs and likely sources of finance. In part, the PFP is intended to help a member attract additional financial support and to provide a basis for improving coordination amongst lender and donors.

The specific policies adopted under the PFP depend largely on the particular circumstance of the member. In general, however, members successful in obtaining SAF and ESAF assistance have outlined wide-ranging reforms, including the abolition of price controls and associated subsidies, trade and exchange rate liberalisation, tax reform, a reduction in fiscal imbalances and the restructuring of public sector enterprises.

(b) World Bank adjustment lending aims to increase the efficiency, flexibility and stability of the economies of borrowers with balance of payments difficulties. The basic objective is to strengthen the growth orientation and external viability of these economies. To this end policy improvements have been sought by the World Bank in four main interrelated areas: trade policy (eg. through reductions in barriers to trade), mobilization of domestic and foreign resources (eg. through improvements in the tax system and tax collection, and reductions in foreign investments regulations), efficiency in the use of domestic resources (eg. through economic pricing policies) and institutional reform (eg. through selective privatisation and increased competition). The precise blend of these reforms, the specific measures chosen to implement them, their timing, and their particular sector focus have depended on several factors, in particular, a country's initial economic condition and the strengths and weaknesses of its institutions. There are no general solutions; the design of adjustment programs has to be carefully tailored to meet specific needs and policy objectives of individual borrowers.

(2) The IMF Executive Board has recently examined the impact of Fund assisted adjustment programs on the poor in recipient countries. While experience has shown that adjustment does not necessarily lower the living standards of the poor, the review has served to increase the importance of designing programs so as to protect this disadvantaged population group.

The impact of adjustment policies on the poor was explored in the World Bank paper ``Protecting the poor during periods of adjustment'' discussed by the Development Committee of the World Bank at its April 1987 meeting. A copy of the publication has been forwarded to the honourable member. Fund and Bank papers on poverty issues including the impact of structural and adjustment policies on poverty alleviation are scheduled to be published shortly.

(3) The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), in its publication `Adjustment with a Human Face', has urged the combining of adjustment with protection of the vulnerable and the restoration of economic growth. Such an approach has six main policy components:
More expansionary macro-economic policies, with a more gradual timing of adjustment and larger amounts of medium-term external finance.
The selective use of economic policies for protecting the basic needs of the vulnerable.
Sectoral policies to strengthen employment and income generating activities.
Improving the equity and efficiency of social expenditure.
Compensatory programmes (often of limited duration) to protect the basic health and nutrition of low-income groups during adjustment.
Monitoring the living standards, health, and nutrition of low-income groups during the adjustment process.

The International Labour Organisation (ILO) convened a High Level Meeting on Employment and Structural Adjustment in Geneva from 23-25 November 1987, which concluded that adjustment policies should provide the basis for future growth of employment and incomes. The meeting advocated the urgent implementation of labour-intensive investment schemes, policies to increase the productive capacity of the poor, development of small and medium-scale enterprises, and efforts to improve the management of human resources. It also concluded that an open world trading system is vital for the attainment of this objective.

(4) (a) Australia's IMF Executive Director participated in the review of adjustment programs and the impact on the poor. Australia's position on this issue was essentially agreement with the consensus view of the Executive Board that considerable importance should be attached to improving program design so as to protect the poor during periods of adjustment.

(b) The Executive Director representing Australia has supported World Bank initiatives to re-emphasise the Bank's role in poverty alleviation and has also supported the Bank's policy of protecting the poor during adjustment. The Bank is helping adjusting countries address poverty problems by: (i) designing adjustment programs so that they take greater account of the effects of specific policies on the poor; (ii) maintaining, whenever possible, social expenditures that disproportionately benefit the poor, and improving targeting of other expenditures such as food subsidies; and (iii) designing short-term compensatory programs that benefit identifiable poor groups affected by adjustment, including employment generation through public works and food-for-work projects.

Australia supports World Bank and International Finance Corporation initiatives to assist small business development. Australia also supports the work of the Bank's Economic Development Institute which provides training to broaden the perspective and increase the competence of senior officials concerned with developmental work in the member countries of the Bank. Australia is funding a program of special support for the Bank's South Pacific Training Program.

In my Plenary Statement to the 1988 September IMF/World Bank Annual Meetings I emphasised that Australia welcomes the Bank's efforts to sharpen the focus of its attack on poverty. The Bank has provided an important and continuing stimulus to economic growth; this is the primary factor in alleviating poverty. Under growth-oriented adjustment programs, the lot of the poor can be improved through the fairer application of taxes and subsidies and more realistic exchange rates.
