TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 11 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What plans or proposals are in train for transferring Flight Service Units from country areas to capital cities.
(2) What Flight Service Units are proposed to be or will be moved and to which locations are they to be moved.
(3) What advantages are there in such moves.
(4) What technical difficulties and disadvantages will flow from such transfers.
(5) What are the cost-effective considerations of such moves.
(6) How many staff are employed at the Dubbo Flight Service Unit and what
(a) are their salaries; and
(b) is the annual cost of running this Unit.
(7) If the Dubbo FSU is moved, what facilities and staff will remain in Dubbo.
(8) What details are available of the cost-effectiveness of moving the Dubbo Flight Service Unit to a capital city.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As part of its drive to contain the rate of growth in costs attributable to the aviation industry, the CAA is pursuing a strategy which is designed to take advantage of the Australian communication satellite system by consolidating air traffic service functions and staff into fewer, larger centres. There are substantial benefits arising from such changes which will contain costs to the industry without any noticeable change in the manner in which services are provided to pilots. It is expected the change will extend over a period of about seven or eight years and that, in the medium term, services will be provided to the industry from five centres, based on capital cities.

(2) As indicated in the answer to Part (1) above, it is intended that Flight Services Units will be concentrated into centres in the capital cities, Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister identify each Senior Executive Service or equivalent position within the Minister's Department or authorities responsible to him which has been reclassified since 1 July 1988 and to which the occupant has been reappointed, indicating in each case (a) resultant increases in salary and other entitlements and (b) whether or not the reappointment followed normal selection procedures.
(2) On what basis is it claimed that the reclassifications conform with the national wage fixing principles.
(3) How many Senior Executive Service or equivalent positions are there within the Minister's portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There has been only one SES position or equivalent reclassified in the Department of Defence since 1 July 1988, viz, PN 1648, from SES Level 1 to SES Level 2. This position was subsequently filled by the permanent transfer of an SES officer at that level. Therefore answers to parts 1 (a) and 1 (b) are not applicable.

(2) The above position was created to head up a new Exports and International Programs Branch in conjunction with the restructuring of the Capital Procurement Organisation. The Branch is responsible for export policy and programs, and for providing a continuing focus on the development of collaborative arrangements with other countries for capital equipment production. Although initially established as a Level 1, the work value has been reassessed in the light of changes in responsibility. The scope of the industry operations functions has increased with a greater emphasis being given to commercialisation, exports and offsets. Additionally, the following functions have been added:
long term Nomad continuing support which involves authorising and controlling expenditure of around $2m per year;
administration of the CODOCK Trading Agreement Lease;
oversight of establishment of the Western Australian ship maintenance facilities including the Commonwealth contribution of $8m; and
technical/implementation aspects of collaboration with overseas countries in respect of equipment development under Memoranda of Understanding currently with UK and Sweden.

The increase in responsibilities exercised and the wider scope of functions managed have significantly increased the work value of the position to the extent where reclassification to Level 2 was warranted. The responsibilities are directly comparable in work value terms to those exercised by the other Branch Heads in the same Division.
The reclassification, therefore, conforms with national wage fixing principles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) By what authority were transcript charges of the Commonwealth Reporting Service increased to (a) $2 a page (or part page) for the first copy of transcript and (b) 10 cents a page (or part page) for subsequent copies of transcripts to the same purchaser, from 1 July 1988.
(2) What provisions are available for impecunious litigants considering an appeal who cannot afford those charges for transcripts which would be essential to the appeal.
(3) Is it a fact that the criteria which are acceptable to the courts for determining impecuniosity are not acceptable to the Commonwealth Recording Service.
(4) Does he endorse the withholding of transcripts on the ground that the applicant cannot afford the charges.
(5) Do persons ordering and paying for verbatim transcripts of evidence often receive edited transcripts; if so (a) how long has this been permitted and (b) does he condone this practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In March 1988 the Government decided to introduce charges for Commonwealth Reporting Service (CRS) services from 1 July 1988. That decision was made on the basis of recommendations of an Efficiency Scrutiny Report that CRS charge for its services on a partial cost recovery basis constructed to reduce demand. Charges were introduced to Courts, Tribunals and Inquiries, for the recording of proceedings, and to Courts, Tribunals, Inquiries and all other users for the provision of transcript in accordance with general user pay principles.

(2) The Government's decision was that any subsidy for transcript charges should not be borne by CRS. The cost of production of transcript, including subsidy in cases of hardship, was to be borne by and be identifiable with the appropriate agency rather than CRS. Any party suffering hardship as a result of having to meet the cost of transcript should seek assistance from an appropriate agency, such as Legal Aid, as is the case in relation to other costs associated with litigation.

(3) In view of the Government's decision that CRS should charge all users of transcript and that the cost of any exemption from such charges not be borne by CRS, the question of determining impecuniosity is not one for consideration by CRS.

(4) Upon receipt of an order for transcript, CRS provides a copy of that transcript to the person or organisation placing the order and subsequently issues an invoice. If the amount is not paid the credit facility is no longer available to that customer. Upon payment of the outstanding amount, the credit facility is restored to the customer. Until the outstanding amount is paid, CRS will not supply any further transcript to that customer except upon immediate payment of the charges for that additional transcript. In cases of genuine hardship assistance may be obtained from appropriate agencies (see (2) above).

(5) Transcripts are not edited but it is not unusual for a Court or Tribunal to request CRS to provide an abridged transcript of proceedings in an effort to conserve resources, reduce the cost of producing transcript and enable CRS to provide a more timely service.

An abridged transcript is readily identifiable by the notation `Recorded: Not Transcribed' in the body of the transcript. Of course, CRS retains the original tape recordings and/or shorthand notes of the untranscribed segment(s) of proceedings and it is open to the Court or Tribunal, or a party to the proceedings, to order a complete, unabridged, verbatim transcript of those proceedings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 2 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he read the full transcript of the South African Ambassador's comment during an interview in Sydney regarding the shooting of an African National Congress representative, when he was reported as saying it could not have happened to a nicer bunch of guys.
(2) What action does he propose to take in response to calls for the reprimanding of the South African Ambassador.
(3) What response has been directed to the South African Ambassador.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) The Government rejects totally the remarks by the South African Ambassador which implicitly condone the shooting attack against the house of the ANC Representative, Mr Eddie Funde. On 20 February 1989, my Department advised the South African Embassy that the Ambassador's remarks in interviews following the shooting had given rise to written complaints to the Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. My Department reiterated to the Embassy the need for statements from diplomatic missions to observe normal proprieties and, in particular, that material should not be cast in terms offensive to the Australian Government or individuals. This is consistent with the guidelines on public statements and media releases which have been sent to all diplomatic missions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 2 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the procedures for the use of Commonwealth cars by the staff of Members and Senators in 1987-88 and what did this service cost.
(2) What changes have been made to the procedures in 1988-89.
(3) What are the perceived advantages of the new system.
(4) What is the estimated cost to the Commonwealth of the new procedures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1987-88 the procedure for booking Commonwealth cars for electorate staff of Members and Senators required staff to telephone the Transport Booking Office at the appropriate branch of the Transport and Storage Group of the Department of Administrative Services quoting the hire code of the Member or Senator and the transport requirement. Staff had access to car transport at government expense when directed to travel under the electorate office staff travel entitlement. Staff were expected to nominate the lower cost service supplied by the Transport and Storage Group. Because costs were charged to Members and Senators it is not possible to provide an accurate cost of electorate staff use of Commonwealth cars. Departmental records show however that identifiable electorate office staff car transport costs in 1987-88 were $133,594.
Similar arrangements applied to the staff of Ministers and Office-holders when travelling at their direction. Separate hire codes existed for these staff.

(2) In 1988-89 there has been no change in the booking procedure other than the use of separate hire codes for electorate office staff. Staff have also been reminded that the standard level of service should be utilised. Staff access to car services has been extended to enable them to carry out their duties within the electorate or State including the State Capital and in Canberra as directed by their Member or Senator.

(3) In 1988-89 a budget approach for electorate staff travel was introduced. Electorate staff travel costs are met from a budget and staff also have access to car transport when travelling within the electorate at the direction of the Member or Senator. Each electorate office has been issued with a hire code to be used when making staff car bookings. The budget approach provides an incentive for offices choosing to select lower cost services.

The revised staff travel arrangements are designed to increase the productive capacity of staff and thereby form a major offset required for awarding the Second Tier salary increase to electorate staff.

The arrangements for access to Commonwealth car transport have been clarified and it is expected that for the same level of expenditure on car transport more flexible travel arrangements will be possible. Staff travel costs will no longer be shown on the record as having been undertaken by Members and Senators.

(4) No additional administrative costs are involved with the revised arrangements. It is expected that closer attention to the cost of services will result in a greater capacity for staff to travel with a budget neutral outcome.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 6 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister explain Australia's policy and attitude towards the self-determination movement in Eritrea.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government favours a negotiated settlement in Ethiopia as the means to ending the needless suffering of both sides and of helping to restore regional stability. There are some recent indications that parties to the dispute are at least considering negotiations as an option. However, the gap between their positions remains wide.

The conflicts in Ethiopia are regarded, both by the UN and by Ethiopia's neighbours, as internal political struggles rather than between sovereign nations. The UN has no mandate to intervene in such situations.
Whilst the Australian Government will continue to provide humanitarian assistance to Ethiopians, it is not in a position to secure a political role for the United Nations in relation to Eritrea.

The Australian Government's concern at the situation was reflected in its decision to increase humanitarian aid to Ethiopia to a total of $13.3 million for 1987/88. Australian assistance is directed towards emergency needs, particularly towards the regions of greatest need.
The Australian Government will encourage arrangements for the peaceful settlement of the conflicts which are acceptable to the parties concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was Australia involved in the recent Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) hosted seminar with Asian industrial countries.
(2) Does Australia support closer cooperation between the OECD and developing industrial countries; if so, how could this cooperation be fostered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, Australia has played an active part in promoting dialogue between the OECD and the Newly Industrialised Economies (NIEs) of Asia (Republic of Korea, Singapore, Hong Kong and Taiwan). The first informal seminar between the OECD and the Asian NIEs was held in Paris on 24-25 January 1989 and Australia was represented by its Ambassador to the OECD, Mr E. M. W. Visbord OBE, and senior officials. Dr Ross Garnaut, who was personally invited to the seminar by the OECD Secretary-General, also attended.

(2) Australia does support closer cooperation between the OECD and developing industrial countries, particularly those in the Asian region. The Paris seminar was a valuable first step in fostering such cooperation. There was wide support for the continuation of the dialogue among the seminar participants, who are currently consulting on the best way to pursue the dialogue.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Finance: Security Checks of Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 4 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department and any authority responsible to the Minister have any requirement to conduct security checks of its staff, if so, are security checks carried out by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO).

(2) If security checks are required and are not undertaken by ASIO, (a) by whom are they carried out and (b) does a review procedure equivalent to that contained in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act apply to such checks; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Normal pre employment checks are applied to all staff according to Public Service guidelines. The Department of Finance and other authorities responsible to the Minister conduct security checks on staff members who in the normal course of their duties have access to national security material. In such cases it is a standard procedure, in accordance with Public Service guidelines, to seek a security assessment from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation as part of the security checking process.

(2) Other security checks are required when an officer occupies a position identified as a Position of Trust. A Position of Trust is a position which involves the custody of stores, equipment, public moneys, or sensitive information other than national security material.

To establish the reliability and trustworthiness by the person concerned, checks are carried out by specifically authorised officers of the employing Department or authority, the review procedures for these checks are according to Public Service guidelines. They are not referred to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, as these particular checks are outside the elements of security as strictly limited by the ASIO Act.
